reviews.content: You have to admire the chutzpah of the people who took on the project of creating a sequel to "Blair Witch Project". The original made so much money and created such a furor that a sequel was inevitable...and yet, the elements the made the original such a surprise success (including the marketing campaign and the relative novelty and uniqueness of the plot and production elements) were no longer available to the makers of any sequel. So anyone volunteering (or assigned) for this 'suicide job' faced the problems of retaining the 'freshness' of the original while not being too derivative of it. To succeed under these conditions, you'd either have to be divinely inspired or incredibly lucky. Well, these guys weren't either of those things, and they didn't even come close. They do one thing right - they take a 'postmodern' spin on the plot by acknowledging the effects of the original movie on popular culture - in fact, the opening of the story reveals that there is practically a "BWP" cottage industry in and around Burkittsville which exploits the commercial success and interest raised by the first film. That's reasonably clever scripting and gives a credible reason for a motley group of people to go back to the original site - they are on a guided tour to the site. In fact, the wittiest moment of the film is when "our" tour group encounters another guided tour group and they argue over who gets to camp where, etc. Where the original was about "bewilderment", hysteria, "woods shock", and agoraphobia, the sequel tries to keep up the interest factor with group psychosis, mass hallucination, Dionysian possession and claustrophobia, and it tries to keep the audience guessing about what 'really' happened that night in the woods and whether something followed them back. It also is far louder, less subtle, more explicit and gory (although you could argue that the sex and violence is revealed in video flashbacks to the surprise and horror of the cast). However, just about everything in the film is done at in a way that combines facile slickness (money was obviously spent on this film) with mediocre execution. In fact, with a different framing sequence and plot device (and a little less nudity and violence), "Book Of Shadows" could have been an extended entry in an anthology series like "Tales From The Darkside", "Tales From The Crypt", or "Night Gallery". Those were always OK to watch if nothing else was on, but they were nothing you'd be willing to pay money to see. The acting and dialog is especially problematic. That was true in the original as well, but the actors (and their dialog) were always captured in grainy, low definition half-heard 'documentary' style that was part of the point of the movie. Here, it's front and center, and there is no escaping the fact that these actors and the director aren't very good, and the movie wears out its welcome very quickly.Still, if you don't think of this as a "Blair Witch" story, and just take it in, it isn't all that bad. I've seen a hundred 50's and 60's sci fi and exploitation films with worse camera work, sound design, costumes, and yes, acting and dialog. So if you only half watch it as background while you read a magazine, or neck with your girlfriend or drink beer, etc., "Book Of Shadows" will go down painlessly enough. I just hope you didn't pay real money to see it the theater in its first release.

reviews.review_title: Why, oh why did they bother?
reviews.content: Why did they bother to make this film? More to the point, why did I bother to go see it?The first Blair Witch was more of a pop phenomena than a good film; the idea of promoting the whole deal over the Internet, and a film made using DVs and Betacams about a walk in the woods was excellent. It all added up so well.But no, this guys had to go and make another film. They wanted some cash, and they wanted it so badly they made such an awful movie it almost guarantees everyone who was involved with it can say bye-bye to their careers.While the original shone because of the creepy, raw and bad quality it had, the new one is terribly bad because of the same traits. It's just that these time, a "real" movie was tried, with disastrous results. Everyone's acting is wooden and planned; while the 3 actor's terror in the first movie was real and palpable this is just another dumb movie with no emotions whatsoever. The story is so convoluted you won't be able to reach any conclusions at the film's end. The movie is so predictable you will begin wondering if they wrote it in 1 evening or two. Worst of all, you can see the merchandising you will be assaulted with shortly all over the film. What a shame of a movie!This movie is dumb, stupid and bad. It deserves all the bad critics it can get. I had never seen a sequel so bad since "The Fandom Menace" came out. Well, at least there wasn't any Jar Jar Binks on this movie.

I liked this movie. I don't get the low rating. It was filmed well and tied in with the first film. Were there some superfluous scenes. Yes! But I enjoyed the comedy horror mix and was intrigued where it was headed. Not a rock music fan but love the opening song.

reviews.review_title: My guilty pleasure, would recommend to anyone
reviews.content: Ok, if you're looking for the Blair witch project 2 THIS IS NOT IT! This film is a completely different entity and breaks the 4th wall in which the Blair Witch Project is seen as just a movie and the main characters are fans of it only. But this film is just awesome. I know a lot of people hate it but it's the (almost) perfect horror. Slow start, character development, then scares and then its climatic. It helps if you've seen the first movie though to enjoy what the characters in this a referring to in their dialogue.

You spend most of your time at "Book of Shadows: Blair Witch 2" waiting for something scary to make you scream. Unfortunately, nothing nerve-wracking jumps out and grabs you by the jugular in this lurid but lackluster sequel to the most lucrative independent horror epic of all time. Okay, you may break out in goose bumps galore as you anticipate your worst fears, but those fears will never engulf you, unless you are extremely squeamish. Not only does "BW2" lack the agoraphobic hysteria of the original with its creepy, black & white photography, and epileptic hand-held camera work, but also writer & director Joe ("Brother's Keeper") Berlinger and co-scribe Dick ("House on Haunted Hill") Beebe ignore the mystery about what became of Heather, Joshua, Michael, and more crucially, the witch--Elly Kedward. Instead, they expose "The Blair Witch Project" as outrageous hokum, then contrive a pretentious, anticlimactic, often incoherent chiller about obsessive moviegoers who channel inspiration from "TBWP" to wreck murder and mayhem. Ironically, Berlinger classifies "BW2" as a "fictional reenactment of events that occurred after 'The Blair Witch Project' was released." Again, the line between reality and illusion blurs but with considerably less appeal. Consciously arguing the media dictates reality, Berlinger sets out with this elaborate agenda to helm a mediocre gorefest that indulges more often in propaganda than peril. Like its predecessor, "BW2" suffers from dull characters that rarely engage out sympathies. Artisan Entertainment has beefed up the budget this time, so the Black Hills around Burkittsville, Maryland, ooze with gratuitous blood, gore, sex, sodomy, and sadism. "The Blair Witch Project" appears prudish compared with its promiscuous, overwrought Technicolor sequel. Despite its bigger budget, better cast, and occasional glimpses of evil, "BW2" leaves less to the imagination than its restrained, artfully ambiguous predecessor. Since a shoestring budget prevented "TBWP" from showing us its monster--the witch, the filmmakers exploited our fears by concealing the evil as well as using jittery movement to perpetuate our curiosity. Sadly, after a tantalizing, tension-fraught build-up, "TBWP" wrapped up on an anti-climax, because the movie could not pay off the suspense it created with a display of evil. While "TBWP" exploited this simple, amateurish, pseudo- documentary approach in its depiction of evil, "BW2" complicates its relentlessly conventional haunted house plot with confusing flashbacks and flash forwards, sabotaging any sense of suspense about its abrasive characters who emerge as even more enigmatic than Heather, Joshua, and Michael."BW2" opens with an amusing mockumentary about "TBWP." Briefly recapping the original's phenomenal success, MTV's Kurt Loder, late night talk show hosts Conan O'Brien and Jay Leon, and film critic Roger Ebert rhapsodize about the movie while Burkittsville natives describe their newfound celebrity status. One local explains she sold all the rocks in her garden to "Blair Witch" trophy hunters. She tried to sell more rocks on the Internet, but the shipping costs proved exorbitant. Berlinger frames this clever opening gambit so it mimics the 16mm dimensions of the original "Blair Witch." Afterward, "BW2" lurches off into its own plot and degenerates into an undistinguished, reality-versus-illusion supernatural saga about an ex-mental patient turned "Blair Witch" tour guide (Jeff Donovan) who leads a quartet of souvenir seekers on safari into the same ominous woods where Heather and the guys vanished. Like "TBWP," "BW2" enhances its realism by letting the cast use their actual first names. Unfortunately, Berlinger's sequel doesn't imitate the impromptu, cinema verite look of the original. He shoots "BW2" as a traditional formula Hollywood fright flick, departing momentarily from this slick, glossy style during the orgy when he quickens the editing rhythm and lenses the action "NYPD" style. No, you need not take Dramamine to survive this sequel.The script by Berlinger and Beebe is no great shakes. Basically, "BW2" occurs in two acts, first in the woods around Rustin Parr's ruins and later in Jeff's fortress of solitude (equipped with an Archie Bunker dog alarm so when the door opens a recording of barking dogs can be heard) where our heroes hole up after their bucolic bacchanalia. Meanwhile, flashbacks and flash-forwards involving murder, mayhem, and police interrogation are spliced confusingly into the narrative. Two realities emerge. Jeff tells Kim "film lies, but video tells the truth." The truth appears in the videotape sequences from either Jeff's cameras or the surveillance cameras, while the characters see what the film sequences show, little realizing how warped their own perception of reality remains. Anticlimactically, the organic horror of the "Blair Witch" takes a backseat to the immediate horror of their demonic possession. Berlinger prefers to play up the clash between his possessed principals than the presence of the witch. Big mistake. Elly Kedward is still more interesting than these oddball characters with their domestic squabbles.Altogether, "BW2" qualifies as a pointless, inconsistent sequel with goose bumps about a "Deliverance" like encounter between demonic spirits and a motley bunch of twentysomethings who go berserk and turn on each other. Valiantly, writer & director Joe Berlinger strives to create a different kind of authenticity compared with the first film, but he founders in his own sea of pretentious ideas. Berlinger should have heeded the old saying: if it ain't broke, don't try to fix it. In debunking and refocusing the elements of the original, "Book of Shadows: Blair Witch 2" blunders off on an even more tedious tangent to tedium. Boo . . . Hiss.

Blair Witch 2: Book of Shadows was surprisingly better than the snoozfest, the Blair Witch Project. It was better than I had expected after seeing the first. This movie wasn't that scary, but I enjoyed it. I thought Kim Director and Jeffrey Donovan were ok in the movie, but the others were nothing special. If I had to grade the movie, I'd give it a B+. It wasn't exactly great, but at least it was an enjoyable movie. I recommend it to horror fans.

reviews.review_title: It wasnt quite as bad as I remembered but it was still bad and disappointing.
reviews.content: Book of Shadows: Blair Witch 2 (2000) is currently available for free on Tubi and tells the tale of a group that wants to take advantage of the Blair Witch phenomenon from the first movie and create their own tour of Burkittsville, Maryland. As they investigate the area they have a rough initial night in the woods that may have included an encounter with the Blair Witch herself. As they begin setting up their organization they experience a series of strange encounters that threatens their ambitions and sparks tramas from their past. This movie is directed by Joe Berlinger (Crude and Addiction Documentaries) and the cast includes Kim Director (Inside Man), Erica Leerhsen (The Texas Chainsaw Massacre, 2003), Stephen Barker Turner (Law & Order) and Tristine Skyker (Getting to Know You). The storyline and execution of this film could have been so much better. The premise had potential but once they put it in motion the film losses steam after the first 15-20 minutes. The introduction and character rollout was good, but that's about it. The director choice was poor, the script seemed rushed to capitalize off the first movie's success, and the conclusion was awful. It wasnt quite as bad as I remembered but it was still bad and disappointing. They should have let the original directors write and create the sequel. Overall, I'd give it a 4/10.

I gotta say i don't see how this film has such bad reviews i love the cast the plot the entire film for me was just one of my favorites. And yes it's a low budget film but greatly done in my book of shadows..

Once again, another great film is misunderstood by most people.  Blair Witch 2 is one of the best films of the year, and far superior to the first film. 
The point of Blair Witch 2 is that there ultimately is no absolute reality. I won't give away the plot, but all I will say is that an extremely violent event occurs, and the film is about how this violence effects the supposed perpetrators of the violence and the community in which the violence is committed.  Everything in this film is purposefully ambiguous because that is how reality now is like in our media-driven culture.  Through the medium of video and film, several different layers of reality are created, and all of them can be equally true.  That, in a nutshell, is the whole point of Blair Witch 2.  Berlinger cleverly cuts back and forth between film and video to reveal how these two different mediums can both distort and reflect reality.In the end, when yet another level of reality is revealed to the viewer, one is left shocked and reeling.  Don't believe what other people say, see Blair Witch 2 and make up your own mind.  It will change your perception of reality forever.

I was so excited when this movie came out. I was a huge fan of the original and had such home for this sequel. I was so disappointed. This movie not only has a terrible story and is poorly made, but it intentionally tries to reimagine the first movie, in a negative way.It is the end that is the most jarring and memorable thing about this movie. When this movie ended, I literally thought the film broke or there was a problem with my theater's copy and that the real end was missing. This movie seemed unfinished more than any other movie I have ever seen. It is an abomination.

When I watch a horror movie I want to be scared. This wasnt ever scary at all nothing in the this movie was scary. Well theres a few parts that are pretty good but most of the movie just isn't any good. Now the first one was. Anyways If you like this first one you probably wont like this one. And If you dont like horror movie then you really wont like this one.

Let me start off by saying this movie is definitely not PERFECT. The acting was shotty at times, the effects weren't always real, and sometimes you felt like pressing the Stop button. BUT, it was still good. First off, this movie is NOT like the original at all. This movie is like the aftermath of the first movie hitting the big screen. This movie is not shot on a camcorder like the first, and there are more than just 3 characters. We have the 5 main characters (Jeff, Kim, Stephen, Erica, and Tristan), and an assortment of supporting characters. This movie sometimes feels like The first, but other times like an entirely different movie. I'll admit, this movie is VERY hard to follow. I lost track myself a few times. But, if you are a Die-Hard Blair Witch Project fan like me, you will like this. Recommend for fans of the first. 7/10

reviews.review_title: it is a good movie deserve better rating
reviews.content: I think the reason this movie is under rated is because people like the first one too much, it was raw, and its totally unpolished documentary style.Without putting the first one in you head, this one is very well crafted. The editing is intriging, characters are a cool combination and all well played. I like the witch character girl especially. The missing hours footage they found out later is crazy and fit in the movie very well. I have to say i wish there was more straight supernatual images in the first one. The first one was too murky in this way.One thing, the music is way too modern of pop rock n roll. Should have better taste. The end theme song haunted from Poe is good though.

reviews.review_title: The Blair Witch has nothing on the evil at Artisan....
reviews.content: Blair Witch 2: Book of Shadows is one of the those movies you go into with absolutely zero expectations --- actually, negative expectations --- and if you come out grasping even a shred of coherent film-making you don't feel so bad.Having been a fan of the first film (why else would you have any interest in seeing this one?) it was hard to figure out where they were going to take it, but I'm also familiar with Joe Berlinger's impressive body of doc work, so I took a chance (thinking it odd he would agree to do something so blatantly non-indy).It turns out, though, that it's maybe even more painful to watch this movie than if it were just a hacked-together retread directed by some grade-Z idiot director. Because Berlinger actually had some really good ideas, but as is quite usual, he was forced to make a lot of changes in pace, tone, scene order, etc. by the studio, all at the last minute. He was also forced to shoot extra footage that he repeatedly says on the DVD commentary that he was loathe to put in.And for good reason... There's a really interesting psychological horror film in here someplace, and occasionally it surfaces. Throughout the movie, Berlinger plays with our minds in the same way the five protagonists play with each other's. Is there really a Blair Witch? Are all the stories of evil merely BS? Or is something evil really coming from within themselves? And if so, is that evil being directed by supernatural forces or merely their own paranoia? Interesting questions, yes --- a hell of a lot more provocative than 90 minutes of "TELL ME WHERE YOU ARE JOSH!!!!!" --- but none are really answered here, and too much is obscured by Berlinger's badly mangled plot and ridiculous over-the-top, extremely fake-looking gore and (ha ha) special effects that take incompetence with CGI to a new low.The evil here is really in Artisan's money-hungry, impatient executives, who were so rabid to cook up a sequel in six months that they ruined what could have been a small miracle: a sequel with more soul and brains than it's provocative, if not exploitative, predecessor.

There's a tradition for bad sequels in horror movies but this is an absolute outrage. The first movie is obviously incredibly true and brilliant to the best things in horror. The second is the worst in exploitation horror from the 80s like "The Burning" - but in "The Burning" we understood what was going on. This movie makes no sense at all - neither the horror, the characters or the story. Watch the first one twice (or more) instead. I have to add something now to get to over the minimum requirement of words. Anyway, it just seems like this movie was made to make money on the success of the first one, which was actually quite good and original. This one is not. It's a bit like "Hostel" and "Hostel 2". Surely "Hostel 2" was not a very good sequel.

Tour group, obsessed with the Blair Witch legend, spend the night living it up in the spot where the infamous child killer Rustin Parr once lived, waking up the next morning with 5 hours unaccounted for as shredded paper snow upon their faces, cameras broken to pieces. Later they discover on a news broadcast that another touring group was attacked and disemboweled. Prime suspects and succumbing to weird hallucinations, they find tapes which might recount what happened during their black out better shedding light on five hours which are lost to them. Fearing that the Blair Witch is real and causing the hallucinations overcoming them, the group will attempt to piece together what happened as they unravel mentally to unusual circumstances occurring to them. Is the Blair Witch real? Or, are these characters merely so obsessed with the mythos of Elly Kedward that they conjure her up, leading to unspeakable acts by a group of people too consumed with a story where she seems so real even if she isn't? I will always be mixed about this film. There are many scenes I think work well. Like when tour guide, Jeffrey Donovan and his group, goth chick Kim Director, Wiccan "nature witch" Erica Leerhsen, & Elly Kedward researchers, Tristen Skyler and Stephen Barker Turner discover the missing footage by replaying backwards. The idea of discovering a time you can not remember playing back and revealing creepy things always works for me. When Tristine approaches the screen standing at about the same pose as Heather Donahue from "The Blair Witch Project", except carrying a sinister look, really gave me the creeps. The opening interviews(..which look like video documented footage)of annoyed citizens(..and a few who have profited from obsessed fans who have infiltrated their quite town)are very funny. I also like how crazy fans are lampooned as Ebay is mentioned. And Jeffrey's home is a nifty warehouse where he contains lots of cool technology which are used against him and his co-horts. Like the first film, these characters begin having a great time, drinking and smoking, just enjoying the event for what it is, only later falling prey to either supernatural forces, or problems of their own making. Maybe Berlinger's parable of media consumption causing us to commit acts is laid on a bit thick, but it is an interesting template to explore. But, I really hate when an opening camera fly over the Blair Witch mountains is interrupted with murders that will later occur. And, the whole asylum deal with Jeffrey left me rather underwhelmed. I think this really beats us over the head that Jeffrey isn't exactly mentally healthy. And, director Berlinger just keeps bringing it back up over and over. While I enjoyed how this film takes little joyous jabs at the first film, the way this tale unravels as our tour group see ghostly apparitions which could or could not exist(..among other things)I think Berlinger, attempting as much ambiguity as possible, loses the audience. I can respect ambiguity, I do, but after a while Berlinger really pummels us over the head with a lot of confusing situations which finally erupts into chaos at the end when Tristine is believed to be Elly. I do really like the final sequence at the end which shows from video evidence that what the characters were experiencing throughout doesn't correspond with what is actually recorded to be quite chilling. This is where Berlinger succeeds the most, I think. We experienced, through their madness, situations that perhaps never took place, delusions created by fans so obsessed with an untrue legend that fiction became fact in their minds..we are participants of this with the final sequence of events(..the interrogation and their acts caught on tape)revealing that we have just spent a great period of time with folks who believe strongly in something that is false.

Where do I start?  This movie was the kind of flick that ruins a director's career.  That sap, Joe Berlinger, has yet to direct another film since and THANK GOD.  This movie was terrible and I got tired of the godawful acting. Erica is laughably blank and is supposed to be this wiccan who is in touch with what's going on -- yet she's the FIRST to die and is as clueless as the rest of them when things start going haywire.  The guy who plays Sheriff Cravens is unintentionally hilarious -- I keep waiting for him to say "I'm gonna git dem Duke boys!" and drive off to Hazzard County, he deserves the Shatner award for overacting.  Stephen is horrible and tells a stupid joke that made absolutely no sense and left everyone in the theater with me saying "huh?"  People say this movie is supposed to make you think, and they were right:  I began to think that I'd wasted my time and money and I was right.  This movie won the Razzie award for WORST sequel of 2001 and in my opinion is the worst sequel ever made... and that includes Exorcist 2, Texas Chainsaw Massacre 4, The Phantom Menace, Leprechan 2-whatever, any Friday the 13th movie, any Nightmare on Elm Street movie and any Chucky movie.  The worst part is that they used that RIDICULOUS "esrever" thing as a marketing ploy to get people to watching it again!  Why not just fall on your knees and beg people to watch your lame flick?Oh, and to the reviewer that said he needed to smack people who didn't like this movie:  you have real courage... especially since you didn't even have the guts to put your real name on your review.  We who hated this movie (and there are many) are so scared of you.

The first Blair Witch movie was just awful.  I saw it in the theatre, and it was the very first movie I wanted to walk out of.  No solid storyline, made no sense, it wasn't believeable, and the acting wasn't up to par...oh, and the camera angles, jerky movements, etc made it that much worse.  Blair Witch 2, which shouldn't even really have that title if you ask me, is the same thing all over again, just with a bigger budget and a LITTLE less jerky camera stuff.  This movie has even less of a plot that the first did, and the end is even more unsatisfying as the original.  So, the acting wasn't the worst, but it wasn't that good...and the whole basis of the plot was just silly.  This is one of those movies where you see everything happen, then in the end- you find out you were either lied to the whole time or someone screwed with reality in some way as to make you think you saw what you saw when you really didn't.  Make sense?  Good, neither did this movie. That's because there was nothing to make sense of. If you're going to make any film, you need a script to start off with...a good one would help, but this movie doesn't even have a bad one.  It feels like a reel of film full of weird images and quick flashes of what seems to be mayhem...the director clearly thought editing would make this movie...it didn't.  I would stay away from this entire series no matter what...especially this one. 
1/10 - one since I was actually able to watch it till then end without shutting it off and cancelling cable, because it sucked so badly!

reviews.review_title: A lot better than the weak, amateurish mess that was the first film
reviews.content: I don't understand why so many people are rating this film so low, while there are so many people who are voting so high for the first film; this is clearly a far superior film. Both are independent, but this actually has some scary scenes, whereas the first just had three stupid teenagers running around in the woods, getting drunk and high, and finally disappearing. This is far better. The film is about a few people who go into the same woods that the stupid teens went into in the first film; something very strange and apparently unexplainable happens, and they spend the rest of the film trying to figure out what exactly happened. The plot is very good, it starts out reminding the audience a lot of the first, and then drastically changing style, turning into a mystery-horror piece. The plot immediately takes off, I was pretty much completely into the film from the very first scene, whereas the first almost had me falling asleep during the first couple of scenes. It also has a great pace, while there constantly is something interesting or exciting going on, to keep you watching, without it getting cheesy, like many new Hollywood-like horror films tend to do. The acting is far better than the first film, at least for most of the characters. The main characters all seemed perfectly credible to me, which is far more than what I can say about the cast of the first film. Some of the supporting cast did seem a little lacking in acting ability, but these aren't actual actors, after all. The special effects and various shock effects are surprisingly good; I would be lying if I said I didn't jump in my seat at least three or four times. Now, as for the negative in the film; admittedly, the execution isn't as good as the idea itself, which is a bit unfortunate, because this plot really has potential, or, rather, "had". Definitely more potential than the film utilizes, unfortunately. I can't complain about any of the scary scenes or special effects, they were all handled extremely well; even things that, had they been done just in a slightly different manner, would have looked ridiculous, and made the viewer laugh out loud rather than send chills down his spine. This film is about as far away from the original as it could possibly get, without actually using a completely different story. All in all, a very well-made horror film, that far surpasses the mess that was the first Blair Witch film. I recommend it to anyone who saw the first and was sorely disappointed by it, and any fans of horror in general, as it will please most generic horror fans with it's reasonably vast amount of blood and gore, and the amount of shocks and jumpy moments. 6/10

reviews.review_title: Throw the Book at This One.
reviews.content: Book of Shadows: Blair Witch 2 (2000): Dir: Joe Berlinger / Cast: Kim Director, Stephen Barker Turner, Tristen Skyler, Jeffrey Donovan, Erica Leerhsen: Whereas The Blair Witch Project used atmosphere to render suspense, this stupid sequel uses nudity, bad acting, and scenes of tourists being gutted. There is also no book in the film so the title is irrelevant, but then again, there is no evidence of a script either. Just a bunch of meatheads obsessed with The Blair Witch Project. They set up a camera and watch strange things happen that they cannot explain. Basically no plot and the story relies heavily on gore and violence. Joe Berlinger can be credited for making things uncertain and stresses minds warped by media influence but the screenwriter is another bust altogether. Special effects are terrific with haunting atmosphere but the acting really sucks. Bad acting by Kim Director, Stephen Barker Turner, Tristen Skyler, Erica Leerhsen, and Jeffrey Donovan. One wonders if they comprehend how embarrassing they look in this foolishness. One of the females sits on the floor in a trance rocking back and forth like a jackass. That is where the people with the white jackets should arrive and take this nut job away. Bypassed theme of evil committed by people whose minds do not fully comprehend with actors who do not fully comprehend how foolish they look in it. Score: 2 / 10
Like most sequels, it's not as good as the original, that being said this is a solid movie with some good scares, and a solid payoff.

In 1999 the world was subject to one of the smartest marketing schemes the film industry has ever seen with The Blair Witch Project. We now travel to Burkitsville where the aftermath of the film has spawned more attention than Beatle-mania. Tourists come and go hoping that they can get a glimpse of the Blair Witch. Now we find ourselves watching a string of events so pointless that no sense is to be made out of anything from start to finish. Meet out tour group, five teens consisting of and ex mental patient, a writer and his pregnant girlfriend, a real life witch and a gothic psychic who are going out into the woods to uncover the truth of what really happened in the first film. If the thought of a Blair Witch sequel doesn't leave a bad taste in your mouth the fact that filmmakers are actually trying to push this as a true story should. At the beginning of the film we get a message that this is a fictionalized account of actual events. Give me a break, how stupid do these people really think we are, if you found the first a little hard to believe than this one is sure to make your brain melt. Director Joe Berlinger has such a hard time deciding what kind of film he is trying to make that it is almost more nauseating than the camera work in the first. We start off with a documentary style filming, reminiscing of the first, then kick into gory slasher movie, next comes teen explotion flick, then we come to psychotic House on Haunted Hill rip-off. The script is horrible and the story makes not the least bit of sense and you better believe that you won't get an explanation for anything that happens at the end of the film. Berlinger seems more interested in just filming some weird images and having them edited into one huge mess rather than making a horror movie (believe me there is not one scare to be had in the entire film). Berlinger has had great success with his acclaimed Paradise Lost documentaries but it is clear he is not ready for a major motion picture. We see foreshadowing and flashbacks and flashbacks within flashbacks and strange dream sequences, you will find yourself totally lost by the halfway mark, but that doesn't really matter because it all amounts to nothing anyway. I would be lying if I said that I hated the first Blair Witch Project but why it needed a sequel is beyond me especially since this one losses sight of the Blair Witch completely about fifteen minutes in and there is not one mention of a Book of Shadows. The acting is horrible, the direction is horrible, the script is horrible, it is by no means a sequel, a prequel or a remake and I can honestly say that it ranks among my list of worst movies I've ever seen, avoid at all costs.

reviews.review_title: I don't like this movie because ...
reviews.content: The plot makes no sense, the acting is poor, the music isn't that good, it lacks continuity over all, and it is obviously an attempt to capitalize on the popularity of the first movie (which was a very good flick). Trying to capitalize on a previous film isn't a bad thing if its done well, certainly. But this film isn't done well. It was, for me (and this is my opinion, so if you liked this movie and disagree don't take it as a personal affront, because movie reviews are opinions and NOT personal affronts or an abuse), a total let down from beginning to end. On the plus side I thought the photography was fairly well done, but thats about the only redeeming quality I saw. Over all ... Its just not worth watching.

reviews.review_title: I could put on a better show with sock-puppets!
reviews.content: This movie is an absolute shambles. It totally crapped on everything that the first Blair Witch movie stood for. And who is responsible? Dick Beebe and Joe Berlinger are, for writing this goofy mess. As people have already commented, what made the first Blair Witch great is the way it was filmed, docu-style with two camcorders. The elements of mystery were what made the movie great and gave it its eerie mood. Blair Witch 2 follows the exploits of a group of weed-smoking teenage student cretins, who have flashbacks to past and present in which they are savagely attacked in the woods. This movie is unbelievable, it was shot like a normal movie with real cameras and Dolby stereo sound which completely detracted the creepyness of the first. I hated all the characters, they were pathetic and terrible actors. And the worst thing about this movie is the fact that they made out the first Blair Witch movie to be just that .. a movie. I couldn't believe it .. if you are going to make a sequel, you could at least assume that the prequel was real. By openly acknowledging the original was a movie, it crapped on it, as audiences can no longer believe that Burkitsville Woods housed the Blair Witch, therefore audiences can not believe that the students are threatened with any imminent danger. Rub my chin, this movie has absolutely nothing going for it. This sequel should never have happened

reviews.review_title: Slick production values doesn't make this an scary movie but nonetheless it's entertaining.
reviews.content: After the major unexpected blockbuster success of the independent feature "The Blair Witch Project". Which that film fooled many audiences and film critics thinking it was an true-life documentary. Which the town of Burkittsville, Maryland is filled with die-hard fans of the movie. Which the town's people are not happy about it. Now five die-hard fans of the movie:Kim (Kim Director), Jeffery (Jeffery Donovan), Erica (Erica Leerhsen), Tristine (Tristine Skyler) and Stephen (Stephen Baker Turner) are visiting the woods. Where the original film is set-up but after an night of partying and drinking too-heavily. The five strangers found their stuff destroyed and having no real memory of what they done that night. Slowly these five people find themselves seeing visions or ghostly presence that haunts them and there's nothing what it seems from these people or the things they experienced.Directed by documentary filmmaker:Joe Berlinger (Metallica:Some Kind of Monster, Paradise Lost) made an interesting although flawed and not very scary loose sequel of "The Blair Witch Project". Berlinger isn't very happy how Artisan (now Lions Gate Films) re-cut his version, which could have been much better. Which the Director explained in the entertaining audio commentary track. Die-Hard fans of the original were truly disappointed that "The Blair Witch Project" was only an movie and this one takes an different style of modern film-making. "Book of Shadows:Blair Witch 2" did make an small profit at the box office, it is probably completely forgotten now but the movie does have an small loyal of fans. Which some people will say "Book of Shadows:Blair Witch 2" is a minor cult film.DVD has an sharp anamorphic Widescreen (1.85:1) transfer and an good Dolby Digital 5.1 Surround Sound. DVD has an filmmaker commentary track, an selected scene commentary by music composer:Carter Burwell (Psycho 3, In Bruges, No Country for Old Men) and more. DVD also has CD Side with an few songs from the film and the entire soundtrack from the movie. Director Berlinger did really try to make this an scary movie with an few jabs at satire but it doesn't always work. The cast do give their 110 % (especially Donovan is terrific) but only Larry Flaherty as Sheriff Cravens gives an laughable amateurish performance that hurts the movie, when he is on-screen. Otherwise... that's one of the few minor flaws of "Book of Shadows:Blair Witch 2". I doubt, we will see Berlinger's true director's cut one day but it is certainly an underrated film with some occasional cleverness. Worth a look. (****/*****).

*Blair Witch* was a very good idea that they didn't quite pull off.*Blair Witch 2* is just another crappy movie, and giving the characters gimmicky names to correspond with the names of the "actors" doesn't make it any better. In a sane world, it would have gone direct to video, or better still, gone unreleased.No one of any sensibility could enjoy this, save perhaps on a *Plan 9* level.

reviews.review_title: Did You BW2 Supporters See The Same Movie I Did?!
reviews.content:
If so, I have just one question...What mind-altering drug were you all under the influence of when you were watching this cinematic piece of trash? Okay, I admit that was a cheap shot, but you deserved it. Now, if you liked this movie(though I can't imagine why you would), that's one thing, but deducing that those of us who didn't care for it are just unintelligent and there's no way possible that such a "thought provoking" and "imaginative" film wouldn't be able to register in our feeble little brains... well, that is the straw that broke the camel's back! Where do you get off?!I read so many comments saying, "Don't compare this to the first Blair Witch!" Why not?! In case you haven't noticed, if it wasn't for the first Blair Witch, there would BE no BW2. There is going to be some kind of comparison to the first one whether it's intentional or not, so just get over it.As for my review of the 'film', first of all, I DID see what the filmmakers were trying to accomplish and I thought it was a very bold attempt on their part, BUT we have to face facts here. The execution of it was absolutely HORRIBLE and ended up with very disasterous results! A film with no visible plot, loose ends that never got tied up(could someone please tell me the significance of showing Jeff in the mental hospital if it didn't help to push the plot along), no concept of foreshadowing, unnecessary use of gore and nudity, characters I couldn't sympathize with in the least, and the worst acting I've ever seen! The scenes that needed to be shorter, dragged on for miles and the scenes that needed more meat on their bones, ended abruptly before we could get any useful information from them. The movie left me with so many unanswered questions it's not even funny!
I'm all for innovative filmmaking, but for me to call BW2 that, it would have to had accomplished what it originally set out to do and unfortunately, it didn't.

Okay, I have to make a confession here.  I actually quite liked this film. 
The story revolves around a group of young fans of the original "Blair Witch Project" film who go to the woods where the events in the film occurred and experience increasingly strange events.The film starts off well, but by the end the plot becomes far too confusing and convoluted.  In his first fiction film, documentary film-maker Joe Berlinger directs with a heavy hand and far too much unnecessary tricks.The actors are passable.  Erica Leerhsen makes the most impact as a witch, being not only very attractive but also showing some genuine talent.One of the worst things about the film is the incessant loud goth-rock music.  I personally don't like that style of music much, but in this film it is so incessant and so loud, it's really aggravating.The film was supposedly heavily altered by the studio against Berlinger's wishes, so perhaps he can't really be blamed entirely for the film's flaws.It's still fun, though, and with a second viewing you can pick up on many subtle concepts that are hidden throughout the film.

"Blair Witch" was one of the most over-hyped films of 1999--also, it was stupid, boring and very unscary. The sequel isn't really a sequel. It mentions the first movie as a work of fiction, has it's cast of 20 somethings spend a night in the woods and they all black out for 5 hours. Then bodies start piling up, the tapes reveal something very scary and the kids realize they've "bought something back with them". There's more to it than that, but I don't want to give away the ending. The acting was pretty good (except for Donovan--God, was he annoying!) and I was interested throughout. It's not that scary, but neither was the first one. So, all in all, a pretty good follow-up to the first film. Be warned though--if you liked the first film, you'll probably hate this and vice versa.

Book of Shadows: Blair Witch 2 (2000) ** (out of 4) Disappointing sequel to THE BLAIR WITCH PROJECT has four strangers meeting a native of Burkittsville and deciding to go on a tour where the first movie was filmed. Soon after wards three of them are being questioned by the police about eight murders but none of the three seem to remember what happened. Their video footage of all the events are going to tell the entire story. It's well known that the directors of the original film weren't ready for a sequel so the studio pretty much just did one on their own and the end results are mixed to say the least. I don't think this is a good movie and in fact I'd call it a very frustrating one but at the same time I somewhat give the studio credit for trying something at least a little different and not just a rehash on the original film. The thing that was so frustrating is that the movie is on the brink of becoming interesting so you keep watching it but nothing special ever happens. Something might happen to wake you up or make you pay a little closer attention but then you're just letdown by something else that either doesn't work or something that's simply annoying. One thing that doesn't help is that all five characters are rather annoying. I thought the actors all did a good job with their roles but the screenplay has them fighting way too much to the point where you'd wish they'd all just shut up and go away. This certainly isn't a good thing when you're suppose to care for these people and want them to survive what they're going through. The non-stop fighting just wore my patience thin and after a while I really gave up on the characters and couldn't care what happened to any of them. Another major problem is that the film itself really doesn't seem to know what type of story it's trying to tell. The director has stated that the studio took the film over and edited it behind his back and I'd believe this because the entire thing is rather confusing. There's a big twist ending but I must admit that it wasn't nearly as shocking or horrific as it was trying to be. I wouldn't say the director was without blame though as some of the heavy metal music didn't work at all and the quick edits of violence was also rather bland. The screenplay also makes the mistake of having the characters sitting around watching the video of the events that happened in the woods and none of this is very interesting either. Once again, each time something decent does happen they follow it up with something bland. Now, the most disappointing thing about BOOK OF SHADOWS: BLACK WITCH 2 is the fact that it's simply not scary. There isn't one tense moment to be found here and that's a real shame considering how powerful the original movie was. In the end this sequel just comes off as irritating because you go into it hoping for something special but it just never happens.

reviews.review_title: Blair Witch 2: Can't Fool Us Twice
reviews.content: Last year's Blair Witch Project was a smashing success, earnings-wise.  But that success was built almost entirely on hype, which managed to hoodwink most moviegoers into seeing an irritating, unscary, and weak film.  The movie had some of the lowest exit polls recorded, and with good reason. Expect the same from the latest (and hopefully last) installment, Book of Shadows.I wouldn't have seen this movie if someone else hadn't paid, which tells you what I thought of the original.  This time, the plot is weak, the acting tired, and the reliance of reputation of its predecessor to enthrall audiences is not only shameful but pathetic.  In fact, the scariest thing about this flick is that someone thought people cared enough for the first one to support an entire series of films.  The fact that the producers began spewing out computer games, nooks, sequels and other gimmicky marketing ploys shows you what the real force behind these movies is... and it's not making good film.  It's all about cashing in while the getting's good.A disappointing opening weekend for this movie could spell doom for any sequels (one hopes).  But who's really surprised here?  The producers?  The studio?  That's what they get for listening to their own self-created hype. Let's hope they bury this tired corpse soon.

Director Joe Berlinger is better than this, and terrific films like "Brother's Keeper" prove it.  What happened here?  Maybe he was reaching to a younger audience than his documentaries might attract and, not trusting his judgment, made compromises.  (I notice he has a writing credit, too.) Maybe his ideas were watered down in re-write.  Or maybe there was studio pressure.  Regardless, "Book of Shadows" is a shambles, either as a stand-alone or as a follow-up to the inventive original. (The original, by the way, scored its success in part because it didn't pander;  "Book of Shadows" is nothing if not pandering, from its Goth chick to its "Deliverance"-like treatment of the locals to the death rock on the soundtrack.  The subtext of this multi-million dollar production is that it understands those on society's fringe and those who imagine themselves to be on the fringe, and that it sympathizes;  really, though, it just wants their money.)  So much is wrong here that I don't think there's any reason to go into it. Is there?  One thing, though:  the actor portraying Sherriff Cravens (I can't find his name here) gives the worst performance I've seen in a major film in a long, long time.  It's too awful to blame the actor entirely, and I think it's symptomatic of everything that's wrong with "Book of Shadows": What script calls for this?  And where was Berlinger?

You know every time I talk to people about this movie I'm amazed to know that people actually did not even know this was a thing, for some good reasons honestly.
This movie is kinda forgetful, the story isn't really in line with the original and in general the tone is just completely different.
But does that make it a really bad movie? Not really not in my standards. The movie has this "So cheesy it's fun" vibe to it, whenever I find myself remembering that this in fact does exist I always remember the antics of the gang in this movie, and how so incredibly cheesy it is. The stupid twists and turns that the movie tosses at you, and the ending? Don't even get me started.
The movie ends up being almost a joke as it strings you along a fairly uninteresting plot of a group of tourists who think they're possessed by the blair witch. But all the various character's stereotypes end up being the reason why I come back to it, from the 'I totally know more than I should know' goth chick, the skeptical of the occult writer, the wiccan chick, the 'Oh I only do this for the money' tour leader.
In short Blair Witch 2 is worth a pass over but don't expect something wow woah, go into it expecting some really cheesy kinda not that great plot, and laugh as events unfold before you.

reviews.review_title: I tried hard to like this movie...
reviews.content:
...and I somewhat succeeded.  Why, you ask, did I want to try to like this movie?  Well, I rented it on video, hated it and then decided to buy it on DVD, granted the price was 5.99.  Just so people know, the DVD is a DVD and CD combined.  I felt even if my thoughts of the movie remained the same, at least I'll get the cool soundtrack.  And it was only 5.99.  So I didn't have much to lose.  I liked the movie a lot more the second time around, though I'd still rate it as OK.  The film has an intriguing premise that keeps the audience guessing.  That's the good part.  The bad part, you ask?  The premise doesn't pay off, and we're led to a third act that's mostly populated by pretentious gibberish.  The acting is decent, except for the old guy who plays the sheriff.  That goth chick and the redhead are both really hot!  There are cool horror images.  I hated the original "Blair Witch" with a passion, so this is a masterpiece compared to that overblown dud of a motion picture.  This one didn't scare me either, but it intrigued and amused me.  Not a film worthy of rushing to the video store, but a fairly good one nonetheless.   
My score:  6 (out of 10)

reviews.review_title: Mind Bogglingly Insane (not in a fun or scary way)
reviews.content: Many people have a debate weather or not the Blair Witch Project was a masterpiece, but regardless of what people thoughts was on the first film, Book of Shadows: Blair Witch 2 is were everyone can agree it's horrible.A group of five exploring members goes into the same location of were the first film took place to document the supernatural as they believe the Blair Witch Project holds something true in real life.There's a lot of problems that is going on into the movie. a side with the other problems the film has like laughable characters, bizarre editing, ridiculous visuals, the biggest problem with the movie is that the uncountable amount of story goes nowhere and not one of them are explain.Not only is it amazing that film doesn't follow any continuity of the first film, but if it was a stand alone film, it would never holds up.

Don't get me wrong... I had my apprehensions on seeing it.  I knew it was going to be bad.  Everyone did.  But, I honestly don't think so now.  It wasn't all THAT good, but it didn't all out suck either.  It had it's ups and downs.  I recommend seeing it, maybe buy it... more than likely, rent it.

reviews.review_title: Suspenseful, pretty scary, but relies on shock value.
reviews.content: Here's the setting: it's a day before the movie starts, and I'm calling up a few friends to see this movie, and I'm really excited to see the long-awaited (for me, anyways) sequel to the cult phenomenon "The Blair Witch Project". Well, it's the day of the movie, and I'm reading reviews that absolutely tear this movie apart because of it's crappiness.  But hey, it's a sequel, how bad can it be?Well, overall, the movie was pretty suspenseful.  I enjoyed Dick Beebe's writing in "House on Haunted Hill", which was a good horror film, as well, so that kind of raised the standards for me, here.  Also, the editing job on this movie is quite superior, in contrast to a review I read somewhere. The editing jumps back from before and after this whole incident occurs, and really keeps you wondering. I liked the storyline, as well. It kept you into the movie throughout it's whole run. But, as someone mentioned on these reviews, it definitely relies on shock value. BW2, for the general teen audience that will see this film, is a pretty twisted, graphic and disturbing film, which is probably what director Joe Berlinger's target was. It really doesn't bother me as much, because I think it made the movie better...to a certain point. The gore kind of got...well...boring for me after a while. The weak stomach may have trouble watching this movie, but folks like me may get tired of seeing it. But the good side of this movie that it had some suspense sprinkled throughout, especially when they start contemplating about the strange events they had during their stay in the woods and they are viewing their videotapes. Also, it does come to a pretty amazing climax.  Getting off the track a little, it does have an awesome soundtrack, too.All in all, the sequel holds true to the legend, but don't expect it to be much like the first movie, which truly scared the hell out of me because of it's play on the mind. In this film, it plays with the mind, but also heavily (and at times redundantly) plays on the eyes. 7/10P.S. I will definitely keep my eyes peeled for Blair Witch 3 next year, as well.

Its not perfect but it is very weird and has that claustrophobic feeling to it, well acted too and quite original, nothing at all like the first film but its actually an alright film. Its far from amazing but far from bad too.

reviews.review_title: Better than the prequel but still aweful
reviews.content: This movie is better than Blair Witch 1 but I still gave it a 1 when I voted for it. That says a lot about what I thought of the prequel. Anyways, the acting couldn't have been worse, neither could the story or the screenplay. A bad story with bad lines and bad actors should be able to make a pretty worthless movie and it did. I read that they're making a third movie on this concept, and I don't know why they even bother. They would probably even make more money if they'd come up with something new. They would definatly make a better movie, because it doesnt get much worse than this, oh yeah, Blair Witch 1 was actually worse.

reviews.review_title: the worst film I've ever seen
reviews.content: The blair witch project. A clever and effective piece of low budget cinema,which was not only critically acclaimed,but also a huge box office phenomenon to boot. But you'd think that maybe just maybe for once that a golden rule would be broken in hollywood and the men in suits at artisan would decide to quit while they were on top and not bother with a sequel to an already exceptional film. So bad is this celluloid abomination,that I was amazed that I was watching this in a cinema. Made on a budget of $10 million(still low by mainstream standards)It feels like a straight to video cheepie that will sit on the bottom shelf at video shops the world over. After all unlike the original's low production value's which contributed to the success of the first film,this was made to appeal to the idiot's who were bemused by the lack of special effects and conventional photography,well they're going the wrong way about it with this amatuer effort. The acting,direction and scripting is more rank than the navy. When I saw this on opening night,the audience sniggered with laughter throughout. There should be a law against putting films out in cinema like this one and insulting undeserving punters by conning them of £5.00. And apparently they are planing on making a second follow up,In what looks like another cheap,tacky and abismal horror franchise that no one want's. Please artisan dont bother the world's not interested.

reviews.review_title: Someone forgot to include a story
reviews.content: I watched this movie hoping it would be a sequel to the original movie, but found out that it was just Blair Witch ->2<-. No further investigation into the witch, just a couple of new teenagers...I think the movie was lousy, to say it all in one word. There is no tension building up through the movie, it's more like unexpected short cuts that make you jump a little, and that's a very cheap way to scare people. Like in most other horror movies, a lot of things happens without explanation. But if there never is an explanation it's not frightening, it's just frustrating. A horror movie should build up tension and in the end you get to know. Like in "The Ring", and watching BW2 was like waiting for the girl to come out of the TV, but she never did. The whole movie through, it feels like something is missing. Part from the tension, it's a story. I also got the feeling that the creators thought that nudity and sex would be just as good as a story. Several times the nudity feels very unnecessary with the actors walking around naked for, as it seems, no particular reason. Probably just a way to make the movie interesting in some way ;).The plot didn't make much sense to me and the end didn't make any sense at all. I can see that it's all the work of the Blair Witch but you never really get to know that in a good way, and I guess that's supposed to be the scary part but judging from the many low grades given to the movie, many people think like me - it isn't! You maybe don't want all the facts handed to you but there can't be too much left to you own imagination either.

Not to spoil anything, but it was a fun movie with interesting twists and turns in the spirit of the first movie. Do not expect a remake of part one-that would be a silly thing to do anyway. This one expands the whole mystery/myth and keeps you guessing and wondering. Fun to talk about afterwards like the first one. Personally I did not think the first was all that spectacular though the basic story concept was very clever. I think the critics usually miss the boat with horror films. The acting is decent and did the job for me, but the important thing is it is supposed to be fun, mysterious, and entertaining. It was. At least it isn't a predictable formula horror movie like most. So sit back and just understand that you are not supposed to understand everything. That is what makes it good-you need to use some imagination to fill in some blanks. Enjoy!

"Blair Witch 2" gave me a realistic way to look at both the movies.  It magicly twisted my brain around into creative knots.  The characters gave many different perspectives on an issue that is present today, even in our government  The sound track paralleled the scenes.  I thought it was fascinating.  To me, it's a modern spiritual art-field.

reviews.review_title: underrated , unappreciated mind-bending . very eerie, unsettling and totally weird .
reviews.content: Book of Shadows" begins with not so much a recap of the events of the original, but an overview of the hysteria caused by a film called "The Blair Witch Project". It acknowledges the original as a work of fiction (a la "Wes Craven's New Nightmare") as evening news shows report about the fans overrunning the real-life small town of Burkittsville, Maryland.Hey, sequels aren't easy. The movie, directed and co-written by Joe Berlinger, isn't a lazy retread of The Blair Witch Project (1999) but a fractured and semi-satirical meditation on it. Berlinger takes as his subject the box office phenomenon of the first film, and then goes on, with both fervor and an amazing lack of genre savvy, to raise solemn issues about the role of media in messing with people's heads and inducing them to commit acts of violence. Is the Blair Witch herself driving the movie's young, impressionable protagonists to murder, or have they simply watched too many horror pictures? Berlinger knew a straight redux of the found footage gimmick of the first film wouldn't have worked, so he didn't even try. He then looked at what were the key elements of the original and what he might be able to do with them. One detail he carried through was the cast of total unknowns acting under their real names. Another detail is the significance of the website to the enjoyment of the experience. This time out, you really need to go the official site for much of characters' histories and for any mention or description of what a "Book of Shadows" actually is. The best idea Berlinger had was to take the idea of the audience using the "lost" footage to discover what had happened to the campers, and this time have the campers try to find what had happened to themselves.Book of Shadows is spicier than the first; the actors are more developed, interesting, and additionally more appealing to look at. Of course the latter lacks relevance to the movie as a whole, but it's especially a bonus compared to the first. Anyhow, the array and diversity of the characters is also something new that was not in the original. This finds itself with a story that is insofar only connected by the name, while the screenplay widely acknowledges the previous movie as just a movie. Here, there is actually an element of creepiness. One of the best offerings Book of Shadows had was the element of manipulation. It combined the mental state of delusion and group hysteria along with video manipulation. It's as cataleptic as the first, but in more of a satisfying way.with Joe Berlinger as writer/director. He retains the spirit of the prototype, while going dangerously deep into the concept of "perception is reality". What happens to these people is scary, because they don't know what to believe. They learn not to trust their eyesight. Flashbacks and flash forwards crash their consciousness. Dreams become as vivid as woken fear.In the end the cameras hold the secret of what is and what is not true. Compared to a special effects gross-out, like The Hostel franchise, this has an edge.The script is acerbic and funny, the characters not without interest. Kim snaps at Jeff: "You're a long way from sane". Perhaps that's right. The loony is still off his head. The sheriff certainly believes so. And yet, despite obvious paranoia, Jeff seems to understand how far beyond a joke the situation has reached. Steve calls it "collective delusion". There is another word. Terror.Where the original was a faux-documentary, this one sells itself as a re-enactment. That aspect is treated with wit and intelligence.Erica Leerhson and Kim Director are intriguing to watch. Tristen Skyler is only transitorily their equivalent.Jeffrey Donovan is very out there and gives a fun performance,at his audition, a camera was put on Jeffery Donovan and he was asked what he thought of the original Blair Witch Project. His answer: "I think it sucks". He still got the part.Stephen barker Turner puts a lot of emotion in his performance and looks very familiar The acting is overall solid.It is to their credit that the filmmaker and screenwriters tried to offer something different and original. Blair Witch 2 follows its own rules but I'm not sure everybody will dig the game it's playing. I have a feeling that many people will hate this sequel but that with time the masses will learn to appreciate it for what it is: A different, ballsy, unorthodox film. Bring on Part 3.

Wow what a big waste of film. I did not pay for the ticket and I still wanted to get money back after seeing this! If you only see 5000 films this year try not to waste your time on this. Smash your head on the wall I found it much better!

You know, I hate the first Blair Witch Project movie so I was assured that I'd despise this, a movie that utterly bombed at the box office and seemed to make no one happy. But you know, it totally worked. Sequels are hard to make. Joe Berlinger and Dick Beebe wanted to make this as a psychological thriller and meditation on mass hysteria - it's also about how one town can become a place that it only was on film - and create a movie that was the direct opposite of the first film.Book of Shadows is closer to the Hollywood movies that the original went so hard away from. Berlinger originally made the film with an ambiguous tone that didn't give away exactly what happened when the characters stayed overnight in the Black Hills. Artisan wanted a more commerical film, so they had him recut and reshoot this to make it more commercial. That footage was shot weeks from the release in a time when movies had to have prints made, not like how they could just upload the movie to theaters.The interrogation that is spread throughout the movie was originally an eight-minute end of the story, but the studio also asked them to be spliced through the story. The filmmakers wanted a story that went from a lighthearted romp to suddenly getting violent and dark. They also added in Marilyn Manson's "Disposable Teens," which replaced Frank Sinatra's "Witchcraft."Actually, I said this was a bomb earlier and it made $47 million on a $15 million budget. For any other movie, that'd be a success. But it didn't equal what the first movie did. Honestly, that was impossible.Tourists are filling up the small town of Burkittsville, Maryland, hoping to be part of the same occult scares that they saw in The Blair Witch Project. Jeff (Jeffrey Donovan) is obsessed with the movie and takes a group on a tour. They include Stephen (Stephen Barker Turner) and his pregnant girlfriend Tristen (Tristine Skyler), Wiccan Erica (Erica Leerhsen) and goth Kim (Kim Director). They camp in a cabin in the woods and hope to see something. Jeff already notices a tree in the middle of the house that was never there in his memory.After doing drugs, everyone wakes up to Tristen losing her baby. It gets worse - they've all been marked for death, their research destroyed and the world itself turning on them. When they play the. Tapes they find under the house backward, they see themselves taking part in a demonic ritual orgy and murdering other tourists. The video footage the police show them is even more damning, putting the statement that Jeff makes earlier, "Film lies but video always tells the truth" to the worst test.Berlinger has mostly made true crime movies in his career, like the Paradise Lost Trilogy, in which he told the story of others who had been blamed for their occult murders, the West Memphis Three. He tried to make a horror movie while also creating a film that took audiences to task for believing everything shot on video to be true. People just wanted more of the same.I know it's pretty on the nose, but I love that this ended with Poe's "Haunted."

reviews.review_title: Horrendously bad sequel to the original
reviews.content: This movie absolutely makes no sense.  We see most of the movie through the eyes of the five characters, but later find that none what we saw is true. Rather the blair witch had blindfolded us and the protagonists.  The last 10 minutes are absurd.  As well 90% of the movie is set in an abandoned wharehouse.The forest was much creepier  You know the original blair witch is still a good concept film, which would be beter appreciated today if had not made a lot of money.  Watch the original, in the dark on a stormy night and dont waste 90 minutes of your life on this piece of trash.

The Blair Witch Project was a brilliant supernatural horror film to successfully use the video footage look and present it as found footage to create a big hype, and this a sequel with hardly any relation. Basically it focuses on four Boston college students, researchers Jeffrey Patterson (Jeffrey Donovan) and Tristen Ryler (Tristine Skyler), witch craft enthusiast Erica Geerson (Erica Leerhsen) and psychic goth Kim Diamond (Kim Director). They are fascinated by the events portrayed in the Blair Witch movie, and there are those who think it was fake, but they are obviously of those that speculate whether there is in fact a witch in Burkittsville, Maryland. So the four students decide to go to the woods where the three students of the Blair Witch movie disappeared, hoping to capture some evidence themselves. After filming themselves sleeping through the night in the site the video footage was found, Rustin Parr's house, and experiencing a little disturbance, they return to town to Jeff's house. There they look through all the footage they captured, and see that it is a little all over the place with timing, and they see themselves doing stuff that they would never remember. Also, through seeing all this we see the students being interviewed by the police about a murder, obviously by the end we see who they are referring to, Tristen being hung. Also starring Stephen Barker Turner as Stephen Ryan Parker, Kurt Loder as MTV newscaster and Chuck Scarborough as Newcaster. The first film was a phenomenal film for making you scared without actually seeing anything, and also the improvising of actions and dialogue made it more realistic. This sequel is the complete opposite, it looks like any regular film with teen pop music, predictable characters, dialogue and events, and it just feels pointless, a stupid film that won't scare or surprise you in any way. It won the Razzie for Worst Remake or Sequel, and it was nominated for Worst Director for Joe Berlinger, Worst Picture, Worst Screen Couple for Any two actors in the movie and Worst Screenplay. Poor!

When "The Blair Witch Project" became the sleeper hit of 1999, a sequel became inevitable. Despite being adsorbed widely through pop culture via parodies and rip-offs, sequelizing "The Blair Witch Project" was a tricky proposition. Found footage sequels are common today but the style was rare at the turn of the millennium. More importantly, the original film was self-contained and didn't leave much opportunity for a follow-up. Commerce would not be denied. Ignoring all these problems, "Book of Shadows: Blair Witch 2" was quickly thrown together and released a year after the original.The film starts with an interesting hook. Instead of directly following the original's conclusive ending, "Blair Witch 2" takes the meta approach. The film is set in "our" world, were "The Blair Witch Project" wasn't a true story but only a wildly successful movie. Thus the film dismisses the found footage angle entirely, progressing as a typical, third-person movie. The story at first focuses on how the real town of Burkittsville was affected by the sudden rush of attention following the movie. During this time, a number of businesses popped up, taking curious tourists on tours through the woods. Among these groups is Jeff Patterson, who makes decent money selling stick-men and genuine Burkittsville dirt over the internet. His freshman tour group, composed of himself, goth girl Kim, would-be wiccan Erica, and married couple Stephen and Tristen, quickly begin to experience strange things in the woods and in the broom factory Jeff calls home.Though the premise isn't without promise, "Book of Shadows" squanders any interest the set-up could deliver. First off, this movie stinks of the year 2000. From the obnoxious nu-metal soundtrack, to the fashion and style, this movie reeks of the turn-of-the-century. Compared to the striped-down, stark style of the original, "Book of Shadows" is a glossy studio product, as crass a cash-in that has ever existed.The movie is also exceptionally stupid. The film indulges in so many late-nineties horror clichés that it almost feels like a parody. The film is inconsistently told in flashback, cutting haphazardly between the past and the future. All this does is drain away any suspense, since it tells us which characters survive. Upon entering the woods and coming to the ruins of an old building, the tour group immediately indulges in drugs. They drink, smoke pot, and even whip a crack pipe out. Despite one of them being a pregnant woman. As divergent as the characters' backgrounds are, they all get wasted. They wake up in the morning, hung over, their camp site wrecked. Most of the rest of the film is devoted to them snipping at each other in the broom factory, nightmare sequences that may or may not be real, and occasionally the characters trying to solve a mystery. Not the mystery of whether real black magic is happening here. The mystery of what happened to their video cameras.There's a lot wrong with "Blair Witch 2" but the biggest problem is its shotgun editing. Throughout the film, scenes will cut away to incoherent footage of people being stabbed and killed. The characters are haunted by incoherent visions. Stephen and Tristen dream about having sex, which turns into them slashing each other with their nails. Everyone sees visions of a backwards walking ghost girl. At one point, Kim sees Jeff in an electric chair, his body sparking and twitching. There are visions of ghost kids, barking dogs, and bloody murder. These fantasy scenes are cut into the film in a spastic manner. So much so that they are frequently funny, like when one of the characters starts chewing on a dead owl. What level of realty this takes place on isn't elaborated on. Which is confusing, especially once a falling bridge comes into the picture.The movie's terrible construction isn't help but it's awful characters. Jeffrey Donovan would, years later, find fame on TV series "Burn Notice." I bet he doesn't put this movie on his resume. His character is obnoxious and the performance is pitched at an embarrassingly ham-fisted level. Erica Leerhsen is far too earnest as the wiccan. She's the kind of girl you'd meet in college who wouldn't stop harping on one or two topics, even if no one else was interested. You hate people like that. Stephen Barker Turner is hassled with a deeply unlikable character while Tristine Skyler, as his wife, spends most of the movie lying sick in bed. Kim Director comes the closest to likable as the goth girl but even she is forced to do incredibly stupid things by the senseless screenplay. An exchange in a local grocery store is especially embarrassing.The direction is awful, the characters are annoying, but the script is the biggest problem. The supernatural events that happen are never connected in any meaningful way. Weird stuff goes on for seemingly no reason. Plot points are raised and dropped. Jeff's time in a mental hospital, Kim's supposed psychic powers, or Tristen's miscarriage come up but have no meaningful affect on the story. An especially ridiculous plot turn involves playing a tape backwards. The film reaches for a level of ambiguity it in no way earns. Few answers are provided for the sake of "preserving the mystery." Is the Blair Witch real? Is she responsible for what happens? How does this connect to the first film? All this really means is that, upon any scrutiny, the film stops making sense completely. For a clue of the film's intense inanity, look no further then its meaningless sub-title. No books containing shadows are seen during the 87 minute run time.The movie was so bad that even a public with Blair Witch fever rejected it. It more then doubled its tiny budget but the response was so negative that no further sequels were made. "Book of Shadows: Blair Witch 2" was rightfully dismissed as the crass cash-in it was.

reviews.review_title: The worst movie I have ever sat through.
reviews.content: OK, so I didn't walk out.  I kept thinking it had to get better or would start making sense, or some plot detail would explain why the acting was so stilted.  And then it was over.  The movie seemed to me to be incomprehensible garbage.

reviews.review_title: It would of been better by itself
reviews.content: I loved the blair witch project and would have much rather they make a sequel that continued with the original story then made a sequel like this.I liked this movie but it would have been a lot better had it been by itself and not part of the Blair Witch Project original movie. The plot was a bit hard to follow but I managed.It was almost nothing like the original but I found it scary and a reasonable movie.

reviews.review_title: Beware of what you don't see in the woods.
reviews.content: I don't know if this is really a sequel to BLAIR WITCH PROJECT(1999)or not...the story line is not really continued as such. What we have is five college students that go into the woods near Burkittsville to investigate the disappearance of the original film crew. The cinematography is not as rough, raw and jerky as the first. There is actually some pretty good F/X. A jumbled story line and the mix of the five characters makes for some nerve wrecking. My favorite scene is actually when they watch the playback of the episode of missing time the group cannot remember. This did make the hair on the back of my neck rise. Creepy! Nudity and foul language seems mandatory for realism. Besides the appearance of MTV's Kurt Loder the cast is pretty lame. But of note is Erica Leerhsen who can grab your attention with or without clothes on. The actual musical score is haunting and meandering. The soundtrack hits pretty hard with music for the likes of Godhead, Rob Zombie, Slaves On Dope and probably most impressive is P.O.D. This is not the worst...but a movie away from being the best.

This shameless cash grab tries to ride the success of the box office smash indie film but utterly fails. This campy horror film is difficult to watch. The movie does nothing to scare or create any tension that was ever present in the first film. The creators thought they could throw whatever on the screen and capitalize on the past success but all this movie does is make a shameful movie that everyone involved most likely wanted to forget as soon as it was released.Book of Shadows has nothing to do with any book that I could recall though I stopped paying close attention before the first hour was over.
