The movie stresses that this movie is involved with the first one with news story praising the success of the first film. The setting is the same Maryland woods as the characters are fanatics of the real film. The group goes out there and experiences the same phenomenon. It is a wonder that the first film could make this local so haunting and the second feels like a spoof film canceling out all the dread that was steadily built. Nothing scary happens at all during the initial scenes.Check out more of this review and others at swilliky.com

reviews.review_title: and the book of shadows is...?
reviews.content: This movie could have benefited from never being made.  In theory, it was probably a great idea.  Take a look at the phenomenom spawned by the Blair Witch Project- a recent cinematic feat that's been mirror and mimicked by plenty since (even I've made a bloody blair witch spoof), cast the director of Paradise Lost- guys who've researched mysterious child murders with possible occult tie-ins, and let the dollars come rushing in. Unfortunately, this film is a mess.  It was a tricky idea to pull off, and it looks like they really rushed their way through what could have been a carefully constructed study on media exploitation of cultural phenomena, psychosis, and faulty camera equiptment.the movie is just generally uneven.  The commencement focuses on the Blair Witch hysteria and how its plagued the small town in witch its based, carefully never hinting as to whether the movie was ficitional or not.  The characters in the movie live in a sublet of our culture wherein the phenomenon caught on, but the three actors didn't go on talk shows and get numerous interviews. "We know it's real" they exclaim.  Blair-Witch Hunt crews explore the woods and exploit people's wallets.  It's a biting satire of the the capitalizisation that inadvertently comes with every trend. This segment of the movie is designed with cheesy one-liners and a generally light-fared plotline.   The movie then attempts to take itself seriously and falls flat on its nose, cracking that nose causing a surge of  blood and gore to gush out ruining what could have been a delightfully beautiful face. Speaking of which, there's relatively no gore in this movie- which is a plus- but the more explicit scenes come in flashes of projected Blair Witch induced slayings- which may or may not be the ones that legend has said took place in the woods.the acting is subpar. the terror is absent.  and it's not because barely anyone dies or because nothing jumps out of each corner, that was a wise part on behalf of the directors-who obviously took notes from the first movie.  It's just that nearly every attempts to turn frightening fail to inspire the sympathy for the characters that other movies, such as the first Blair Witch did.  They're each unique and i did appreciate some of the techniques used by the actors/actresses (esp. the uppity "i understand and you don't cos I'm a" wiccan character. that hit close to home) but the development is severely lacking.  On a positive note, the movie does leave you with a dilemma that the film never answers and you can debate with your friends afterwards- but it hardly inspires you to sit down and go through the process of watching it again.

reviews.review_title: Entertaining horror flick about a haunting witch that's been dead for over two centuries
reviews.content: Released in 2000 and directed by Joe Berlinger, "Book of Shadows: Blair Witch 2" begins amidst the hysteria of the found-footage of the first film. People from around the world curious about the Blair witch phenomenon overrun Burkittsville, Maryland, wherein an entrepreneurial dude named Jeff (Jeffrey Donovan) leads a 'Blair Witch Hunt' tour involving four clients, a Wiccan, a Goth girl and an academic couple. After camping at the ruins of the home of an executed murderous hermit (who was evidently possessed by the spirit of the witch in the 1940s) the group has a rude awakening when they can't remember what happened the night before. They go to Jeff's nearby pad—a curious factory-turned-house—to review the video tapes for answers and discover something horribly macabre.Atmospherically, "Book of Shadows" is quite effective as a haunting ghost/witch flick and the writing is actually smart—the entire play on hysteria, delusion & perception is quite clever. The screenplay was written by director Berlinger, who's best known for the great "Paradise Lost" trilogy of documentaries about the "West Memphis three," youthful outcasts accused of a hideous 1993 triple murder in Arkansas based on dubious evidence (and who were finally released in 2011). Anyway, "Book of Shadows" starts satirically and amusing, but gets increasing serious and sinister. The acting is good too, with Kim Director's powerhouse performance as the Goth girl standing out. Erica Leerhsen is also a highlight as the Wiccan babe with several alluring scenes, but they coulda done more with her.The reason so many people call this flick "the worst movie ever made" (Why sure!) is obviously because it's a knee-jerk reaction to it being a sequel to the mega-popular "The Blair Witch Project" (1999), which was an altogether different kind of movie, being a found-footage flick, not to mention the herd-mentality of an over-critical feeding-frenzy. Since I'm not a fan of found-footage films—seeing as how they're about as entertaining as watching home movies for an hour and a half—I find "Book of Shadows" far more interesting than the first film.There's a secret message in the movie that you can discover in (***SPOILER ALERT***): the FIRE, the GRASS, the factory WINDOW, the GRAVESTONE and the RUG, which all-together spells: "Seek me no further or...". This combined with reversing Tristen's backward words in the last act reveal the secret of 'ESREVER': "Seek me no further or... the children will again walk free," meaning: the Blair witch would loose the spirits of the murdered children to torment the invaders of her domain. (***END SPOILER***) As for the complaints of there being no Book of Shadows, it's simply not true. The character Jeff is a movie enthusiast with ambitions of being a filmmaker and "Book of Shadows" is the name of one of the scripts he put together and intends to shoot. So it's not something totally out of nowhere that Artisan dubiously added to the title, as most people think. Yes, they added it, but it had relevance to the movie. Furthermore, the actual 'Book of Shadows' is a Wiccan spell book and is figuratively used in the movie in that the group obviously falls under the spell of the Blair Witch after entering her diabolical terrain.The film features a creative score by Carter Burwell and a rockin' soundtrack with quality cuts by the likes of Marilyn Manson ("Disposable Teens"), Godhead ("The Reckoning") and many more.After Berlinger finished his version of the movie the studio complained that there weren't enough conventional horror elements and so additional scenes were shot & edited into the picture. What else is new? It has been thus throughout cinematic history. For me, the added scenes beef-up what might've otherwise been too low-key for a horror flick. True, this route was taken with the first film, but "Book of Shadows" is the antithesis of that movie, and it's the better for it IMHO."Book of Shadows" is a dense horror flick and therefore worthy of repeat viewings for gems to mine. (One aid in helping to understand the picture is Jeff's statement at the camp: "Film lies; video tells the truth"). Unfortunately, this is evidently too much for some dullards. Yes, it's a slow-build with meandering aspects, but the movie's laden with subtext and the climax is pretty horrific, even while it's somewhat predictable. You never see the witch, but her nefarious presence is palpable nevertheless and the ambiance fittingly oozes Gothic. As for the doofuses who argue that the pic has too little to do with the first one, nothing could be further from the truth. Lastly, Jeff's factory-turned-house is almost iconic; a great location for a ghostly horror flick.The film runs 90 minutes and was shot in Baltimore, Maryland.GRADE: B

Joe Berlinger directed this dreadful follow-up(rather than true sequel) to "The Blair Witch Project" that treats the first film as a film, and the hysteria that followed, plaguing the "real" residents of Burkitsville Maryland, though inspiring a former mental patient(played by Jeffrey Donovan) to lead a tour of the locations seen in the movie, and his first group seems to fall prey to the same "fictional?" forces portrayed in the movie. Is the Blair Witch real after all? Absolutely wrong-headed, idiotic, utterly ineffectual and pointless film with unappealing characters and none of the menace and dread seen in the first. Truly awful, with an infuriating ending making the entire picture moot! A genuine sequel to the first would still be a good idea.

Blair Witch Project didn't really scare me, but it was a very good movie. It had some vision that most films of its ilk severely lack, and was about as un-Hollywood as you can get. In part because of this, there was this buzz of uncertainty about it. When it came out, I was just starting high school, and there was a lot of gossip about how this actually was true.Blair Witch 2 completely betrayed that. And profoundly betrayed it.The actors were all pretty teens. The plot was nonsensical and nothing was actually resolved or revealed. What was advertised as an exploration of the Blair Witch legend didn't explore it at all, but just contrived new stuff, handed us archetypal characters that were impossible to care about, and attempted to draw it all back to videos, as if it somehow made the first movie more meaningful.What was truly ironic about all this was that the fact that this was bigger budget never actually came up. The first movie had no money, and so attempted to scare us with suggestion and inference. This movie HAD money, and tried to scare us overtly, but the best it could do was a pristine dead girl in a closet? STILL no actual sighting of the Blair Witch? But it's not all that surprising. Even on the video release of the first film, the downward spiral was becoming evident. The new footage was the three actors (on better quality tape) just sitting around and regurgitating stuff they had already said in the theatrical release. The creators had nothing to add, but added for the sake of it. Which is exactly what Book of Shadows is.

reviews.review_title: Both blair witches sucked, but this one was better
reviews.content: The sequel... what to say? I would say this was better than the first. But still kind of crappy. Why does it have an orgy? What was the point of that? I didn't really need to see a bunch of people acting like idiots. I didn't even want to see this movie, because the first one was bad. But my friends said that this one was better. And I am a horror fan. And I have to say, I am so disappointed in my generation. So, to top the movie off, rent it before you buy.4/10

Much like the title, Book of Shadows: Blair Witch 2, this movie does everything backwards. Instead of being a thrilling and horrifying found footage movie, like its predecessor, this sequel is more like student-made pseudo-intellectual fan fiction. It's wandered so far off the path of where the first film was, that it becomes almost unrecognizable as part of the original story. This horror flick tries to be so deep in all of its references and editing and cinematography, but it all comes off as pretentious and gratuitous. Book of Shadows was a waste of my time and a sequel I hope to soon forget.

reviews.review_title: I can't believe I put off seeing this...
reviews.content: Ok, putting the fact that this story is entirely fiction & the plot is kinda messed up in the eyes of those who believe nothing like this could ever happen, Blair Witch 2 (Book of Shadows) is surprisingly well. I honestly don't know why everyone said it was bad, because the camera is still for once, and the cast is very talented. I think Book of Shadows is just a freaky and scary as the 1st film. I even put off seing this, because everyone said it was VERY bad. Well, I liked it. I bought it previewed at Blockbuster & it is very good actually. I'll admit that I couldn't watch it over and over, but every couple of months or so, yeah, sure, I'd enjoy this film. It's pretty freaky & it's not very pretty either. Very gory & disturbing, but it's a good movie. I'd give it 3 out of 5 stars. Check it out if u haven't. It's really not that bad.

reviews.review_title: What the hell is wrong with some people!
reviews.content: Book of shadows Blair witch 2 is about NO NO NO I'm not even going to say the plot because this film is terrible. Blair witch 2 insulted this franchise completely with its horrible plot and bad acting. The film was only this is the only good point by the way,it gave a interesting tale but it was so bad,the movies end when the three survivors did not kill the victims and the witch made it look like they did it,that was one of the worst endings I have ever seen in cinematic history..ugh this film annoyed me off completely,I hated this film and that's all I have to say. If you did not like the first movie don't watch this horrible film. Over the 2000 years,the Blair witch project get very successful it was released into 3 video games and then in 2009,the Blair witch project 3 was announced and was put on IMDb. Then no news was released and the movie was probably not going to be released UNTIL Adam Wingard,director of a segment in V/H/S and the guest announced the woods,a horror film for September 2016 that was under a fake title and it was really..'BLAIR WITCH 3'DUN DUN DUN,the movie was released in theaters and was about Heather's brother who tries to find her with a bunch of friends but stumbles into the Blair witch's hood and ya they..they die. The movie was said to be as scary as the first film and when I watched it..ya it was just not my thing,it had a good plot but it was no where as real and scary as the first film.

reviews.review_title: You MUST watch this film with the director's commentary ON!
reviews.content: First director Joe Berlinger admits to an absolute loathing of the original Blair Witch Project ... and then goes on to reveal his own character faults with such a stunning lack of self-awareness that you'll probably find yourself screaming in incredulity at his disembodied voice. I have never before been so unintentionally entertained by anything else in my entire life. Do not, however, bother subjecting yourself to this stool specimen of a flick in its unadulterated form. Every ounce of hatred Berlinger harbors for his film's predecessor manifests itself in his story line's slimy proto-teen characters. In short, I wouldn't whiz on these kids if it was the only means of saving them from their self-induced flamings. There's more heart in a pop-top can of sandwich spread than in this soulless, spineless little spin off.

I just got back from the theater tonight from seeing this film. The theater wasn't even filled up. That was not a good sign. After the movie was over, I can see why. This movie is so awful that Seseme Street Presents Follow that Bird was scarier than this movie. What made the original great (yes, great! As a avid horror fan, Blair With Project was GREAT!) was that it was original. This seemed like an episode from the old 80's Freddy's Nightmares. People complained that "nothing happened" in the original film. Well, NOTHING happens in this one. The acting is so terrible that the whole theater was laughing at it. The original film hardly had any comic relief moments, this one is filled with it. The original was shot like a documentary, this had "hip 90's music" and tons of great "pro-pot smoking" scenes that it made me ill. No jumps, no scares, horribly directed and it is obvious that the people involved with this film hated the original Blair Witch Project. Well, I hated Book of Shadow: Blair Witch 2 (which never explained what the hell the "Book of

I am a movie fan, I watch movies, it's my hobby. I own almost 300 DVD's and see at least 10 movies a week, usually at least 1 in the theater. Never in my life have I ever during or after a movie said the words:"I want my money back!"I mean 9 bucks nowadays is nothing, and it's very hard to make a film that would upset me to that point...Then came Blair Witch 2!The only good thing I found about the film was the camera direction. When I found out acclaimed director, Joe Berlinger, co-director of the documentaries "Paradise Lost: The Child Murders at Robin Hood Hills" and "Paradise Lost 2: Revelations" was involved I wasn't surprised. When I read reviews online (I wanted to prove to myself that I wasn't the only one), when many said this movie was a horrible failure in comparison for Berlinger, I WASN'T SURPRISED.I was a big fan on the first Blair Witch. I actually saw it before its wide release, in a little art house theater in Boston. Before the hype. It was innovative. It was mind blowing. And it was suspenseful! (the scene near the end was probably the most suspenseful movie scene I've ever been witness to.) I can't BW2 had any of these. I can say quite the opposite.The only thing good about the film were the first 10 and last 10 or so minutes. The documentary footage. The rest was pure crap. If you liked this movie please promise me never to read any of my reviews, EVER. I don't want you to, just on the off chance you may agree with me somewhere in some other movie! As impossible as that is!Pete's Movie Rating (out of 10): 1 (only because imdb won't let me rate in negatives... okay may-be not that bad... but CLOSE)

reviews.review_title: A sloppy disjointed mess of a movie whose intriguing core of analyzing the mass hysteria around Blair Witch can't overcome its flaws.
reviews.content: In the Autumn of 1999 after the release of The Blair Witch Project, the town of Burkittsville, Maryland sees a massive boon in tourists who are obsessed with the Blair Witch legend giving rise to tourism in the area. One such tour, The Blair Witch Hunt run by Jeffrey Patterson (Jeffrey Donovan) is having its inaugural tour with boyfriend/girlfriend graduate students Stephen (Stephen Barker Turner) and Tristen (Tristine Skyler), goth girl Kim (Kim Director), and wiccan Erica (Erica Leershen). During a wild first night the group blackout and awken to find Stephen and Tristen's research papers have been torn to shreds and a slow descent into madness begins.Following the success of The Blair Witch Project Artisan Entertainment were eager for a sequel, but producers Haxan films wanted to wait until the hype over the film died down before attempting a follow-up. Artisan instead made the decision to move forward on a follow-up without the original writer/directors Daniel Myrick and Eduardo Sánchez, though they are credited as executive producers. True crime documentarian Joe Berlinger was hired to direct in what would be his first narrative feature film (and also his last until 2019's Extremely Wicked, Shockingly Evil and Vile). Berlinger sought to make something the direct opposite of the original film as the filmmaking and camera work had been subject to widespread parody following the film's release and Berlinger instead of making a straight horror film aimed for a more satirical film lampooning the lazy consumption of media that allowed audiences to be fooled into thinking The Blair Witch Project was a documentary. Artisan did not like Berlinger's original cut and made requests for new kill footage to be inserted throughout the film, the additional of mental hospital sequences, and the 8-minute epilogue that bookended the film set in a police interrogation room would instead be sprinkled in vignettes throughout the film. The film was a far cry from the success of the first film as Book of Shadows: Blair Witch 2 only made $26 million in the United States a far cry from the $140 million the first one had produced with interational numbers only bringing the film to $47 million against its $15 million budget. Critics and audiences also panned the film, and Artisan ended up scrapping a planned Blair Witch 3. While the movie does have some interesting ideas about mass hysteria and consumption of media, it conveys those ideas rather sloppily and poorly.Easily the best part of the film is the opening 5 minutes where Berlinger gives a snapshot of the hype around The Blair Witch project using clips from Roger Ebert's At the Movies, late night talk show hosts Conan O'Brien and Jay Leno, and interviews with residents of Burkittsville to look at the cultural ripples caused by the film with some very funny deadpan deliveries on things such as "shipping rocks" getting a good smirk from me. But unfortunately the film heads down hill and fast once we meet our main characters on the Blair Witch Hunt and while I didn't think much of the three characters from the first Blair Witch movie, Blair Witch 2's characters make those three look like the pinnacle of John Hughes' writing. The characters in Book of Shadows: Blair Witch 2 come from the Kevin Williamson school of late 90s horror tropes with them falling into the same Gen X cynical and "too smart for their own good" archetypes that might've been interesting were it 1996, but after multiple imitators across several different teen skewing horror films it's pretty hard to see these generic twenty somethings as anything other than "a copy of a copy of a copy" that's seen its edge dull from crisp clarity to a messy pixelated blob. The movie's edited like scenes were placed in a blender with random gore shots or cuts to the police interrogation never creating any sort of atmosphere of creeping dread especially since the interrogation room sequences spoil who's going to be left alive. The editing in Book of Shadows is some of the most frustrating I've ever seen with the opening having at least 4 different time identifying texts that will leave audiences confused and bewildered as to where we even are.Book of Shadows: Blair Witch 2 seems like it has a nugget of a good idea with satirizing the frenzy around The Blair Witch Project, but with the sloppy editing, unlikable characters, and virtually non-existent story good ideas alone aren't enough to salvage a mess like this. Maybe if Berlinger's cut that had a more satirical tone had been released maybe this material could've worked, but you're still stuck with a group of bland unlikable characters so it's a crapshoot.

I'm suprised everyone thought this movie sux.. i like it because it played with your mind.. and let you know that reality is what you make it to be.. and how people these days believe what they want to and that the media controls to much. I definatley reccomend it.. and if you don't/didn't get the point of the movie, I'm sorry....

The only reason I even watched BW2 was to test run it for my theater (looking for presentation problems).  Horror movies usually scare the sh** out of me and I thought this movie would do the same.  BW2 didn't even flirt with being scary.  About the only thing I took away from the movie is the amazing resemblance that Jeffrey Donovan bears to Ralph Fiennes.

This movie totally sucks. It makes the first one look like a masterpiece! This movie was soooo bad that I could hardly sit through it! Don't expect ANYTHING spooky about this film. The only scary thing is I had to pay to see it!! Not even a damn witch!! Don't see this c***!!

reviews.review_title: Could it be - Yes it is worse than the first!
reviews.content: I went to see this one for free (friend paid) since I wasn't going to pay for it after watching the first 'Blair Wash'. I said "Hey it can't be that much worse than the first, right?" Boy was I wrong.  This movie sucked, plain and simple.  I think I will need someone to pay me to even consider seeing a third.

what this movie wanted to be: a psychological thriller or a sequel to 1999's ground breaking "The Blair Witch Project".  I vote for the latter.  "Blair Witch 2" really has nothing to do with the first film except for the hype surrounding it.  All "Blair Witch 2" is really about is five people (a tour guide, a writer and his pregnant girlfriend, a girl who is into Witchcraft, and a Goth chick) who go into the woods in Burketsville, Maryland to find out what really happened there.  They decide to spend the night in the woods and they set up a surveillance system to video record anything that might happen.  They wake up the next morning only to discover that the surveillance equipment has been trashed, the writer's papers have been ripped up, the pregnant girl has had a miscarriage and they have no memory of what happened the night before. I don't know what to really make of this film.  I really can't say if I liked it or hated it.  This movie does manage to maintain a constant level of creepiness but it unfortunately never amounts to a big pay off.  However, that level of creepiness is actually one of this films biggest merits. Since no one is really sure if the events of "The Blair Witch Project" actually occurred, that adds to the overall goodness of the film.  Whether "The Blair Witch Project" really happened or is just a brilliant hoax concocted by local townspeople or talented movie makers is anyone's guess. This is where the concepts of fantasy and reality come into play.  Is the Blair Witch real?  Did three students really disappear into the woods of Burketsville, Maryland?  But as I said before, none of this ever amounts anything truly satisfying.  This is what "Blair Witch 2" should have done which was try to explain the mystery of the Blair Witch, but it instead opted for the usual cheap scares.    6/10

This follow-up to the ground-breaking film that introduced many of us to the Found Footage concept is a 'fictional re-enactment of events following the events of The Blair Witch Project.' It starts promisingly, with Burkittsville residents being irritated and financially bolstered by the notoriety their town has attracted. Some dialogue is rank, ("There are always naysayers who come here and say  nay.") and the characters are pretty unlikable and stereotypical (we are introduced to Kim (Kim Director) lying back on a grave, smoking, dressed all in black and daubed with heavy make-up – so she'll be a goth then). Erica (Erica Geerson) is a Wiccan and therefore sensitive to whatever 'curse' may or may not be out there. They seem to be a bit stoned and listen to rock music and might possibly have just stumbled off a catwalk. Text book, picturesque teens. A disappointing development after the realism displayed by Heather, Mikey and Josh from the original.This is a major flaw. Main character Jeffrey (Jeffrey Donovan) has a history of hospitalisation and is victimised by the local Sheriff (who seems to have strolled straight out of 'The Dukes of Hazzard'). And yet because of his uncharismatic, postured playing, it is impossible to sympathise with, or feel anything for him or his plight. Tristine (Tristine Ryler) is really the only sympathetic, or realistic character present  And yet, this sequel is undeserving of the critical drubbing it has received. It has some great unnerving moments: the stuttering doll-like creature Tristine sees in the hospital, the image of her drowning her dead, bloodied baby in a stagnant pond (would anyone who suffered a miscarriage during such an unnerving trip seriously then consider continuing with that trip?), the slow drifting into delirium  and the ending, where the group watch the recording they made of themselves and it contradicts their memory of events is a pretty neat way to wrap things up.The temptation could have been to produce another docu-drama, but events here are deliberately stylised in such a way, the audience is in no doubt it is watching a professional production.The locations are excellent and the whole production is very well shot, but I think 'Book of Shadows' is a (perceived) failure because while it is good, it isn't brilliant – and it needed to be brilliant to match the virtually insurmountable success of the first."She's a witch, maaan!"

reviews.review_title: why do you hate this movie???
reviews.content: I've seen this movie three years ago, and I love it. I saw first than "Blair Witch Project" and I find that is most entertaining than the first one. So, a lot of people that has watched this movie have hated it, but I ask: why? it is because people have liked more than this falsehood that the first one, but I see it on the contrary, although the first one seems realer of that than they pretended to be at the beginning.newly I had watched the movie (the first one), I believed that it was real, but with the time, and seeing this website, I say that all those producing are some rats, and they made that movie practically to increase the tourism in that region.But, in spite of all the falsehood of the same one, I vote for the movie 7/10

reviews.review_title: Frightening but should not have been a sequel
reviews.content: I was more scared by this one than the last. It shouldn't have been made as a sequel - it would have hung together better as a story in its own right. With another witch from somewhere else, maybe, or some other kind of killer altogether.

I would advise anybody who liked the first film to avoid seeing this.
It was clear that the original creators had very little to do with this film, as we see a fantastic concept turned into a generic teen horror. The plot was utterly uninteresting and served only to move the characters into needless situations. Obviously the producers seemed to like some of the ideas used in the first film - like the interview footage - but its use seemed totally inappropriate.This exact group dynamic has been over used in recent horror films, but it was totally unnecessary in a film which already had such a fantastic story to work with (from the 1st film). The actors were totally unbelievable in their roles, at almost no point during the film did I view them as their characters - all I could see were obviously cast actors - was I supposed to believe that I was watching a totally free spirited young woman who is one with nature and somehow had time to completely master the wiccan art, when it's obvious she has been in make-up for three hours before the scene.
The addition of numerous drug/alcohol consumption scenes was a very cheap attempt to gain the film credibility with its younger audience.
All in all - the films desire to be a box office success completely undermined the character and raw edge of the first film.

reviews.review_title: Blair Witch 2 is full of clichés, with a horrible script, made predictable. The film is also not scary at any time and this is very serious for a horror movie
reviews.content: With success coming from the most cost effective film in cinema history, The Blair Witch, a sequel was inevitable. And it came just a year later. Even with a signed contract with the production company for a return, the writers and directors of the original, Daniel Myrick and Eduardo Sánchez, seeing the path to where the project was going, decided not to return at the end. To replace them, it was called the famous documentary filmmaker Joe Berlinger, just the original film is practically a documentary and have been sold as one.Berlinger, director of the famous Paradise Lost: The Child Murders at Robin Hood Hills (1996), Paradise Lost 2: Revelations (2000) and Brother's Keeper (1992), had good experience in the field and seemed to be a good choice to keep the same climate and characteristics of the original, but what was seen was a complete misrepresentation of the concepts and ideas that both surprised and shocked the world a year earlier.Book of Shadows: Blair Witch 2 is the previous movie really is like a movie and fanaticism caused by the success of the film that will develop the structure of this sequence. Everything begins with a montage of news reports and TV shows, entitled to the testimony of celebrities such as Jay Leno, Conan O'Brien and Kurt Loder (MTV) interspersed with residents of the fictional town of Burkittsville, where events have passed, arguing how the film has affected their lives. Are shown scenes of queues at the cinema to see the movie. Tourists have been drawn to Burkittsville, which has no more than 200 residents, because the film about the Blair Witch.Jeff (Jeffrey Donovan) is one of the city's residents who decide to cash in on the instant fame of their city. He has a website that sells T-shirts, caps and sticks tied exactly like in the movie. Your product is the hottest tour of the place where they were found tapes Heather Donohue, Joshua Leonard and Mike Williams, the protagonists of the film. It brings together a group that part towards this morbid visit to the city. In it are the beautiful witch Erica (Erica Leerhsen), a couple who is studying and writing a paper on the "Blair Witch" Tristen Skyler (Tristine Skyler) and Stephen (Stephen Barker Turner) and Kim Diamond (Kim Director), a goth with psychic powers. On reaching the place promised, the five wriggle in the most comfortable and start talking and drinking until erase. The next day, the equipment Jeff are destroyed, the work of Stephen and Tristen is torn and no one remembers what happened in the forest. They then decide to go to Jeff's house to try to find something for the few remaining tapes and when strange pagan symbols begin to appear in the body of the young, the situation is complicated.Blair Witch 2 was an almost unanimously negative criticism from U. S.. What seems to have bothered the critics was Berlinger deliver a film "conventional". Director Joe Berlinger said everyone expected something more like the first film, and he preferred to reverse expectations. However, in this case reversing expectations was the worst decision. It is acceptable to the director actually want to deliver something different, a different point of view of history, but many facts leave the film as one of the worst of 2000. Black magic was inserted gaining prominence, but the fact of fdora pagan symbols, the question is not thorough and emerges as the resolution of the questions raised.The film takes a clear idea of wanting to profit from the success of the first film in a disjointed and poorly done. First the shooting style and realism printed in the first film simply were not shown this time. The identity was being lost. The footage shot by the actors themselves with camera shake in hand and drop method actors alone in the woods. Berlinger, and leave the camera shake, bet on the soundtrack and a much more elaborate edition, seeks to take the events of the forest environment and leads to a more closed, claustrophobic.In the photograph we had a big disappointment. The night shots in the first film scary passed an impression of where the story was going. It was also left out. Now the most important is to show the teenagers playing with the legend of the witch, and sex. Speaking of casting, he is one of the worst I've ever seen, except maybe for the lovely Erica Leerhsen. The others are from a lack of naturalness, specially the Gothic Kim Director.Change the expected by all, in this case, was not a good decision. Blair Witch 2 is full of clichés, with a horrible script, made predictable (as that Erica is back in a closet and obviously know it will backfire and cause a big scare at all). The movie really distorted what was so successful and was the first differential. Tried to innovate and show something different. Despite the criticism of the imaging industry, the film is not scary at any time and this is very serious for a horror movie, which theoretically would have to at least equal the first.

A group of young adults obessesed with the events that occured in The Blair Witch Project head out to the same woods where the other three students disappear. The next day they wake up with no memory of the events that occured the night before. As they watch footage that was recorded the night before while they blacked out, they learn some horrifying truths and discover that the Blair Witch is a very real presence.Mangled by both auidences and critics alike and a major flop at the box office, despite opening on 3300+ screens, this is actually a very worthy follow-up to the original. While it might not be as original or creative as the first one, it still is very creative and original in its own right. And features good performances from the five lead actors and some scary and intense scenes. It also has a very surprising ending and is much smarter then most films of its kind. Now if only it were just a bit more coherent.

No-one can deny that The Blair Witch Project was the most ground-breaking film of last year. When it turned an extremely healthy profit someone in a suit decided that a sequel would be  good business. So it was with some trepidation that I sat down in a south London cinema yesterday evening to see possibly the first public showing of this film in the UK. I should have stayed at home.The basic story is simple. The Blair Witch Project has been a massive success, and the town of Burkittsville is overrun with obsessive fans. Jeff, who has recently been released from a mental institution, has set up the Blair Witch Hunt, which offers tourists the chance to see where the movie was made. But after a night of camping, Jeff and his four customers cannot remember the events of the previous night, so they decamp to his home, an abandoned warehouse, to study the footage that was shot the day before...The premise of basing the movie on the hype of the first film is really the only sensible alley that a sequel could have taken, but writer/director Joe Berlinger manages to stuff it up at the first corner. "I was in the hospital when it came out", says Jeff of the first film, so we are subjected to laughable scenes of him a rubber room, complete with window and radiator, and of him having milk poured up his nose. Things don't improve. Throughout the film we are subjected to mono-dimensional characters, right from our alleged heroes to townspeople so unpleasant it makes Royston Vasey look like Hi-De-Hi. The words they speak seem to be coming off the tops of their heads, and the script as a whole is so poor I wouldn't use it to line a cat litter tray.As director of the acclaimed documentary Paradise Lost, Berlinger should at least make things look interesting. He doesn't. He fails to inspire any kind of tension, and it's worth noting that he employs a device [interspersing videoed footage with people talking about it] that Myrick and Sanchez rejected the first time round. The performances are workmanlike at best, with the five leads giving it their best shot. The worst actor here though, must be the sheriff [whose name isn't listed at the time of writing]: a gruff stereotype who adds virtually nothing to the plot.I do hope the young actors find better roles, but they can't really do any worse. A cack-handed shaggy dog story filled with plot holes [Who is Erica really? Why did the Witch possess Tristine in particular? What the hell is the Book Of Shadows??] is not the best way to start a career. But I am left wondering why Artisan are releasing the film worldwide simultaneously? It couldn't be because they want to avoid bad word of mouth, surely? At the end of the day, The Blair Witch Project was a truly unique event, and Book Of Shadows is nothing more than an ordinary horror film, and not a very good one. Don't even think about paying to see this rubbish.

Have You Seen 'The Blair Witch Project'?  Thought it was good?  Very clever film right?  A lot of hype but paid off right?  Yeah, well the sequel sucks. Don't bother watching it...actually DO bother just to see the comically bad owl scene (a stuffed owl flying through a window! OOOH scary stuff!)  This film is terrible.  1/10 - the one being because a sequel was a good idea. Shame.  Horrible.

Well, when it started I thought it was going to be at least a decent teenager film. After 30 minutes, I was asking myself: "why nothing happens?"; then the film reached 110 minutes and still NOTHING happened. For a suspense/horror movie, that's a big disappointment, mainly when the previous film of the franchise is highly suspenseful and frightening.The acting is poor at many times; Kim Director's acting varies from medium to bad. Scenes involving discussions or fights are really really lame. Actors make nervous expressions in face and attitude, but instead of really pushing the other actor, they just affectionately put their hands in other's shoulders, like they were good friends calmly sharing secrets. I believe "Book of Shadows: Blair Witch 2" is one of those famous one- armed bandit. Seeing "Blair Witch Project" over and over again is more pleasureful than watching this one single time.

reviews.review_title: There was no need to do a sequel to this.....
reviews.content: The night I was set to go into the theatre and see the follow-up to one of the biggest independent horror flicks of 1999,and to have it totally wasted with a movie that has no plot,the lamest dialogue ever(which equals to some of those "Friday the 13th" movies they had back in the 1980's),and had me going in circles the whole time. There was no need to make a sequel,and besides,why kill off a good thing that had audiences scared out of their seats in the first one only to see it totally and completely trashed in the sequel? And where was this book of shadows? Anyway,you had these college kids including one who looked like a cross between Elvira and Morticia Addams,and the others who were just travel into the woods of Burkettsville on this "Blair Witch Hunt" hoping to find whom or whatever is out there,and certainly there was no witch here,only to find out their heads were completely messed up in which they are seeing things that are not there.... The night I went to see this the audience(which consisted mostly of teenagers and little kids who were sneaked into the back of the cimema to see it)didn't get the whole concept of the movie,which was pointless and clueless. Let's hope they don't make a Blair Witch 3. Another wasted flick for this Halloween season.

I do believe I'm the ONLY person on this curious little planet (check out Jupiter man, better believe it - we're small potatoes!) who quite liked this sequel. Admittedly, ANYTHING to follow the original had to be an improvement, even BLAIR WITCH GOES TO WASHINGTON?  Now that ISN'T to say that this juiced-up little offering is any great shakes in its own right....one would be hard-pressed to find anything much professionally impressive to rave about, but hell's bells, there IS a story of sorts here - something to focus your frontal lobes on. OK so we have little more than another bunch of collegiates doing the woods thing again, following their compatriots into the Black Hole of Burkittsville. No better organised but cashed-up obviously, with some state of the art surveillance equipment and some flash computer hardware. It comes down ultimately to the discovery that someone or someTHING has tampered with the equipment overnight and that two hours of the group's lives appears to be unaccounted for. Laugh at what follows if you like but hey, you think that asking an audience to spend nearly an hour staring at dead leaves along a god-forsaken trail in the original film WASN'T funny? I thought it was hilarious?BLAIR WITCH 2, which Sanchez and Myrick exec-produced by the way, at least TRIES something. You might not like what it does or how it does it but give it its due - its a functional movie. Exploitive?  sure! Of any lasting benefit to anyone?  No!  though you might want to ponder the significance of the last twenty minutes or so, I though it was rather creative thinking!Looking forward to BLAIR WITCH 3: REVENGE OF THE MUNCHKINS!

reviews.review_title: Good Movie And Far Superior To The Abysmal Blair Witch Project
reviews.content: This very good film had an easy ride in all honesty. It wouldn't be hard to produce a sequel to an utterly dire piece of rubbish such as The Blair Witch Project. The original film was no good at all and so any film would have been better.Not that that should take anything away from this film. Students go into the woods of Maryland to make a documentary about the events of the first film and that's when the fun starts. This film has quite a few scary scenes in it and the actors and actresses seem to be doing well in their scenes. It's a film which you need to pay attention too and is one of the better horror movies of the 21st century.All in all, I recommend checking out this sequel to Blair Witch because it is good and far superior to it's predecessor.

reviews.review_title: I wanted to like this Film.............
reviews.content: Okay let's start off by saying this............. I LOVED the first movie. Scared me, creeped me out, all of that kind of stuff. Blair Witch 2 did a little of that but mostly left me flat.  I'm glad they took a different direction then the first one, but I was disappointed in the poor acting "Aaron Spelling-esque" cast.  I really got the feeling these people were pulled from some bad "Melrose Place" spin off, And the Sheriff was right out of a "Smokey  and the Bandit" movie. I also thought the pounding hard rock soundtrack really took away from the movies overall creepy factor,  In some cases (like this one) I think less would have been better. Now the story could have been good ............... But that ending??? Who didn't see that coming?  I felt it was a cop out and lacked any sort of mystery or shocking imagery.  Now don't get me wrong I wasn't looking for explanation, but I was wanting for something less obvious.Overall I didn't hate it but I was sooooooo disappointed

Because I saw The Blair Witch Project as an immediate masterpiece and classic there is nothing left for me to vote this off as a 'cheap' rip-off or better as a result of a hype. I mean, this film really has no good things in it, except maybe Kim Director, who I though was very cool as (well KIM). Anyways nothing special here, but not a complete waste. In comparison to Blair Witch Project it would get a 4 out of 10. But let's be objective here.5,5 out of 10

This film takes the premise that video, film, and the internet have obscured the lines between reality and non-reality so much that we no longer know what is real. The first Blair Witch film and its companion piece CURSE OF THE BLAIR WITCH proved that. To this day, some people are still asking, "Did it really happen? Is it a reenactment of a real event?"One character in this movie says that "film lies but video doesn't." Yet we know that both can be faked -- the same point made in WAG THE DOG. For example, we buy into stereotypes of people because we see them on TV and in films. BOOK OF SHADOWS is filled with stereotypes, the most obvious being the old sheriff, complete with southern accent, nasty attitude, and threatening behavior. Is he real? No. This movie admits that all the people in the film are actors "re-creating" supposedly true events. And we buy in because we want to play along.This film is a bit ragged, but that too may be intentional since we are being duped and we know it. The acting is not great, but that may be simply to remind us that this is just a movie version of supposedly real happenings, just as in the awkward TV reenactments of crimes on "reality based" shows.I found the film to be an interesting dark comedy mixing THE EXORCIST, the recent remake of HOUSE ON HAUNTED HILL, ROCKY HORROR PICTURE SHOW, and ONE FLEW OVER THE CUCKOO'S NEST. In typical Hitchcock fashion, we are misled all over the place. Perhaps Jeff, the mentally unstable leader of the tour who is very expert in video equipment, has faked the videos. Perhaps not. When this film comes to its abrupt end, we are left to decide for ourselves, much as we were at the abrupt end of THE BLAIR WITCH PROJECT.

reviews.review_title: Worst film I have ever seen? Oui.
reviews.content: I cannot begin to tell you how upset I am. Not only did I have to sit in the third row, but this was in fact the WORST movie I have ever experienced. I didn't walk out only because I was in shock at how bad it was.Bad dialogue, bad editing, bad special effects, and dear God, bad bad acting. If one can call it acting. I am personally offended at how bad this movie was.It was as though Berlinger decided that in order to make it seem like he is not ripping off BW or cashing in on its success, he had to do exactly the opposite of what made it successful. Do not leave anything to the imagination. More gore must equal more scares.I think the group involved in the creation of this film should have been fired, and the group responsible for the outstanding mockumentaries be brought in. Namely Curse of the Blair Witch, and the Burkittsville 7. The new one to go with BW2 was outstanding above the other 2 by far. Those were scary, because they seemed so real.This movie was formulaic in the classic big budget Hollywood sense, and missed the mark horribly. I saw it for free at a premiere, and I still feel cheated.

reviews.review_title: I had to slap some more people again.
reviews.content: This is one of the better sequels of the decade. It is certainly the most original. This time around, we have a movie that recognizes itself as a movie knowing that its predecessor was a work of fiction. Paradise Lost director Joe Berlinger chose a creepy movie to direct and it is certainly made that way by him and HOUSE ON HAUNTED HILL screenwriter, Dick Beebe. The opening credit sequence was awesome as we see a load of forest and trees to the sounds of Marilyn Manson's "Disposable Teens". *MINOR SPOILERS* This film follows a former mental patient named Jeff Patterson (Jeffrey Donovan) who has come up with a tour to bring four other fans of the original film into the woods to invent a search for the legendary Blair Witch. The countless visions of violence and gore are enough to turn any weak stomached person away from the screen. There is enough blood, violence, gore and death to keep any horror movie buff occupied. If you want to scream...don't see this movie. That is the last thing it does. It entertains. But to some, it annoys just as badly as the first film did. Which, the first movie did not bother me. I was only bothered by how all the people moaned about it. I had to slap them too, just as how I had to do with those who felt the first movie was terrible. This film gives some good visions and ghostly images. Thanks to the IMDb goof page, I was able to find all the hidden images within the film. Thanks guys! Despite what other people say, this was an under-rated horror film that should have been an immediate smash success. Instead, it was a success just not as big a success as the first films. Many people were disappointed. And now I feel that when the third entry comes out, I will have to slap many more people in order to try and punish them into realizing that these are some of the most original movies ever made.....5/5.

reviews.review_title: Believe It Or Not,This Was Actuley A GOOD Movie!
reviews.content: I really did enjoy the Blair Witch 2,sure it was a little weird but it does have you on the edge of your seat,waiting to see what happens. The actors and actress' in the movie,weren't so believable but who cares.The first Blair Witch,was obviously better considering it was the first one but this was just as good.     Maybe,even better.Maybe,i enjoyed it more because it was more like a 'normal' film.Don't expect anything to good,when you see it but the film is good enough and i guess you could say i AM looking forward to the Blair Witch 3!(i think....)

reviews.review_title: It's not The Blair Witch Project, but why should it be?
reviews.content: There seems to be a lot of complaint about how dissimilar to BWP1 this film is but why should it be similar to the first one. This film manages, after passing references to the original, to be its own distinctive entity. It's not as good as the original but it's not really justified to expect it to be. The original was truly that.This film is flawed. The acting and writing could be better. the Wiccan character is almost objectionably stereotypical. Its sense of purpose is convoluted.But nothing is perfect. This film is, IMO, great entertainment. It keeps you on the edge of your seat. It is also visually superb.Comparing it to the original is an exercise in futility. Book Of Shadows: Blair Witch 2 (terrible title) is it's own film. If you are deciding whether or not to see it, or if you have already seen and are evaluating it, try and take it on its own merits.

let me say first, my only disappointment was that the movie isn't longer. it built up such a great story line which really got me into it, then it just stopped knowing that there was so much more it could have done.  obviously making way for the next in the series, like star wars, empire strikes back made way for return of the jedi.  even though it started slow (and at first, i thought i wasn't going to like it during the opening scenes showing flashes of gore) but like a greek tragedy, the story takes you down a path to which there is no escape and continues to pile the tension until you almost can't take it. and that's where it leaves you, tense. its like reading a great book and having to put it down only cause your house is on fire and still you try to keep reading it on the way out. but in this case you have to wait until the next installment.

reviews.review_title: Under-rated. Much better than the first.
reviews.content: `Blair Witch 2: Book of Shadow'. Personally, I felt this film is much better than the first one. Much better. The first one I found it like really boring. This one has a good storyline and are very entertaining from start till the end. The acting has been done pretty well for the unknown actors. The atmosphere this movie gave is excellent. This is what I expected from the typical horror film to be like. Don't give high hope from the movie and I'm sure you will like it. Definitely, one horror film that worth a watch.Max: 6.5/10Recommendation: Lend it from the VDO store

How in the world could anyone stomach to make a film this awful? I feel incredibly dumb to be duped into watching this waste of time and money.  I saw the special on SciFi, that looked interesting-- I thought, "Hey, even if it had a lot of problems, the first one was kind of scary and really different-- if they have a big budget to do it with, it's got to be pretty cool." I could not have been more wrong! It had less of an ending and made less sense with way more gratuitous gore than the original, with significantly worse acting and a script that got more stupid as it got more complex.  I imagine that everything might make more sense if I went to the website and researched it and bought lots of merchandise.  My fifteen dollars wasn't enough! Please, please, for the love of good movies, spare yourself! I'm not exaggerating!  All told, "Book of Shadows" was the worst movie I've ever seen! Be afraid! Be very afraid!

reviews.review_title: Suspensfull film that stands on it's own feet
reviews.content: This film is a completely different entity than the original in many ways.. less of an experimental film and more of a main stream modern horror film. But in many ways it is even more effective. The story focuses on a small group of people who are obsessed with the original film and decide to go camp out in the woods on the spot where Heather's tapes were found with their own video gear and see what happens. Of course the promptly consume what seems like tons and tons of drugs and booze and when they wake up in the morning they find their stuff trashed and that they have lost four hours of their nights where they have no recollection. Retreating to the warehouse where one of them lives, they start watching the videotapes to try to figure out what happened to them, and mysterious things keep happening. Basically many things happen in this film that are either real or illusion and the reality of the situation is dependent on the differences between film and video as outlined early in the movie. However that throwaway comment is easily missed and the audience is constantly on edge wondering what is happening, what is real or not real. The cast of young newcomers is quite good at setting their characters and the direction and tech work all contribute to an eerily spooky setting that will please both fans and non fans of the first installment. GRADE: A-
One of the worst films I've ever seen and I've seen a lot of bad ones...
Truly awful movie. It reminds me of Caddyshack 2 or Airplane 2...the first movie is one of the best ever, the second one of the worst ever. TERRIBLE script, terrible acting.

reviews.review_title: This movie should not have been made
reviews.content: How anyone could have liked it is beyond me.  I'm not so much concerned about how it carried on the idea of the original, but the characters were so stupid that I just wanted to kick them-- OH, their stupidness.  Like their 'goth girl'?  Ooh, so goth that she's listening to P.O.D. in the van.  I wouldn't have cared so much if they had just had her dressed like that, but they called her goth through the whole movie-- and she's always giving the little 'rock' sign.  They really should have done some research on the subculture before they actually released such idiocy.And their witch.  Ugh.  While I don't really think that Wiccans are the most enlightened people, I've never known any of them to be as ridiculously . . .. ridiculous as theirs.  I'm sure that Wiccans everywhere were as offended by her as I was by the 'goth girl'.  Again: RESEARCH, people.Some of the movie was interesting, even thought provoking, and yet I can't bring myself to watch it again.  They could have done something really good with it, too, which is the depressing part.

reviews.review_title: This is so bad that it's funny.
reviews.content: I loved the original Blair Witch Project - scared the pants off me.This one is pitiful. Worse acting I ever seen and boring story line.

Worst movie I have ever seen, and I own a copy of Shakes the Clown.  It hurt me.  Please don't let it hurt you.  People act by yelling, the title means nothing, you'll figure out the plot within the first 20 minutes.  I wish I had more to say, but any more words would be a waste of my effort.

reviews.review_title: To be honest, I've seen worse
reviews.content:
This got *bad* reviews on release back in 2000. Brainless, derivative, and opportunist were a few of the terms banded about or at least implied.So I watched it expecting something truly dire aka Cabin Fever and ended up actually being reasonably entertained.It presents itself as a 'fictionalised re-enactment of true events' - once again attempting to blur the line between fiction and reality, and is filmed with a higher budget and more traditionally polished production values like you'd expect from Hollywood. No shaky cam this time.The story focuses around a troupe of 5 intrepid adventurers going on a tour of the Blair Witch area to see it all for themselves. Jeff is leading them on this mission as 'the tour guide' and it's his maiden voyage after advertising the service on the web (Once again smartly tying in with the original.).After a night's camping of getting stoned, drunk and talking complete nonsense they wake up to find their gear's been trashed and it's snowing paper. None remember falling asleep and they're disturbed by what's happened.From here, things get weirder.Obviously there's a supernatural overtone in this movie, with gothic ideas and black magic prevalent. In places these are implemented reasonably well, if not enough to *scare* us they're enough to keep our attention.
The main strength the movie has is blurring reality - you're never sure what's real and what isn't, so although the acting isn't exactly a-list it's enough to facilitate the quirky happenings and make things puzzling.There aren't any strong twists or clever moments, but it never pretends to be a work of art.As a horror film buff, I accepted I knew what this would be, and it was never self-important, boring, or pretentious. Contrived, yes, original, hell no. But what it does it does reasonably well.Tolerate its shortcomings and you may be entertained.

There are some sequels that fail to live up to the original. There are others which seem like a sad attempt to cash in on previous popularity. Blair Witch 2: Book of Shadows manages to overshadow the original Blair Witch film by establishing itself as one of the worst films ever made. The real crime of this film is that somewhere a third world worker suffered over CD stamping plants to produce the god awful pile of crap. This is the kind of film that makes going to see Glitter seem worthwhile.There are spoilers below, but do you really care at this point?The film begins by informing us that the following is a reenactment of the fictional events following the Blair Witch Project film. Thinking about this screen for any length of time makes your head explode. Do not resist this urge. Save yourself from the incoming s**t. I've never enjoyed films that take time out of their busy plot to inform us how clever they are. Once you're in the theatre the eight dollars (or whatever) is gone. You're there. Stop pimping it. That's one of the reasons that seemingly endless clips about how cool the original movie was are so annoying. Chances are the small handful of people who went to see Blair Witch 2 also saw the original. If they didn't, there's no way in hell they are going to go back and watch the original now.The acting is miserable. From the over-the-top hillbilly/western/North Eastern sheriff to the collection of gen-x kids who wander into the woods in search of thrills, liquor and who knows what else, this is one of the worst casting jobs ever put to screen. Replacing the cast with marshmallow peeps would have brought more personality out. Sure, the film tosses out some gore and nudity, but after two hours of mind-numbing plot you just don't care anymore. You just want to see the credits roll so you can go on with your life. The actors in the film were given character names similar to their real-life ones, and I suppose this is supposed to be clever, but ultimately it just lands squarely in the "who gives a f**k" pile.As if the bad acting, sets, and storyline wasn't annoying enough, the real kick to the groin comes at the end of the film when you're informed that everything you've seen previously didn't actually happen. The characters, hopped up on drugs in the woods and in a pseudo house, thought they were having a normal evening of killing off the bad "witch" for the good of. well, something, but instead were all crazed psychotics who murdered innocent people. Whoopee. Nothing like sitting through a couple hours of mind-numbing garbage only to be informed that the garbage you sat through was all just a big bait and switch, and that none of it actually happened that way. I suppose if the end result would have been something meaningful it might have left the audience happy. but instead you just don't care.I'm happy to have seen Blair Witch 2 because it sets the bar for crap. No matter where I find myself, be it stuck on an eight hour flight with Battlefield Earth playing over and over again or forced to go to a Pauly Shore marathon to save a dying relative, at least I can say that I'm not having to see Blair Witch 2 again. This film will forever give us that: no matter what miserable hole you find yourself in, just remember:At least it isn't as bad as Blair Witch 2.

Underrated "sequel" to THE BLAIR WITCH PROJECT is an entirely new story, taking it's premise from the real life BLAIR WITCH craze, as well as the events of the original movie.  Four people (two journalists, a real witch and a goth chick) are led into the Maryland woods by a local outcast who gives "Blair Witch Hunt" tours.  Once in the woods, they all black out for several hours, and later head back to the tour guide's warehouse/studio/apartment to review the video footage they shot and figure out what happened.  Well made, disorienting and effectively eerie, this is one of the best American horror movies of recent years.  Bears more of a resemblance to David Lynch's LOST HIGHWAY than to the original BLAIR WITCH, however.

reviews.review_title: What is wrong with IMDb users?
reviews.content: OK I just want to get one thing straight. The average user rates the god-awful atrocity of a film War of the Worlds a 6.7, but gives a good little horror flick like BW2 a 4.1. They give a bottom 100 movie contender such as sex and the teenage mind a 4.8 but yet a challenging and intelligent movie like Book of Shadows gets a 4.1? Do you really think War of the Worlds and Sex and the Teenage Mind were better than BW2? I admit this movie has its flaws, but 30 minutes into it, it comes together beautifully. The violence doesn't flinch, the acting is above average and the idea is original. Did you just want more of the first movie or something? The end of this film is truly gripping as far as horror flicks go, and the ideas it puts forth is spine tingling. This a good movie and I can't understand the bad reviews for it. I think its because of all the Blair Witch 1 backlash, that nobody really gave Book of Shadows a chance. Well I am here to help you make up your mind. Go and see this movie because it is really a good movie and deserves a way higher rating and some much better attention than it has received. Crawl back into your safe little holes and leave the good movies for the big boys. Thanks. 7/10

I only saw this movie because I was with a colleague that wanted to see it. We went to the previous one 'cause it was the only that we haven't seen at that time. We went to this to see if it was really better than BWP and it was. It seemed that the first was only a bate to take us to this, it is the reason of existence for this and for all Blair Witches to come. This film is a imitation of others, but a bad imitation. The mistery around the witch and the cepticism and all that atmosphere of horror is made with demons in "The Irrefutable Truth about Demons", the references to video and comparitions with movie, have been made in all "Scream"s the Blair Witch phenomenon, was created in the net, its supposed to attract people to the site, to the place and above that, to the theatre, this movie is clearly fiction, it lost the "magical" spell, it didn't had the power of the Witch. The blockbuster effect will be lost, before the fifth movie.

reviews.review_title: What one could expect from a sequel
reviews.content: We all know that a sequel is never (or rarely) as good as the original. Sequels are often a stretch of a self-contained story  to make more money.With that in mind, Blair Witch 2 is not all that bad a movie.  Is it scary, not really.  Does it have a sense of suspense and tension.  Yes it does. Admitted that it uses all the old tricks of the book.  Silence building up to a strong musical clash.  Rapid sequence of disrupted images and so on.Lets face it.  This is the best modern movies can do nowadays.  A movie that is meant to be mainstream will rarely be ground-breaking at the same time. Characters are not incredibly interesting but they're not dull either. The actors are a bit inexperienced but everybody has to start somewhere.Is it worth seeing. Yes.  Is it entertaining. Yes.I believe that people who are strongly disappointed by this movie wanted to see the same 'documentary' genre.  Actually, I was pleased to see it was different.  The film-makers tried to make some changes to the original format, and change is often good.This is a nice even 7 out of 10.

After the first Blair Witch Project movie became massively popular, the town of Burkittsville, Maryland has attracted hordes of tourists. Seeking to cash in on the witch mania, a local guy called Jeff (Jeffrey Donovan) arranges a tour in the woods where the movie was made. With him are a goth named Kim (Kim Director), a Wiccan named Erica (Erica Leerhsen) and a researcher couple Tristen and Stephen (Tristine Skyler and Stephen Barker Turner). Soon after setting their camp up in the forest, they start seeing and committing sinister acts and lose their grasp on what is real and what is not.Unlike the first movie, Blair Witch 2 is not a mockumentary, although it utilizes shaky video camera footage a lot. Actually, it's not even a direct sequel as it acknowledges the fictitiousness of the original film right from the beginning while relying on the same mythology. In any case, it's not a very good film. The charm of the first Blair Witch was to NOT show the scary things, and a similar approach would have been better for the sequel too. Now we only get a rather run-off-the-mill horror movie with very unconvincing acting and little sense of building paranoia. The scares are sparse and the non-chronologically advancing plot line frequently robs the story of its tension. I don't think the movie is offensively bad though, so horror fans may enjoy it if nothing better is on.

The First time i saw Blair Witch 2, i thought it was very disturbing, lots of violence, lots of blood. But anyways, it's a very clever and original movie. I don't know why people hated it so much, probably because they didn't understand it. Movies that you understand are boring and predictable. And that is the total opposite of this Blair Witch sequel. Five strangers go into the woods, to go investigate where the original Blair Witch was filmed. There is the goth, the wiccan, the leader and maker of the tour, and a guy and his pregnant girlfriend. After a long night of partying in the woods, the five strangers can't remember anything that happened. The movie becomes confusing, disturbing and unexplainable. I really enjoyed it, the story was very clever and there where some excellent performances by unknown actors. I would give Book Of Shadows:Blair Witch 2, 9/10.

reviews.review_title: Awful movie, but some things in it worth thinking about
reviews.content: The worst thing about this movie, well, it's hard to put a finger on exactly what is the most awful: Direction, acting, writing, it's all uniformly awful. Oh, add to that, casting, characterization, filming, etc. etc. But what makes this movie interesting is not what makes it bad, but the fact that underneath all the awful execution, there's a very good movie just dying to get out. **Spoiler Alert**There's a very original idea here--and in places there's a glimmer of execution that's worthwhile. The idea, and this will be a spoiler so watch out, that individuals can be so taken in by the obsession surrounding an event that they find their own evil. The characters here are silly in the worst way, and in some ways are similar to the original in that they are thoroughly dislikable and stereotypically Gen X, a bigger snooze than any in the last few years: A Goth, a Wiccan, a couple of grungers etc. Awful. But when they go slowly insane trying to reconstruct several lost hours of their lives--and are faced with the reality of events--well, there's something there. Something that, given a decent script, and all the rest, has much to commend it. Don't see this movie--it's garbage. But if you do, I'd suggest trying to ask about the culmination some questions; dig a little deeper past the garbage, there are some nuggets worth finding.

reviews.review_title: A Rough Draft of A Movie
reviews.content: The first Blair Witch brought horror through self fright by three lost individuals driving each other toward insanity.  The appeal of the first film was that it concentrated on that aspect of horror which many horror movie today seemed to have forgotten with the use of CGI special effects. The plot was honest and believable.  The film used the in your face interview of the local's take on the legend of the Blair Witch to convey that mystery which embody the whole Blair Witch quality.Well, in the sequel, the same effects are employed, but it is a complete disaster!  The first interview of the local made me felt that he was putting me on.  Once that tone was set it carry out toward the whole movie.  The movie is saying, " Don't take it too seriously and let us just rehash some of the old stuff and throw in some new stuff that make us look amateurish." In the end, BW2 did not do justice to the first because it is a complete sellout.  You will also know why some films should not see the day of light. This film is definitely too rough to sit in your stomach and will make you puke after the first half hour leaving you with a wanting for some good old fashion Freddie Kreuger one-liners. Yeech!

reviews.review_title: The curse of the sucky sequel strikes again
reviews.content: By Greg UrsicRoger Ebert once compiled a list of a thousand things not to do in a horror movie: don't split up to search for the killer/monster, never go in the basement, etc,.  I don't remember if it's listed, but one of the criteria should be - don't return to the scene of the crime - any camper at Crystal Lake or insomniac living on Elm Street can tell you that.  Someone should have told the witch hunters headed for Burkittsville.The "sequel" opens with snippets of news stories documenting the effect the first movie had on the people of Burkittsville and highlights the fact that it was pure fiction.  Our intrepid travelers - consisting of a Wiccan, a Goth chick, two researchers, and a their recently released mental patient guide- are determined to find out for themselves whether or not there is anything to the legend of the Blair Witch. After a night of binge drinking and drugs, they awake to discover that, small surprise, five hours of their life is missing, but not in the normal god-I'll-never-drink-again-hangover way, but the there's-something-spooky- X-files kind of way.  The question on everyone's mind is what happened."The Blair Witch Project" either scared you stupid or bored you silly, but there's no disputing its success - costing only $30,000, it brought in $200 million plus at the box office.  The marketing for the film was brilliant - extensive prerelease coverage, Internet hype (the website's "Missing" posters, video clips, and legend of the witch drew hundreds of thousands of hits), and its jerky video style, was the ultimate manipulation of the reality tv concept.  The combination worked so well that many people were convinced that the events onscreen actually transpired.  Much to its detriment, "Book of Shadows" dissociates itself from the very conventions that made the original fresh.I'm suspicious of any horror movie that peppers its press release with phrases like "amorphous villains", " general conflation" and "devolving psychological state". "Shadows" demonstrates a classic maxim - a big budget does not necessarily mean a better film.  Although this movie boasts a heavy hitting soundtrack, and is helmed by a talented director (ironically renowned for his skill as a documentary filmmaking) it falls prey to the curse of the sequel.   And how.Plagued by stilted dialogue, a disjointed plot that jumps around needlessly, characters that are pale representations of people and horribly amateurish special effects (the animatronic owl would not have fooled a child) there is little to recommend this movie.  More frustrating is the violence - intended to be shocking, the sequences are poorly filmed and the blood so obviously fake, that the scenes lose any impact they might have had.   The ultimate death knell for  "Shadows" however is that it is guilty of being a horror film that isn't frightening.The only terror you will experience watching this film, is the time you've lost, and sadly you will know exactly what happened.

For anyone who was truly terrified by Blair Witch, you will howl with laughter while you watch this horrible sequel.  It's not scary, it has nothing to do with the original, and the actors couldn't act their way out a paper bag.  Don't be fooled!  Don't pay the eight bucks to see this crap!

reviews.review_title: A waste of a perfectly good $7 and an hour and a half
reviews.content: You know how when you're a little kid you're afraid of the dark and afraid of the bumps in the night?  The Blair Witch project brought me back to that time.  It was scary because it let your imagination mess with your head. You never saw the thing that terrified you and that made it even scarier. Book of Shadows went the opposite direction entirely.  In the first five minutes you've already seen more gore and blood than in the entire original film.  I may have been able to appreciate this movie if only I could have gotten past the excessive (to the point of silly) use of random violence and gore and the HORRIBLE acting.  I couldn't take this movie seriously.  It had no plot, the characters were unbelievable stereotypes, and I left the movie feeling like I had my $7 stolen.  A waste of a perfectly good Friday night. I want my money back.

The sequel is better in its entire than the first movie.  It actually has twists and turns, goes someplace, and is believable.  In the first movie, all the people do is run around like chickens with their heads chopped off, and swear in every other sentence.  Blair Witch 2 had real dialouge and really decent actors to carry the movie along.  7.9 out of 10.

Ok so anyone who doesn't like this movie sucks.  well figurativly speaking. It seems like such a dumb way to start a review but seriously the general american public is so afraid of a film that asks you the audience to actively participate in it. Blair witch 2 definatly matches the original in a totally different way. The originality and creativity that bled into the original from the created legend is some how let loose upon a new concept in this mind bending sequel. The mass hysteria created from the first film invades the real town of Burkitsville. A group of info seekers join a Blair witch tour hosted by an ex mental patient who sells blair witch 'everything' on line.  You see they party hearty and wake up the next morning to a destroyed camp and a group of victims from another camp.  Puzzled by the phenomena, bad events happen one after another as the atmosphere builds to an open conclusion. One in which the director asks you the audience to come up with your own answers. To bad most people just couldn't figure it out. They need everything delivered to them straight forward with no brain work at all. Read between the lines people and discover what the film maker and his art trying to say messages about suggestion, the reality of video, the influence of hollywood, public reaction, prejudice, group hysteria and etc. Finally someone asked The mainstream audience if they could handle figuring something out. To bad the majority anwsered no but for people with half a brain check out this witch, it rocks!

reviews.review_title: Rushed Cash In Sequel Isn't So Bad
reviews.content: I saw this film when it first came out. I was in college in 1999 only 20 miles away from Burkesville MD and so I understand as well as anyone the huge sensation 'The Blair Witch Project' caused. Every weekend about 25% of my college would roam around the Burkesville woods getting drunk and high.Hence, this film really hits home for me. Just as the viewer is forced to be around hung over kids whom spent the night drinking and smoking in the woods, so was a whole year of my college life!
