This is the classic example of a rushed sequel punched out to cash in the original's popularity before the fad wears off ('Sister Act 2' 'Sherk 2' 'Shanghai Knights') without any regard for quality. The studio never cares about quality because the sequel factor alone will guarantee box office success.The major factor here is that ALL FIVE of the characters are just named after the actors playing them! That's how fast this script was punched out! It was literally written ON THE SET! I'll never forget the trailer for this. Usually trailers highlight the major action and money shots of the film. This trailer actually showed a girl dancing on bed. Yup, that's the best shot they could show us to drag us into the theaters! A girl dancing on a bed! This is supposed to be a scary movie right?Anyway, five stoners camp out in the Burkesville woods just like 'The Blair Witch Project.' Scary? I'm always amused at how even respected film critics like Roger Ebert religiously recited 'The Blair Witch Project's promo, "the Black Hills of Maryland" as if somehow it's scary. Burkesville is the suburbs. The suburbs! No one can get lost in someone's backyard! And any "campers" would be arrested for trespassing. It's the suburbs! After a hard night of drinking and drugs the five kids awaken to find their book in progress destroyed by an industrial shredder. They all act surprised at having blacked out as if something scary has happened. Nothing scary has happened! They just passed out drunk! Next, the pregnant girl has a miscarriage. Drinking and drugging will cause that as well. The nurse at the hospital says, "Your body is telling you something's not right." as if it is scary. No, it's just the drinking and drugs! So the five kids go to what's described as an abandoned Civil War factory. WOW! Plumbing, electricity, paint and glass that's held up for 150 years! No wonder the North won the war, they were really advanced. WWII factor we might buy. But Civil War factory? Anyway, the kids watch the tapes of themselves from the night before but find nothing until they're played backwards. OF course you can't really do that because video doesn't work the same as film but whatever. The backwards footage reveals an orgy of drinking and drugs. We already knew about this!!! The kids then go into a trance and wander off to murder an neighboring group of campers. They're so out of their minds that they remember to bring a camcorder with them to capture it for posterity.Next the kids are interrogated by the police in scenes which fail to work as either drama or comedy as ALL the cops are overly acting redneck stereotypes. Again, Burkesville isn't the Deep South. It's the suburbs! Why are ALL the cops inbred rednecks? If the movie isn't going to take these scenes seriously neither is the audience.All in all it is fun for some laughs and not horribly made. It does go down as a classic example of a punched out and rushed cash in sequel.Only one mystery remains. What's the "Book of Shadows?" There are no books or shadows in this film or even mention of them! Again, this leads me to conclude there were multiple studio scripts and rewrites and the film was just slapped together without regard.

The worst film I've seen in five years is this horrid sequel to the frighteningly original Blair Witch Project. This time around a group of teenagers go into the woods to explore the myth of the movie they saw last summer and one morning find themselves wondering why none of them can remember what they all did the night before. It starts off funny, but ends up...actually it doesn't end up anywhere: the movie keeps threatening to get started for ninety minutes and then the credits just roll. Everything that was scary by way of suggestion in the first film is given away here in full frontal graphics that destroy all mystery and excitement.

reviews.review_title: A big pair of pants and smelly ones too
reviews.content:
Studio artisan try to turn the clever,suggestive and low budget shocker the blair witch project in to a blockbusting franchise with tragic not to mention hillarious consequences. A half interesting idea is ruined by a director not used to making proper films and a novice cast.
One star out of five

reviews.review_title: i liked this one better than the first one!
reviews.content: now if you didnt read the first one i wrote for the first witch, then great. i gave this a little higher because the movie was visible, and the cast had me baffled and i understood a little part of the movie.  although the thought of the kids going back there to the same spot as the others is outrageous, i didnt understand why on earth they didnt make a prequel to it, like show what happened to the witch to make her so evil, and explain why she lives in those particular woods. good try, though but it was overall boring, but the music helped which increased the 2 from the first one, and gained one point which gave my vote a 3.  (D- F+)

I've seen both, Blair Witch and Book of Shadows : Blair Witch 2, all i can say is that the previous movie was more scary but not as entertaining as the 2nd part, i really enjoy watching BW2, every time i play it i can't go anywhere until it ends, it's really entertaining and it's fun, maybe not scary but it really has some meaning and connection between the Blair Witch and Burkitsville phenomenons, it explains widely what happens to the persons involved in the Blair Witch cult, and i'm glad i have this in my DVD collection as i really appreciate this film and i think it's really good, it deserves a 10 stars ranking in my opinion, that's all i can say.

This is a fascinating follow up to the horribley unscary original, which benefits nicely this time around from  much more interesting characters. The Goth girl was my personal favorite. She didn't take anyone's you know what.Not a sequel in the true sense of the word, but more like another chapter, with a highly chilling ending. Even if you saw it coming, it's still rather creepy. Give it a look for something different.

How come everyone that LOVED the first BLAIR WITCH absolutely HATES this one with so much passion?  Because it ruined everything that made the first so great!  Acting?  sucked.  Writing?  sucked.  Movie?  sucked.  The only reason I'm not giving it a vote of 1 is because that freaky little shaking girl was kinda scary.  This movie was trying much too hard to be scary and it so didn't work.  Maybe if it was edited differently (the going back and forth and the flashbacks were way too out-of-place), and maybe if the expectations weren't so high for a repeat the movie might have been better. But Artisan put it out assuming the first one made a lot of money because it was good (I personally LOVED IT!!), but the fact is it made a heap of dough because of the hype.  People went to see to see what everyone was talking about, and they ended up hating it, so no one went to see a sequel. Although the people that HATED the first one, LOVE part 2.  What's up with that?

reviews.review_title: Further Proof That The Horror Film Is D-E-A-D
reviews.content: MORD39 RATING:  0   out of  ****Man, even though I'm only in my thirties I feel like an 80-year-old fossil when I continually berate these new "horror" duds. The first BLAIR WITCH PROJECT was successful for me because it managed to be unsettling in a very "simple" and "creative" manner. I seldom bother seeing new horror films anymore, but I broke my rule one more time for this atrocious piece of garbage...As with practically ALL new horror movies, the first few minutes make you think that the filmmakers are going to try something special, but then your expected disappointments come crashing in FAST. Next comes the unnecessary heavy metal (or rap) music, and then a young and aggravating cast of hateful teens are introduced and are so despicable that you pray they'll get killed.Love the intelligence of our 21st century teens in this script; their dialogue is sprinkled with the usually carefree helpings of "s..t," "f..k," "d..k", etc...etc... And they speak in those annoying lingos: "yeah, like, I mean...dude...like..." Heaven Help Us.Once again we've got our MTV camerawork spinning and flashing, zooming in and out. God knows we've got no story, so I guess something has to stimulate an audience. What the hell is supposed to be happening in this movie? I can't tolerate an endless barrage of illusions and images that fail to add anything except to make me more confused. This film makes absolutely NO SENSE AT ALL.When it was over, it was forgotten...just like a bad meal. In years to come, NOBODY will remember it (like 99% of all modern horror bombs).Which brings me to a comparison regarding the re-release of THE EXORCIST. Now there's a classic made about 30 years ago with strong characters with personality and problems. There were shock sequences, to be sure, but they all had a purpose. I am astonished at how many "lost" young people today cannot see the greatness of EXORCIST, yet I'm sure those same 21st century kids will enjoy the "cool rock soundtrack" for BLAIR WITCH 2 (and think that it constitutes a great horror film). Oh, well...what can we expect today when a film from 2000 has the "normal" kids swearing and raving more than the possessed little girl of THE EXORCIST ever did??? Boy, are we over!!I'd love to know the kid who thinks this is a good film, and who simultaneously hates the academy award nominated EXORCIST!

reviews.review_title: A CONCEPT FILM<>AND BETTER THAN THE ORIGINAL
reviews.content: More of a concept movie than an actual horror movie, this underrated sequel to the highly overrated "Blair Witch Project" is a joy to watch. Spooky, suspenseful and thought-provoking - much better than the dull and over-reaching original.

I never commented on the first film. Not because I didn't like it. I did. I thought it was very unique and entertaining. I guess I just never found the time to comment on it...so there's my comment on it. Now on to the sequel. Why do they do this? Why do they allow people to mess up a good thing with garbage? This, like so many sequels, is just a prime example of production companies trying to capitalize on the success of a very good first movie. Unfortunately, Myrick and Sanchez are primarily to blame for this extremely sub par mess. For some reason they felt that they didn't have the time to direct or write this one, and so they hired Berlinger, a very good documentary composer, but not the right choice for BW2. It was as if they only had a rough draft, but felt hurried to release a sequel, and so ultimately just stuck with the rough draft. And the characters...I mean who can really truly say that they actually cared about these people? That was what was so heartbreaking about the original; you actually cared about them and felt their fear. Not so in this one. And the acting was very inconsistent. At times the acting was pretty good and somewhat convincing, and at other times it was very shallow. All in all, this was a very disappointing sequel.

Using a style close to Romero's "Living Dead" trilogy timeline, "Book Of Shadows" uses the first film as a springboard and offers up a surprisingly good story, with more plot twists and turns than the most clever whodunit.Director Joe Berlinger and his five unknowns (Kim Director, Jeffrey Donovan, Erica Leerhsen, Tristin Skyler, Stephen Barker Turner) create a wonderful sense of atmosphere, fear and hysteria when a "Blair Witch" tour of the famous Black Hills of Maryland leads to a forgotten five hours of time, in which the characters have no recollection of what happened. 
As they frantically research videotapes of the night before, it becomes clear that a supernatural force has controlled them, but who has it actually controlled?This film is surprisingly well done and if you can overcome the annoying soundtrack, the storyline quickly becomes far too engrossing to pass up. Like Romero's "Dead" trilogy, this film acknowledges the one before but takes new events and new spins on the material.  The Blair Witch is present in this one as she was in the first, but instead of being searched for, she takes on the role of predator...using these young people for whatever purpose she sees fit.The connection to the first film was clearly both a help and a hinderance to this one, as some fans expected more of the same while others simply shyed away because of the "Blair Witch" name.  This film can hold it's own in either part of this trilogy or a stand alone.Don't buy into the negative reviews and give "Book Of Shadows" a watch, you might just come out of it as surprised as I did.3 1/2 out of 5

A little over a year ago a monumental and different horror film was released: The Blair Witch Project.  Now we have Book of Shadows, a poor, weak, and meaningless sequel to the masterpiece.  I thought the Blair Witch only struck every 60 years, well only a few years after the original film is released which has started a Blair Witch revolution and put the small town of Burketsville on the map.  A group of Blair Witch hunters are led into the woods by a former mental patient Jeff Patterson, on what he has advertised as "The Blair Witch Hunt."  After a night of alcohol and drug induced frenzy the group awake missing five hours of their lives with their footage of the previous day and all documentation about the witch destroyed.  As the movie goes into detail about what happened during those missing five hours we discover that these people did not leave the woods alone. 
Writer/Director Joe Berlinger the man behind the great documentary "Paradise Lost" attempts to make the viewer question reality and to make us feel a sense of the insanity that the characters feel, but after an hour of the movie the question I was repeatedly asking myself was "Why?"  And by the end I was completely disgusted.  The film is empty of substance and unlike the original is completely unbelievable and lacks the sense of frenzy and suspense that the original brilliantly produced.  No story, no plot, and completely worthless.  Like the original, unknown actors were cast in the leads and for the most part do a good job, but pale in comparison to the original three.  The only actor I recognized was the sheriff who is responsible for the worst acting in the movie.  The acting can't save the script, if there was one.  The "script" and I use that word loosely was probably banged out overnight to try and cash in on the heat of the original.  I look forward to the prequel, but lets just pretend Book of Shadows just didn't happen, I'm sure the filmmakers will.

reviews.review_title: A rare kind of cinematic disaster.
reviews.content: A formula for a movie this bad only comes around a few times, and it should definitely be studied and observed to prevent future tragedies of it's kind.What happens when a studio wants to cash in on a wildly successful movie but can't get the original director? Then hires someone known only for making documentaries with no experiencing directing narrative-driven fiction? And that director doesn't even like the first movie? And then that director makes the exact opposite of the movie they want out of pure spite for them and original film?You get a cinematic 30-car pileup like "Book of Shadows." Whereas the first film was a fake documentary that showed a group of people fall to pieces in a realistic situation and at the end only hinted at something supernatural, Book of Shadows is a more generic horror movie that makes no attempt to seem like a documentary at all. Staffed by a team of insufferable, banal characters with no interesting or redeeming qualities. They are all apparently based on people who all serve as a metaphor for the people "effected" by the first film, like Wiccans, Goths and people who thought the movie was real. The director put so much thought into what they were supposed to represent, he forgot all about how to make them compelling character in the actual film.The movie is laden with subtext and hidden meaning, but that doesn't justify it's existence. Now, not only is the film a mindless, generic, incoherent and totally unentertaining mess, it's also extremely pretentious and smugly satisfied with itself. Like an especially dimwitted dog who takes a poop on your carpet because he's mad at you and grins at you like he actually accomplished something. But at the end, you're going to have to clean the carpet, he has to sleep outside, and nobody won here.One half of this film is motivated by greed, the other half is motivated by wrath. You put the two together and it's like mixing nerve gas, everyone in the room dies horribly.The director apparently blames the studio in some regard for the movie's poor reception due to the heavy editing they did. But honestly? Even just from watching the footage that actually made it into the film, it's easy to see there wasn't much to salvage.It's rare to see a film that's cheap cash grab AND insanely pretentious, but Book of Shadows pulls it off. It's one of my top ten worst movies of all time.And no, "Book of Shadows" doesn't mean anything.

This movie was way too expected for it to be cool,i mean,a lot of people knew about the hoax they played on the first one and some of them were not happy about it,some people didn´t even get the first one, so the idea of a sequel sounded good (For the movie company) to get some more money while the blair witch was hot but people were not buying into it again. The new premise promises to scare people away by telling a new story in wich the dark forces of the woods really exist and attack a group of blair witch fans, was this idea too desperate or what,i mean,did they really think people were gonna go and get scared at this movie,It´s sad to see a good premise go down so fast but hey ¡That´s Showbusiness! This film sadly doesn´t build up any suspense or tension enough to keep people awake,I liked it but i am a big fan of the genere and a true Blair Witch fan from the first movie so i have to appreciate a sequel,not as the original but at least like it and show some compassion for the effort they made on making it,even if they sucked at it on making it. I´ll give it a sad 7 out of 10 on horror in the woods movie.

Well Blair Witch 2 is certainly not what i had expected!  I was so eager to see it and i at least was hoping for a scary movie, but boy was i dissapointed.  The movie comes off as more of a suspense film in which you could be intrigued by the plot rather than scared.  The movie definately wasnt horrible in my opinion, but thats my opinion and i bet 9 out of 10 people will probably beg to differ.  Mostly in part because the whole movie was COMPLETELY CONFUSING!!  I might of been the only person in the entire theater that had an idea about what was happening (because certainly my date had no clue!).  The constant flashbacks and forshadowing of events can certainly boggle ones mind.  But...  it was somewhat inventive, at least it wasnt exactly the same as the first movie!  For the fan of Blair Witch you should probably check it out, but if you didnt care for the first movie, or are looking for something scary, stay clear from this one and dont waste your time!  Just my opinion and of course i could be wrong. :)

If 'The Blair Witch Project' redefined everything we knew about horror, then 'Blair Witch Two' clarified everything we know about sequels. Mainly, they're a bit s**t. Or, in the case of 'Book of Shadows' they're all s**t. Other reviewers have said it, but I think it's worth repeating. 'Book of Shadows' is the MTV version of 'The Blair Witch Project' They took all the qualities of the original and injected it with retarded ness. What resulted is a film so caked in `The 90s' that it stops being a horror film and ends up being a derelict. There is absolutely nothing to fear from this movie. The atmosphere is foreboding horror is totally absent. Instead, we are treated to CGI! Wow, a CGI ghost. Can you think of anything less effective? In some ways it's like comparing the two 'Haunting's. One, with an atmosphere so thick you could cut it with a knife despite the fact you NEVER SEE anything, and the other so overdone with OTT CGI it ceases to be anything more than laughable. In fact, they're similar in a lot of ways. Didn't the 90s Haunting have the giant purple ink stain in it? Or was that 'The House on Haunted Hill'? Either way, my point still stands. 'Book of Shadows' has a bunch of stereotypical teenagers go out in to the Blair woods. They all fall asleep, or something, and when they awake they have no idea what's happened. Of course, as logic dictates, they've had an orgy in the middle of the forest and this revelation is only discovered when they play their video tapes backwards. What the hell? That about sums up my review. Basically they took the premise of the original and realized that to squeeze more juice out of it they needed a sequel. But sadly it seems they listened to all those idiots who moaned about `there wuz no ghost u dindt see nething it sux0r lololol' and all that kind of nonsense and what resulted is this. Three out of ten. If you want to see a scary film, watch 'The Blair Witch Project' If you want a comedy, watch 'Airplane' If you want the equivalent of a coca-cola enema, watch 'Book of Shadows'

The previous film had its charm because of the footage. Not so here and the film is shot on classic camera angles. Moreover, when it comes to some camera shots, they have a kind of blue filter, which in my opinion just spoils it. The music is also rather inappropriate in places, in my opinion. As far as the plot is concerned, it's kind of... weird. On the one hand, it had its good moments, but unlike the last episode, where I was like "WOW, that was something" after the ending. I was like, "What the hell?" In my eyes, a completely unnecessary sequel that I recommend avoiding, and I don't recommend the movie itself.

In the end, I was surprised by this movie. Of course, BWP was scary as hell, although a bit vague in its approach. BW2 is even more so. In the end, it was a bit gratifying to learn the secret, but getting there was a pain.The hallucinations are too much and very annoying at times. The plot is too simple and the execution and pacing is sloppy. My favorite character may have well been Kim, the goth chick. She's the most interesting to me and I actually cared what happened to her. Other than that, there's not much to like. The film is too vague and avoiding for its own good. It doesn't want to face the evil it created and just winds up going around it. SPOILER ALERT The film is just so predictable, and at times, too obvious. For example: the bridge that's the "only" way in or out. We all know, without having to see the trailer, that the bridge will collapse. And the dog alarm, the real dogs show up. The guy goes to get a gun, and presto, the dogs are gone. I knew they would be. This film breaks no new ground, and is not at all scary. Stick with the first.

I loved Blair Witch and have watched it many times. This sequel was promising in the beginning but swiftly became atrocious. The artificial lighting editing and acting contrasts vividly with the original. Movies have suffered in the past from "theatrical" acting, but movies appear to be evolving in such a way that heavily artificial movies like this suffer from being "movieistic". And that coyness of the "nude wicca" still wearing her panties and with her hair obviously glued to her breasts to hide her nipples! This was clearly for a quite different market than Blair Witch, perhaps for people who enjoyed Scream 3. There is naturally a certain cynicism involved in making sequels to "horror movies" but there was something almost immoral in this exploitation of the original movie and of a potential audience. Perhaps the makers were sincere and it's easy to lose one's way in the woods. But I have rarely seen a movie so deserving of the oblivion that it is surely nose-diving into. Every movie has its audience though, and perhaps one will turn up. For myself, I think it will be a healthy thing all round if it loses a lot, a lot of money. I liked the final credits though and the soundtrack is great, one is less likely to be disappointed by the film CD.....

reviews.review_title: The movie that should NOT have been made...
reviews.content: Why, why, oh WHY are we subjected to such c***!?!?!?!  What did we do to deserve such a "sequel"??? I was sooooo psyched to see this movie, especially since every other "horror" movie this year has been HORRID.  I NEVER tell movie plots and this time you should be thankful, as I don't quite think I could explain it anyway.  Remember all those terrible plot HOLES in Jurassic Park 2?  They've surfaced here...stupid things like a couple going upstairs to bed...but then there is a knock at the door and the guy only has but to walk a few feet to open the door to outside...HE WAS UPSTAIRS!!!!!!!!  I pray that we are not subjected to a third of these...as I'm not even going to count this a being related to the Blair Witch Project...why tarnish a film's image?  It was the last film that scared me...and I fear with the sort of horror movies in 2000...it is the LAST film to scare me...Trust in me...Stay in and read the website...it is cheaper AND scarier...

reviews.review_title: This film left me so confused 😵😵
reviews.content: Ive watched the 1st blair witch was good and fresh then 1 night i saw this film and to be honest it was ok very very confusing and nothing close to number 1 seemed that they shouldnt called it blair witch 2 but im still glad i watched it not the best but not the worse . Enjoy 😵😵

reviews.review_title: why are people not getting it?
reviews.content: I have seen both movies and i loved it. The problem with second movie is that most of the people don't liked the idea of the whole played with their mind stuff, to me it was wonderful and simply original. We are talking about a witch here what do you expect? spells? messing with their minds and altering their psyche was something i never seen before. Witches do not come and eat you or give you stupid scares is that's what you were expecting? Instead they f*** your mind up and you wish you rather kill yourself instead of being in spell...that's f******* scary.sorry for my bad English

of course this was going to receive bad hype. it is the sequel to one of the most popular and highest grossing independent films of all time. that is why people do not like it. it is not so much a sequel as it is a movie that was inspired by the blair witch project, i guess you could say, or maybe a re enactment of something that really happened after the release of the blair witch project. but it is a GOOD movie. the original was great, but this one is too. i am not going to say one is better than the other, just that you should watch them separately to like the 2nd one more, because it is nothing like the first. it is scary though. really scary. and here is a plus, erica leerhsen is in it(and is naked for those of you who care, i watch it for her acting talent and she is hot). and kim director is hot as the goth chick. so, all in all, this is a cool movie. if you like both, get that blair witch experience box set. it has both movies, a cool game, and a necklace of that weird blair witch stick sh*t, but i would advise you not to wear it in public. anyway, rent this movie at least, it kills all of the halloween sequels(except for 3 because the original and 3 are sooooooooooooo awesome and the rest are dumb and most have nothing to do with the REAL michael myers that carpenter created. moustapha akkad sucks, many people have bad opinions of michael because of him whereas if he had made the original, made 3 part 2, then more people would recognize michael for what he is, a creepy shadow stalker, not another jason or angela baker(these guys are great, but michael is better as a shadow stalker). but whatever.ANYWAY, blair witch 2 is cool, i don't know why they call it book of shadows, but it is cool, and so is the first one. no more sequels please. recommend: tourist trap, jack frost, Texas chainsaw massacre(original and remake), the burning, terror train, EVERYTHING HORROR!!!!!!!!!!!
The movie isn't that bad, but the acting... is cartoonish and over the top

reviews.review_title: Don't waste your time. The first one was way better...
reviews.content:
"Blair Witch 2" just couldn't decide what kind of movie it was.  Was it a slasher horror flick? Was it a psychological thriller? Was it supposed to be a serious look at the persecution of modern day witches and Goth kids? Maybe it was supposed to be all these things, and ended up being none of these things.All we had here was a movie that tried to be clever, but didn't have very much to say.  Horror fans will be greatly disappointed with this installment in the "Blair Witch" series.  The first one was honestly creepy and cleverly done.  This one just laid there like a bored hooker. It went on WAY too long and had only a few scares that consisted mostly of breaking windows. 
We still didn't get a good look at the witch and we didn't even get a good look at the murders that took place during the film.  All we get is a bunch of artsy footage that leaves us confused at best...and knowing in advance how the movie was going to end.  In fact, the end was ruined by the sheer fact that we already knew what was going to happen.The only character that made this movie even remotely worthwhile was Kim. She made a lasting impression with her portrayal of the resident "goth chick."  The movie should have focused more on her character.  Her sexy black look was the only really interesting thing in the movie. C-

reviews.review_title: I Knew This Was Going to Happen!
reviews.content:
Why is it that every time a horror film makes any money the creative vision of that film gives way to a sequel involving typical film making techniques that the absence of were the very reasons the original was so original in the first place?  Halloween gave us Halloween II.  A Nightmare on Elm Street gave us Freddy's Revenge.  These aren't sequels, they are desecrations.For me, the Blair Witch Project worked.  I saw it after the hype was firmly established and while it was what I expected it somehow still managed to get under my skin and stay there for a long time.  This film, with it's bloated, unnecessary contemporary soundtrack and by the numbers direction was exactly what I didn't expect and I left the theater feeling cheated.  The film starts off promising, managing to poke a little fun at itself without being too self aware.  There's a couple references to the original films critics via characters who are walking around the woods claiming they "just want to see something."  After the promising first few moments, the film seems to slowly fall apart.  I think some of the individual parts of the film work very well, but the film as a whole seems less than the sum of it's parts.
What exactly is the film trying to express?  It is an indictment on modern day "witch hunts" in which people who embrace alternative religions and/or dress in black are really good people that society prejudges as evil?  Does the sheriff in the film serve as conservative ideology against the younger generation who engage in behavior he just can't understand and therefore labels it as wrong or even immoral?  Given the directors documentary history, it seems natural that the film would use the idea of a witch hunt to show that things haven't changed much since the Salem witch trials of 1692.  The Wiccan character even says that the first film sent back the cause of witchcraft (as a religion) 300 years.  By the end of the film I was just confused.  I'm not sure that the film didn't show witch hunters as sympathetic, thereby giving the prejudice an excuse.Remember the first Nightmare on Elm Street?  It was very effective in 1984, the time of it's original release.  By 1991 we were given Freddy's Dead-The Final Nightmare.  Supposedly they took the little independent low budget film and supplied it with a budget and true Hollywood talent and each installment came was no where near as effective as the first.  It seems the lesson was not learned and we will be forced to see sequels of this merit.
It's not just the fact that sequels are generally inferior that is my point here.  Two guys with some equipment purchased at electronics store make an original horror film-no matter how you felt about The Blair Witch Project it was different and they took a chance.  Now Hollywood has it's hands on the franchise and have rendered it unrecognizable.  I will go see the third Blair Witch project where the producers will undoubtedly try to correct what went wrong here, but I fear, while already low, my expectations will most likely be confirmed.

I fail to understand the Book-of-Shadows-loving minority. First, there is the complaint that this movie is unfairly compared to the original Blair Witch -- HELLO!! ITS CALLED BLAIR WITCH 2!! They are giving the impression that this movie is a continuation of the first (for example, that it would be scary or suspenseful)....it is natural to expect similarities to the first movie. Second, why do some people assume that when someone doesn't like it, that it must be because they don't get it? I think we all get it....we just don't care because we don't find it scary/entertaining. But I guess one person's trash is another's treasure. You have to admit that this film was poorly made (lack of history, lack of plot development, too many missed opportunities -- like with the kids in the street) which just doesn't help at all, and yeah, that owl was real fake.

I think we have found a winner for the worst movie ever made!!! I know that there is a trend for horror movies to be poorly made or made with ridiculous plots, but this movie tops 'em all. Why does it fail so miserably? Because -- nothing happens!!!!! This was not a scary movie. This was not a suspenseful movie. It was not creative, mysterious, illuminating, terrifying, startling or even funny. No emotion. You never care about what has happened, or what will happen cause you start to get the idea -- nothing happens! Do not see this movie -- I wish I had been given such advice before I saw this miserable film. It's really that bad.

Blair Witch was great, scary in the finest sense - your own imagination. Blair Witch 2 was absolutely terrible - such a waste of a potentially good project.  I suppose that having read the publicity notices, etc., all of the suspense was missing from this one.  It looked staged, there was no sense of "In Search Of" or "History's Mysteries" type of documentary to this one.

One giant plot hole after another is how you can accurately describe "Blair Witch 2" that is a non-sequel followup to the original.  Five film students obsessed with the Blair Witch legend go up to the woods where the incident supposedly occurred. As a result, there are many twists and turns that happens to this group that turns out for the worst. Truly bad, it seems like they tossed a bunch of scenes in a movie and slapped them together sloppily. It's really bad and you'll leave the theater asking yourself "What the f*ck happened here?" because that's an accurate description of this movie. Don't bother spending $3.50 to rent this.

reviews.review_title: I still can't figure out what a 'Book of Shadows' has to do with anything....
reviews.content: Only slightly more annoying than folks who jump on a movie's bandwagon are folks who go out of their way to trash a very good to decent flick as being "absolutely the worst, most awful, horrible, terrible piece of trash ever put on the silver screen" for no reason other than that they can't be reasonable about such things. For two prime examples of both phenomena, (see also: Star Wars Episode 1) we have 'The Blair Witch Project' and 'Book of Shadows: Blair Witch 2'. Neither is 'Citizen Kane', but they both certainly have something to recommend them. 'The Blair Witch Project' can never be recreated. It was a one-time marvel, wildly innovative in its way, and the scariest movie I've ever seen in my life to boot. 'TBWP' is all about what you can't see, but are afraid is there. This annoyed some people something fierce, as they certainly couldn't be expected to exercise a little imagination, now could they? Others, like me, saw it as the 90s' single blow for true psychological terror. Furthermore, it has believable characters. Heather, Mike and Josh talk like every college kid I've ever known, including me. And *you never know*. Was there really a Blair Witch? Did those three ill-fated campers actually even die? Who the hell put Heather's footage at the foundation, anyway? I remember sitting in the theater watching the last 5-10 minutes of 'TBWP' and feeling like my fiercely pounding heart was pumping icicles through my bloodstream. I flinch at a jump scene like everyone else and grimace at gore, but sitting in a theater, surrounded by friends, I felt for the first and last time *real, creeping fear* when I myself was not in danger. Of course, shortly thereafter, the media couldn't stop yapping about a movie that had been talked about for months in the independent film industry. It's ultra-creepy web site was getting a gazillion hits a day, and 'TBWP' was an Event, voted 'Movie of the Summer'- over Star Wars, no less- by several publications. The point of all this rambling about 'TBWP' in a review ostensibly for its sort-of sequel is necessary, as the one aspect of this second film *is* the reaction to the first- and it is also necessary to look at the aftermath of the original movie to understand reactions to this one. At the end you still 'don't know' what happened.  'BW2' is not as scary, funny, believable or innovative as the original. It's got nudity, sex and tons of blood, none of which the original stooped to- although the blood-letting flashbacks were put in at the studio's insistence. The performances- though not groan-worthy- are not as good, some of the characters not as interesting. Erica and Kim- who bears a middling resemblance to Rose McGowan- are both gorgeous, and they are at least fairly interesting. Jeff comes off as useless, but you can understand his position, and the 'normal couple' is simply boring. 4 of these actors- all except Erica- have worked before, although for one- Stephen- this was a first movie role. All are relative unknowns, but most of them have parts in upcoming flicks, and any talk of their careers ending here is just malicious b.s. on the part of the anti-bandwagoneers. Any assertion that the box-office failure of 'BW2' shows that most people hated the first after being 'tricked' by the hype into seeing it is strictly inaccurate- I didn't see it in the theaters, not because I hated the first but because I didn't have time and I was sick of the *hype* itself. There is a subtle but important difference. What we have here is a movie that tries to be independent of the first- it's relative lack of artistic and structural ties to that movie being one of its best assets, as it avoids most sequel cliches- and it's a decent effort on it's own merit. The problem is that it can't be seen as an independent movie with its own merit in the eyes of the general movie-going public. If it didn't have 'Blair Witch 2' as part of it's title, half the people who have posted reviews here wouldn't have done so, and those reviews that remained would not have been so adamant. This is not a movie worth getting *that* worked up about. It is, however, worth a rental.

reviews.review_title: The worst horror film I have ever seen....
reviews.content: I was watching Blair Witch II on TV.  I absolutely hated it.  The plot was extremely confusing, the title made no sense, there was  brainless carnage, and a lousy ending.  The whole movie made no sense whatsoever. All I could piece together was a bunch of kids getting stoned, turning on each other, and saying "That's not how it happened" at the end of the movie.  Blair Witch II is a pathetic film with a poorly thought story.  AVOID AT ALL COSTS.

reviews.review_title: Lives up to it's horrible reputation
reviews.content: How could a sequel The Blair Witch Project ever live up to the original. Well, it can't, and this film is proof. I put off watching this movie for eighteen years as i suspected it would be pale in comparison to the original, but I had not idea it would be this bad. At only nine minutes in, you already know just what kind of one dimensional cliche characters you are in for and the general mind numbing soundtrack that accompanies the truly worst dialog and acting that your gag reflex starts to kick in. You've seen this type of film many, many times.One review I read claims that viewers that do not like it, just don't "get it". Well, let me tell you, this is definitely the type of movie that no one needs to "get". Mother, Hereditary, Antichrist, The Killing of a Sacred Deer, Enemy, those are movies that might be able to make that claim, but surely not this garbage of a film.

Blair Witch 2 is by far different from the original movie. There are very new characters, an unusual movie plot, and the same settings from the first movie.The Blair Witch Project has been a hit in theatres. This makes civilians from all over the world come visit the little town of Burkitsville, Maryland. After mental patient Jeff Paterson (Jeffrey Donovan) is released from the hospital, he moves back to Maryland where he begins a tour guide called the Blair Witch Hunt. His first tour is a group of misfits including Stephen Turner and his girlfriend Tristin, Erika Geheersen who is a witch, and Kim Director who is a gothic punk with a pathetic life. They begin their tour by going up to the Black Forest where the film students dissapeared. It starts out like a fun time. They get drunk, have sex, and basically party their heads off. By morning, they don't remember a thing that they did the night before. So, they head over tho Jeff's house which is an abandoned factory. They decide to look at the footage that they shot and see if they can develop any clues whats so ever. Accusations fly by, eriee clues come, and they put the pieces together on the tape and discover the unexpected of their evening. Produced by Eduardo Sanchez and Daniel Myrick (The Blair Witch Project) and directed by Joe Berlinger. Blair Witch 2 is a fair sequel.

reviews.review_title: the blair witch made me see this movie.
reviews.content: i woke up in the movie theater parking lot yesterday, and couldn't account for 2 hours of my life.  i keep having these horrible visions that i saw "blair witch 2: book of shadows".  good thing they don't have surveillance tapes of me dancing naked on the concession stand... or do they? aaaahhhhhhhhhh!

If you want to see a better filmed movie with characters without the personalities of rocks, with the same ending that this movie COPIED, but filmed 100% better, save your time and money and rent Nightmare (a.k.a. Scissors, a.k.a. Gawi). When watching that extraordinary film I noticed one little thing... the Blair Witch Project 2 used the same ending. Thanks for ruining great films for me, Joe Berlinger. U.S. directors, please stop ripping stuff off of Korean horror. Thank you. Otherwise, this movie had some good points..for instance the graveyard girl looks pretty. And the ending was a shocking twist. Even though it is from another movie.

I must admit, I love this movie. You really have to see between the lines to understand the concept of it. Book of Shadows: Blair Witch 2 is the most bizzare movie I have seen. I own it it's so good. My take is 9/10. This movie isn't as bad as the critics review it. If you watch it over and over (like it did: try approx. 14 times since January 2001) you'll eventually understand the plot. I recommend you rent it.My MPAA rating: R for bizzare, seemingly non-stop gruesome violent images, strong sexuality and language, and for drug/alcohol use.

reviews.review_title: Not as bad as people are saying
reviews.content: Wow, buzz about this movie is so bad. That's kind of ridiculous. It's like once one critic says a movie is bad every other one does and says the exact same reasons. I wonder how many critics read Roger Ebert's reviews and then copy them changing the words around while saying exactly the same things. Blair Witch 2 is not nearly as good as the original which was incredibally creative, however, it is far from terrible. It is creative in its own way which means it does have some really cool elements. ofcoarse, along with those, there are plenty of stupid moments like quick halucinations that are a waste of time, or even worse, when they cut to images of bodies getting cut up. This stuff is not scary, but stupid. However, the movie does get interesting as these five or six characters can't remember what they did and try to figure it out. I often felt like if they took ideas just a little further they could have been really cool and scary, but they didn't. I don't think these guys really knew how to make a horror movie, which is exactly the opposite of the way I feel about the team that made the first one. Don't get me wrong, Blair Witch 2 is not a waste. It does have cool ideas, but it just isn't as great as I would have liked it to be. The ending is really interesting and it is a decent movie. Worth seeing.

reviews.review_title: Not as terrible as some would have it, but not so good either
reviews.content: Wafer-thin all around, extremely clever on occasion, and rather annoying much of the time, Blair Witch 2 is not a complete waste of your time and money, but it's far from a fulfilling horror experience.I have to admire the decision to deliver a real movie this time; that is, shot on real film with real lighting, and a script and so forth.  However, the results are mixed.  The first half-hour is near-brilliant in its documenting of the effect of the release of the first film on the weary citizens of Burkitsville, who are sick of the tourists who've flocked in to see "the home of the Blair witch".  There are great scenes of tour groups flocking through the sparse forests in such abundance that they run into each other.Once the plot, such as it is, settles in, any sense of purpose inherent in the setup goes south in a hurry.  The characters are depressingly undeveloped, acting more as mouthpieces for their various points-of-view than as believable people.  An hour of hearing the Wiccan moan about the general perception of witches made me long for her inevitable demise.The main problem here is the story.  Hitting you with a constant barrage of "did that happen or didn't it?", the narrative retroactively cancels events and then reinstates them with such rapidity that you eventually come to the conclusion that none of it really matters, and disengage from the movie. It's like a season of the X-Files condensed into two hours.  The ending is intended to be an ambiguous lady-or-the-tiger style question, but since neither possibility has really been adequately explained, you're unlikely to care.  There are some good creepy moments here, but in the end, they're buried under a story that's impossible to care about.

starring: Jeffrey Donavan, Kim Director, Stephen Barker Turner,Erica Leershen, and Tristine Skyler.plot: A guy who just got out of the mental institution, Jeff (Jeffrey Donavan) runs a tour group to see the blair witch. He takes Kim (Kim Director), a psychic who thought the original movie was cool, Erica (Erica Leershen), a wiccan who wants to communicate with Ellie Kedward (the blair witch), and two authors, Stephen (Stephen Barker Turner) and Tristen (Tristine Skyler) who are writing a book about the blair witch to the black hills. But they black out, when they wake up all their materials were wrecked and their research was ripped up. Then, Tristen has a misscarrage. Still wanting to go on the tour, they stay at Jeff's place. In his home/store they begin seeing strange hallucinations and some disappear. Erica says that they brought something back with them from the woods ...reveiw: Book of Shadows: Blair Witch 2 is nothing like part 1. The Blair Witch Project was very scary. But Book of Shadows is just weird, in a cool way. The ending was cool to. My favorite character is Kim, she is hot, gothic, and nice, everything I look for in a woman! Jeff is also a cool character, I just hate it that we dont know why he was in the nut house. And Erica was also hot. Every actor does well, especially Kim Director and Jeffrey Donavan. I love the quick creepy shots.10/10.

Book of Shadows: Blair Witch 2 is nothing like part 1. The Blair Witch Project was very scary. But Book of Shadows is just weird. The ending was cool to. My favorite character is Kim, she is hot, gothic, and nice, everything I look for in a woman! Jeff is also a cool character, I just hate it that we dont know why he was in the nut house. And Erica was also hot. Every actor does well, especially Kim Director and Jeffrey Donavan. I love the quick creepy shots. All of the characters have weird hallucinations, SPOILERS AHEAD!!, Kim sees Jeff being electrocuted, Jeff sees Kim eating an owl, Erica and Stephen share a hallucination where they start to have sex but then Erica cuts Stephen's stomach open, and Tristen has nightmares where she drowns her baby in cold water, and later in the movie the baby freezes when it is still inside of her! END OF SPOILERS!! I also like the scenes where Jeff has flashbacks of being in the nut house. If you want a weird horror film with cool images and hot girls, then see Book of Shadows: Blair Witch 2.

Alright, to start with, I'll go on record as saying I enjoyed the original movie. That's important for a moment's time.I think the best way of describing this movie is that the producers took Blair Witch, and remade the movie to appeal to the MTV generation.What do I mean by that? Well, the first movie had a very deliberate style of horror. It was rooted in the grainy realism of the whole thing, which felt so realistic because of how the movie was produced (most of the time, the actors weren't acting, they genuinely WERE so scared). The horror was not about what you could see, but what you COULDN'T see.Of course, in today's fast-food quick-fix world, subtlety like that just doesn't sell. The original movie The Haunting was a genuine classic, a horror movie based entirely around sound. The remake was a CG special FX-laden snorefest without the slightest scare. This movie is much the same thing. It seems that people today don't want horror, they want to see a big ugly computer-rendered monster on screen ripping people apart. The first movie had none of that, so when it had been hyped up, everyone went to see the movie expecting this. When they got a subtle and genuinely creepy movie instead, they complained, it wasn't blatant and dumbed-down enough for them. I know I sound like some artfag movie critic who wants to sound like he's above everyone else, I'm not, I'm just a semi-intelligent guy who loves horror movies. I love a dumb horror movie if it's just plain fun instead. Sadly, this one isn't, it's just dumb.So that, and the huge profits the first movie made, seem to be the reason this movie exists. Atmosphere is stripped away, and replaced with a bodycount. Surely the kids would lap it up, the people who hated the first one for not having blatant visuals and scares would love this one, it's much more in line with movies like Scream, which is today's youth's idea of horror? Correct. It's almost universal that everyone who liked this movie hated the first one too. The people who liked both tend to be people who just enjoyed the mythos and setting. I'm almost one of those people.The plot's been outlined many times, so let's get down to business. The characters are a horrible bunch. Stereotypical goth girl who hangs out in a graveyard, is constantly bitchy and depressed with snappy comebacks, and thinks she's psychic. Token Wiccan girl, because thanks to Buffy, they're trendy these days. She's another walking stereotype. Barely 5 minutes go by without her pointing out how witches aren't all evil and they're unfairly persecuted. Her wiccanism is really forced down the viewer's throat. Then there's the wizecracking, goofy crazy streetwise guy who's all about beer and pot. The cast so far seems specifically DESIGNED for the MTV generation. Then throw in a couple of slightly older folks, who feel rather out of place in the movie. I'm not sure why they were put in, their relationship works great in the plotline, but their characters just don't sit with the rest of the whole movie.The method of storytelling wants to be edgy. Tell it with flashbacks and chronological jumps, fill us in on backstory as we go. Whatever. This is a horror movie, it's impossible to build suspense for what's about to happen by telling us how someone's life was two years earlier, or letting us know that they survive to the end of the movie. It's mildly confusing for most of the film, and does far more harm than interest. Should really have stuck with a more conventional style.And the nature of the horror itself? It's largely a matter of personal preference, but most people with an IQ above 70 and an age larger than their shoe size just isn't scared by "OMG A DEAD BODY!!!". CG special effects and really blatant, laboured horror are the order of the day here. No doubt groups of fratboys or alternative metallers hanging around with popcorn and soda will be cheering on every death and consider this a cinematic masterpiece. With a rock/nu-metal soundtrack, it seems to be the kind of demographic this is marketed at anyway. People who prefer slightly more intelligence from their movies will be left rolling their eyes at the "suspenseful buildup" that you can see coming a mile off every time.
I sound like I'm really giving this movie a panning, and hate it. In some respects, I don't mean to. In others, I do. I love horror movies. Some of them take themselves seriously and succeed. Others don't take themselves seriously in the slightest, and they're just fun. This movie wants to take itself very seriously, and falls so flat on it's face that it's not funny. It constantly references the first movie, but if it'd instead referenced itself a couple of times, to let the viewer know they should be having fun instead of trying to be scared, it would have worked a great deal better. Another bad idea, this movie wants to be a scary horror, when it would have been so much more fitting as a silly horror. The characters, effects, scares and even subject matter all seem absolutely perfect for some kind of self-referential parody. But nope.I guess that's the core of why I didn't enjoy the movie. It tried too hard, and tried to reinvent a great horror movie into a dumbed-down but still entirely serious revision.I'm a fair person though. The characters may have been hopelessly cliche'd, but the actors did a great job. They played what they were given very convincingly. The visuals of the movie were great, the forest and the area most of the movie takes place around (I really wish they'd used lower-quality, TV-style cameras for the mock documentaries at the start though, another example of it taking itself too seriously). The soundtrack was out of place for a horror movie, but it's still good music in it's own right. And finally, the Blair Witch setting kicks ass. I've seen the movies and played the games, and it's a great setting with an incredible backstory that's weaved together through all these different mediums. This movie doesn't let down on that front. Shame it does on all the rest.Overall verdict, if you're willing to turn your brain off for a couple of hours to be only mildly impressed, or if you've got a short attention span and hated the first movie, go rent. Otherwise, give it a miss.

reviews.review_title: Worst Movie Ever? I liked Zardoz more...
reviews.content: I am still in physical pain after seeing this film last night.  Wow.  This one "ranks" up there with Zardoz and Manos, Hands of Fate.  I am warning everyone I can not to see this movie.  There was really no discernable plot, and the characters were completely flat.  Nothing from the first movie was explained, as I thought it would be, and nothing really happened until the end of the film. I hope that the original film makers didn't have ANYTHING to do with this one.  Their little low budget thing was really good, and this big budget farce was just crap.  Save your money.

Book of Shadows:Blair Witch 2 is based on the events which occurred after the release of the first film, and stars a group of five persons who are all equally obsessed with the Blair Witch legend. They all joined an inaugural "Blair Witch Hunt" on the Internet, which was started by Jeff(Donavan)who travels with the other four into the Black Hills of Maryland where the first movie was filmed. From the start we are shown that Jeff is, or was, highly unstable via a scene in a mental institution. The other four seem somewhat normal...we have the logical couple, pregnant Tristen and her boyfriend Steven(Skyler and Turner), who have written an argumentative novel on the Blair Witch legend..then there is the beautiful red-head Erica(Leerhsen), who claims to be an Apiscipal minister's daughter and also a Wiccan..and then my favorite of them all, Kim(Director, not literally), who plays a sexy goth chick who has premonitions and psychic powers. Quite an eclectic group, I might say.Once the first night falls they all hit the brewskies and pot pipes(yes, even the pregnant girl)but are rudely interrupted when another tour group comes and wants to take the foundation camp. After an exchange of profanities, Jeff and the rest of the gang pretend to be all freaked out and ultimately convince the other group to check out Coffin Rock. Hmm..interesting. Anyways, after this scene, Jeff's group presumes to drink themselves into a blackout. They wake up the following day to find all of their research ripped to shreds and all of their cameras broken into pieces. They ultimately blame the other tour group for this since they would not give up the foundation camp to them. See, this is where the movie gets tricky, because they have no recollection of what they did during their drunken stupors...or do they? And if they do remember then why do they blame the other tour group, which, by the way, was brutally murdered at Coffin Rock late in the previous evening. What is going on here? Certainly our main characters aren't responsible...I referred to this film as manipulative because a lot of what it shows the audience is not what actually happened...or is it? It is suggested that maybe other forces were at work here. An example is the scene where Kim gets into a confrontation with the store clerk. We clearly see for ourselves that Kim only threatens the clerk and does not kill her...but at the end of the film the police show Kim the security video that they confiscated from the store and it shows her stabbing the clerk with a nail filer. And the scene where Steven accidentally pushes Tristen to her death is also shown at the end of the film as a deliberate act of violence because Steven was mad that she had a miscarriage. I really don't know...this is kind of a mess. Did the Blair Witch manipulate the footage? Or did they really commit these crimes? One will never know because the film never provides a direct explanation. Oh well. It's a very intriguing idea, to say the least, but I use the word 'intriguing' most lightly. It's an okay sequel, but only if you enjoyed the first film. If not, skip this one altogether. I would also recommend skipping it if you don't like to be played with, because this movie will play a lot of tricks on you and this is part of the reason why I rated it so low...it was deceptive. 3/10...it's still worth a look if you are a fan of horror films. Don't expect it to be like the original, though.

reviews.review_title: This movie got a bad rap
reviews.content: This movie received so many needlessly horrible reviews.I think that the Blair Witch series is the best horror movie series since Evil Dead and in some ways surpasses it.This is not for people who enjoy such so-called horror(ble) drek such as Scream,I know what you did etc,and even such classics as Friday the 13th(the original dead teenager movie) and Nightmare on Elm st, as it is better than both of them.This film is the victim of anti-trend syndrome.What the great Spinal Tap said in ignorance,I say in ernest,"There's a fine line between stupid and clever."and in condemning this movie,those critics didn't just cross the line,they threw up on it.

reviews.review_title: Illogical, Disjointed Mess with No Point!
reviews.content: I liked the first Blair Witch. The sequel is a waste of time. The script is pretty bad and there are absolutely no explanations as to why all these bizarre things are happening. It appears as if the writers backed themselves into a corner with what had happened in the first 90 minutes and then realized that they did not have any more ideas so they just decided to end the movie. The performances are all pretty weak as well with the exception of the girl who plays Tristen. Very disappointing film with very little going for it.

reviews.review_title: Horror Connoisseurs Don't Waste Your Money!!!
reviews.content: Where are Blatty and Barker when you need them??? Was the screen writers guild on strike during the writing of this stench??? I have to give the actors credit in this one for pulling off their characters as well as they did with what they had to work with. This was the most hard to follow movie I have ever seen. It was thrown together so badly that you didn't know which way was up. I had the feeling all the way through it that the writers didn't know anything about writing stories and were depending on the gore to get them through. It has an R rating which was a mistake because it might scare 15 year olds at best. This movie, as well as a few others lately, infuriated me at the lack of quality control in Hollywood. I didn't like the first one either but at least I had to give the people who made it credit for having an original idea. Being amateurs, they pulled the original off rather well. This one just stinks.

The Lie of the BWP fans is not that they enjoyed the original film. They did. That's their right. The lie is that they sat in movie theaters full of fans who equally liked that awful film. The truth is that the great majority of paying fans who sufferred thru the original BWP were led their by Artisan's very successful promotion of the movie, a feat which they cannot reproduce, now exposed.BWP-2 is a box office disaster.  If the claims of the BWP fans were even half truthful, then the legion of fans who were supposed to love the original would at the very least pay to see BWP-2 at least once, despite the awful reviews. Very very few people are going to BWP-2. That is the real count of how many actually liked BWP-1. Although I understand that in Palm Beach County, Florida, there are 19,000 people who paid to see BWP-2 but have had their admission fees voided by an inaccurate machine.  That's life.

reviews.review_title: As a movie buff, I've seen hundreds, if not thousands of movies...
reviews.content: ...But this one is, by far, the worst movie I've ever seen in my entire life. At the premiere, the director talked about the movie and that made me honestly interested in how the film would turn out. I figured, if this guy is so in love with this movie, how bad can it possibly be?But then the film started.I'll admit, the first two minutes of the movie were entertaining, doing an almost Waiting for Guffmanesque documentary, but then it just all hit the fan from there on. The story was non-existent, as it was more of an "instance" than an actual story. The acting was horrid and wasn't helped by the fact the characters were terrible cliches, especially the Wiccan and Goth girls.In fact, this movie was so bad, I'm honestly not sure whether or not I should sue for damages, for the reason I feel so unbelievably traumatized by it. And not in a good way! If it was honestly scary because it was meant to be scary, that would be wonderful, but it was only scary in how bad the movie was. I weep for Hollywood.The director mentioned that they went through *20* different versions of the script, so I'm beginning to wonder if this is a case of the producers taking everything and screwing it up, but if not, then this was the biggest waste of 10 million dollars and months of people's time (as well as hours of mine).If Artisan had any sense, they would pull this movie and not waste anyone else's time and money. I weep for the careers of all involved.

The first movie about Blair Witch, was just a waste of money. The second one, is also a big big waste of money. They call this a horror movie, the only thing that scares you. Is that this movie, actually came out in the stores. The name of the movie, should have been "Blair Witch 2: Book of crap........don´t even mind to see this lousy movie

reviews.review_title: Don't go out of your way
reviews.content: Book of Shadows: Blair Witch 2, the sequel to The Blair Witch, takes us back to Burkitsville, Maryland where Jeffrey Patterson (Jeffrey Donovan) has started a blair witch hunt tour to make some cash off the events that happened in the original Blair Witch movie. A group of students decide to take the tour each with their own agenda. Tristine (Tristine Skyler) and Stephen (Stephen Barker Turner) are writing a book on the blair witch, Erica (Erica Leerhsen) a wicca who hopes to find and learn from the blair witch and Kim (Kim Director) who plays the roll of a goth. They all head into the woods on the tour but wake up the next morning to find their camp in disarray and unable to remember anything that happened the night before. All they have are the tapes from their camcorders. As they try to find out what happened that night, strange things continue to occur and they are unaware of who or what is behind them.Joe Berlinger tries his hand at directing this sub-par story but didn't come out on top. I felt detached and only wanting to see the tapes to know what happened, nothing else that happened in the movie really mattered. The story was pretty unoriginal, missing a lot of characterization and actual entertaining scenes. The actors didn't really do anything to change the downward slide and couldn't draw me in.Joe Berlinger didn't follow the same camera techniques as the original blair witch and it probably saved this film, somewhat. If he would have gone with the first person view I believe the movie would have flopped even more based on how well the original was done.There are some quick gore scenes throughout the film to satisfy an itch and the plot never made me use my imagination so we are lacking quite a bit of what makes a horror movie, a horror movie.All in all I couldn't shake the undying need to know what happened on those tapes. After I found out the action finally started to pick up but a little too late. If interested give this a peek but don't go out of your way.

reviews.review_title: yap!yap!yap!(and a minor spoiler here and there)
reviews.content: "We're walkin' around in circles, Heather!" "No. We're not!"But, in the end, she has a nervous breakdown and admits, sobbingly, that they WERE walking in circles. But what else could she have done? Face the sad fact that there was definitely something out there? Stop living in denial? Wake up and smell the coffee?In October 1999, Marc heard about a low budget horrorflick that was taking American audiences by storm. A few weeks later, Marc saw the scene in which Heather Donahue videotapes her own testament and found himself scared witless.First, despite the simple Grimm Brothers-like story-line, people still manage to not get The Blair Witch Project at all. "The dialogue is pretty bad", one complains. Another person accuses the filmmakers of bad filmmaking: "I couldn't see were the second act ended and the third act began". "It had its boring moments", yet another guy wrote. And Joe Berlinger, director of the inevitable sequel said that the mockumentary-style doesn't require a 'shakycam' technique, adding that "Mockumentary certainly isn't about convincing people that what they are seeing is fact".Boy o Boy! (2 X)Talk about missing the point! This isn't 'unconventional filmmaking'. This isn't a mockumentary that directors tried to surpass as being fact. Its companion piece, "The Curse Of The Blair Witch", THAT'S a mockumentary. Our three disappeared characters never came around to shoot and edit a documentary. After the couple of interviews they did in town (steadily shot), they just tried to capture on video what the f**k was going on in the woods, holding the cameras with trembling hands. BWP shouldn't even be considered as a movie. "A Year Later Their Footage Was Found". This line is right there on the screen, at the beginning of it. Raw footage. And what follows is just that: a bunch of dark, suggestive, incoherent images and sounds with only one purpose: scare you. Scare you good. Everything else goes. BW has no redeeming quality; if it didn't scare you, you can only appreciate the fact that five people beat Hollywood with a camcorder, and pity the fact that it was hyped to such an extent that people turns against it because it was too popular to be considered underground. By the way, I do think it's rather amusing that much negative reviewers aren't saying something like "I didn't like BW" but "I wasn't scared -I really wasn't!- by BW".And, OF COURSE BWP has its boring moments. That's all part of its pseudo-authentic nature. When was the last time you couldn't take your eyes off the screen when a friend or relative showed you his or hers incoherent videotaped holiday or backyard activities? When was the last time you remarked to such a person that their video had such a nice structure and great dialogue? Anyone who dismisses BWP because it is sometimes boring and lacks movie-dialogue and a good structure is clearly missing the point. Again, folks, check your conventional movie-expectations at the door.I think it was Stephen King who considered the sound behind the door-routine as the archetypal horror-situation. So, imagine, if you will, a walk through the first floor corridor of a haunted house...wait, let's make that a haunted castle. It's night. It's dark. You're alone. You hear a sound, right over there, right behind that door down the end of the hall. A loud, creaking sound. The best thing to do? Run! Run in the opposite direction. But something in us can't resist. We humans are rather curious creatures, aren't we? (and stubborn: I'm gonna prove there ain't nothin' there). So we stand motionless for a couple of secs. Then, ever so slowly, we start heading for that door. No matter what can be found behind that door, it'll be relieve of tension as nothing, nothing can be more nerve-wracking than the walk itself. Tension mounts. What can be scarier than not seeing the whole picture? For people with a sense of imagination, our mind, our fantasy becomes our greatest enemy. So, when we finally get our hand around the doorknob, we have become jelly-legged. We pull, or push, open the door and out comes a monster/killer/ghost and things fall in place. Labeled. Branded. A manifestation upon which we can focus our fear.In BWP, that long walk through the corridor isn't accompanied by comic relief, a cool soundtrack, or the fun of watching a every-hair-perfect-in-place Neve Campbell or Jennifer Love Hewitt screaming at the top of her longs while the camera  focuses on her breasts doing a little exercise in her just-a-tad-too-tight tank top. What we DO get is a tired girl, coming down with a bad case of the flu, whispering directly at us, in a grainy video-image, that she is 'so scared' and 'so sorry'. And we never get to see what it was that scared her so. Nor does it matter. The fear itself is enough. Is more. In BWP, we never get around to open that door in that haunted castle. We never get around to face, label, brand, or categorize what scared us. No relief. Just the fear. And the horrible authenticity of it.BWP was and is a once in a lifetime experience. And I have to admit, I was naive enough to NOT expect a sequel. Come on, a sequel would be the dumbest thing, right? What do you want to do, have another bunch of unsuspecting students go into the woods, armed with semi-professional camera gear? Not exactly, but a sequel was inevitable enough, though.One guy on the internet compared it to the Scream-phenonemon.They greenlight the sequel any day. Story not quite done? Final cut must be ready within three months from the first shooting day? No problemo, patron. The sequel doesn't need to be a good film. There will be so many people just dying to see this thing. Ever heard of those two magical words: Opening Weekend, man! The first two days before the effect of the word of mouth ("It sucks!") kicks in, we already made a profit. But, stubbornly, we still go for that part three, by the time of which nobody's interested in that witch anymore.The story of Book Of Shadows (BOS) wasn't a story that wanted to be told, but had to be told, to give the originally fairly small Artisan Pictures the chance to even more cash in on their sleeper hit. And fast. Several drafts were written and Artisan quickly rushed into production with this one. It took them merely a year after BWP's release to cough up BOS. The opening is fair enough, which shows the effect BWP had on the area where it was filmed. A frustrated sheriff who clearly had enough of it all, runs around screaming at the umpteenth bunch of teenagers to get their butts out of the woods and back in their cars so they can be on their way home.Artisan was wise enough to make this neither a Kevin Williamson-style horrorflick or a 'remake' of the first film. But, in a way, this is actually both. The story that had to be told for money purposes takes elements from Twin Peaks (the 'inhabiting spirit' storyline) and Wes Craven's New Nightmare (fact and fiction interwoven in a fictional film). Whereas BWP threw everything overboard to be an overwhelming psychological experience, BOS is, in technical terms, a professional picture. Technically conventional moviemaking. The film is populated by fairly attractive people, whose acting ranges from mediocre to downright amateurish. There are special effects and conventional scares (the ole tap-on-your-shoulder routine). There is a superb soundtrack produced by Marilyn Manson and there are some cool visuals (like the camera 'attacking' Jeffrey Donovan, who should be given the chance to move on to better things). Is it unfair to compare it to the first film? Well, it's a continuation of the same premise, isn't? It's the middle part of what apparently will be a trilogy.And Joe Berlinger's reaction to the criticism resembled that of Jan de Bont's, who did a remake of "The Haunting": "They didn't get what they expected, they had other expectations of what I was trying to do with this film".  Er, gee, it's a horrorfilm. I guess I sorta expected to be scared. I dunno. My fellow countryman's "The Haunting" wasn't scary and Berlinger's BOS isn't scary. BWP was for many people a terrifying experience, a confrontation with their own fears. BOS, not a sincere motion picture, simply isn't scary. Thus a failure.This film is released in a time when I have to get used to the fact that I'm in a new phase of my life, and, more important (obviously not necessarily for me), the United States of America are choosing their new leader. And my mind can't help but wander back to the walking around in circles in BWP, to Heather's clinging to a fake certainty, to Heather's not wanting to face the facts.So many of us are there with her, aren't we? Walking around in circles. Fooling ourselves. Limiting our own potential. Wanting to be in control of things. Needing patterns. Fake certainties. Sticking to rules we create ourselves. Taking sides. Even if it all doesn't work one bit, we couldn't just try to change it, could we now?We see it in our own daily routines, in politics (the repetitive stupidity of the presidential elections. Not joining hands, or at least trying to find a middle way. No, it's a contest with opponents who need to disagree with each other on principle in those dumb debates -"Senator, how serious are you about your plans?"- and trying to beat 'the other guy' by finding out that he did something in the past that makes him way too human. Every four year. The same thing over and over again) and in art, too. BOS came out and, there we go again, all the reporters ask the same questions that already have been asked about a million times and the 'talents' give their standard replies, stating how great it was to work with their fellow actors who are the greatest bunch of talented people, and that their director is a one of a kind auteur. We all know it's a charade, we all know it's bonkers, but we still keep it up. What else can we do?In the end, I really don't know what scared me more: the power BWP has to conjure up primal fears or the symbolic value of a stubborn person suddenly realizing and admitting that she has been walking around in circles and the way she reacts to the fact that she doesn't have this pseudo-safety anymore to hold on to.If you appreciated the original Blair Witch Project, I'd like to recommend the original "The Haunting" (1963) by Robert Wise. (O, and maybe "Primary Colors" -1997- by Mike Nichols, too).

reviews.review_title: Why is there a need to make a good thing so very bad?
reviews.content: "The Blair Witch Project" was a monumental film for many reasons: it was made on a non-existent budget, grossed millions at the box office, brought terror to the audience through suggestive imagery, and showed that "a little movie that could" can beat a studio film like "The Haunting" when it comes down to it. However, this is not the case with "Book Of Shadows: Blair Witch 2."The idea is good, but it's another example of bad execution. The idea is that in the fall of 1999, this group of five people travel into the woods of Burketsville on a "Blair Witch Hunt." The leader of this troop was once a mental patient at the local loony bin and has now set up a travel agency of sorts into the Blair Witch woods, which is funded by witch merchandise, merchandise, merchandise and by hocking black market goods on Ebay. The rest of the group is made up of a couple working on a Blair Witch book doing on location studies, a real life modern day witch that is a "child of nature," and a run-away goth chick who. So, all of these people saw "The Blair Witch Project" and now they're off to see where it was filmed and this entire movie is a reenactment of what happened to them.So, there's no book of shadows in "Book Of Shadows: Blair Witch 2" and there's no witch either. This time the troop of people go into the woods and make it out, but the Blair Witch has "touched" them and continues to mess with their heads from far away. So, the gist of it is that the Blair Witch has these super powers that now reach long distance and turn everyone against each other by making them see things that aren't really there.All in all, it was disappointing. I really enjoyed "The Blair Witch Project;" part 2 was very hard to get through. It seemed more like an excuse to make a movie hot on the tails of a successful one hoping to ride the gravy train and throw in as much metal music as possible.
