reviews.content: Sorry, that's an awful pun.But then, its an awful film.The original Blair Witch Project is possibly the most original horror movie of all time, certainly of the last twenty years, and I remember the creators saying that they would NEVER do a sequel, for all the obvious reasons (the original was built up on internet hype and the cunning ruse of the docu-style content).So the Studio bought the rights and handed them over to somebody who had no right to touch the material (Joe Berlinger, please stand up). Book of Shadows is, quite frankly, laughable. Where the first film thrived on having amateur actors and no script, this sequel suffers terribly from sub-amateur actors and an all-too-obvious script posing as improvisation. The plot (if indeed, there is one) is ridiculous, with only the first three minutes providing anything of interest at all (it parodies the media circus surrounding the first film). Somebody decided to edit this to create a non-linear narrative, perhaps to hide or excuse the fact that NOTHING MAKES ANY SENSE!!! Even the actors are heard to utter; "This makes no sense" and "I have no idea what's going on"...and they are absolutely right, as the audience are saying the same things.From the horrendous continuity errors (check out the goth girl's white make up - it appears and disappears at will) to the laughable editing (one dialogue scene between two characters tries to splice two takes of the same shot together in between lines, presumably to cut out some terrible acting, and it is the most obviously poor edit in any film, ever...and I have seen Cradle of Fear), there is not ONE REDEEMABLE FEATURE that could leave you feeling anything other than cheated.The characters are, and I am complimenting them here, completely one-dimensional, the direction and cinematography are awful (not one decent angle. NOT ONE), and the climax is simply ridiculous. When the surviving characters are arrested and taken to the police station, their dv cameras and security cameras tapes are confiscated and played back to them...but some admin assistant at the police station must have fancied themselves as a movie editor as the tapes are played back as one, previously cut together collage of all the tapes!!!!What?!?!?!?!?! The 'scare' scenes of a Ringu-style girl walking backwards through the forest and disappearing are in there just for the hell of it.Oh yeah, and there is a disappearing and reappearing tree that spooks the characters at several points. Eek. NOTHINGMAKESANYSENSE!!!!!! If you enjoy mickey-taking and paying out ridiculously poor films, this is one for you. You'll have more ammunition than you know what to do with.If, however, you're a fan of the original, or a fan of movie-making in general, DO NOT TOUCH IT WITH A TEN FOOT POLE.I guarantee that every time you watch this movie, a little piece of you will die.Shame on you, Berlinger, shame on you.

reviews.review_title: maybe this should have been a script for Freaky Links instead
reviews.content: Maybe it's because I waited to see this on video after I had already become a big fan of the tv series Freaky Links, but the whole time i'm watching it it reminded me of just another Freaky Links episode. I liked the movie, though i was a bit disappointed with the ending after hearing what a trip it was supposed to have been, but I think it would have done better as a 2hour tv movie for the show.

reviews.review_title: Should have sticked to just one movie
reviews.content: The Blair Witch Project was a phenomenon at the time. Using it`s very own style of movie, it was a sure hit. Part 2 is just like the other horror movies. Nothing like the original movie. I recommend to see it but with VERY low expectations.

This could have been a good film imo, but it isnt because it does not take itself seriously enough. The film constantly analyses what is happening rather then getting lost in the horror of the events unfolding and worse still is the darn tv footage. I came to watch a film not trash tv, thats the worst aspect.  Whoever was reponsible for some of the finer elements of this film, i sure hope they get another chance.

reviews.review_title: Remarkable intelligence for a mainstream horror film
reviews.content: For once a sequel actually improves on the (already impressive) original. Despite a $7 million budget and Hollywood aesthetic BW2 is remarkable close in thematic content to the original Blair Witch Project. I always thought that BWP was based on Sartre's edict that "Hell is other people" and for all the talk of witches and curses it is from the twisted dynamic between the groups of strangers thrown together in both films that the true horror comes. Visually there are links from BW2 to the first film: close ups of female faces distended by unfocused camera lenses, 'found' footage on video, fake interviews with Burkitsville townfolk, but it is in the differences that BW2 strides ahead of its forerunner. Director Joe Berlinger has crafted a supremely intelligent film that both debunks and reinforces the Blair Witch mythos, ably assisted by an excellent cast of unknown actors. A must see film for horror fans in these days of identikit sequels.

Some people I expect to not know enough to make a proper critique of this movie, but it's the most horrible thing I've ever watched.  This movie was personally offensive.  The Wiccan was portrayed as a druggy sex-crazed idiot who only joined the Craft because she wanted to spite her parents.  And it was a stupid "slash 'em up" movie.  It wasn't scary, it was sickening.  I loved Blair Witch I, and this was a major dissappointment.

reviews.review_title: What a sad and uninspired film . . . .
reviews.content: Book of Shadows: Blair Witch Project 2 ½ starWhat a sad and uninspired film has been made in an attempt to capitilze on the success of last year's excellent and original Blair Witch Project.What perhaps is most disappointing about this film is that it had such potential. The first 35 minutes are good. The set-up provided in that time period with these exact same characters could have been used to make a great horror film by simply following the rules of the genre. Instead this film strays from those rules but doesn't break any ground it just retreads poorly what occurred in the first film with a twist that basically just cheats the audience.The story starts by telling us the first film was indeed a fictional film but the town in it is real. It then shows how that film impacted the town, taking place about 5 months after the first film's release. One resident, Jeff, who had been in an insane asylum a year earlier creates a tour that goes into the woods to look for the witch and the legend discussed in the first film. For his initial tour he gets four young adults, Stephen and Tristen a couple writing a book on the mythology of the Blair Witch and the hysteria effect caused by the film. He is a man of reason who does not believe in mythology, she feels that there is always a factual basis to any myth. She is also six weeks pregnant. The other tour goers are Erica who is a Wiccan that wants to commune with the spirit of the Blair Witch, and Kim a Goth with psychic powers that is going simply because she thought the movie was cool.The tour group goes to the remains of the Blair Witch's house where they discover a mysterious tree. The Wiccan casts a pair of spells one to undo the evil at the sight, and one to awaken the Blair Witch's spirit. The group sets up some cameras provided by the tour guide and then engages in liberal drug and alcohol use around the campfire as they try to stay up all night. They have brief run-in with another tour group whom they convince to set-up camp at Coffin Rock where the witch committed her murders in the 1800's (as revealed in the first film).The group then collectively blacks out and when they awaken it is raining paper and all of their equipment has been destroyed. They soon find their videotapes in the exact place where the tapes of the first film were supposedly found. At first they suspect the other tour group of sabotaging their equipment but when they find out the next day the other tour group was murdered they don't know what to think.And then the film falls apart. The group goes to the home of the tour guide, which conveniently is an abandoned factory with a shaky metal bridge over a ravine providing the only way in or out. The factory also happens to be located on the Black Hills outside of town which are haunted by the witch. But that alone wouldn't have sank the movie. While we would have been in familiar territory (I'm sure you can guess what happens to that bridge) the elements were in place for a good film. The characters begin watching the tapes to try put together the lost time. The psychic and the Wicca both sense an evil presence among them.But the film is all build and no delivery and it requires the characters to have the intelligence of chipmunks. Before the characters set up house in the factory they have to go to the hospital due to a medical emergency. Later in the factory they notice they all have strange markings carved onto their body. You think they would be alarmed. But the two men both argue that it must be poison oak. It has to be one of the most laughably inane scenes in film history. The one character lives in the woods; he doesn't poison oak looks like? The other characters are writing a book on witchcraft or in the case of Erica is a witch herself. Earlier scenes in the film show them deciphering these same types of symbols. Yet they don't recognize them. Not to mention the symbols are obviously scar tissue from like a knife or something, even if they were so dumb as to think the symbols were coincidental why would think it was poison oak? Have they ever scene leaves that are so thin they can draw straight lines? And since they were in the hospital earlier anyway wouldn't they ask doctor to look at these symbols? Later in the film Erica does read the symbols and tells a character she's next to die. Yet that character does not die next meaning either Erica isn't a very well educated witch or the screenwriter failed foreshadowing in film school.This film is basically a one scare film. Characters will see something supernatural, the audience jumps and the character blinks and your back to where you were 10 seconds ago the image was a hallucination. The film plays this trick at least 30 times, no exaggeration, probably because it was too devoid of original thought to do anything else. The gore quotient is also up quite unnecessarily more than in the first film yet again probably because the director had no other way to manufacture scares. SPOILER ALERT The film has other problems, which I can only reveal by discussing specific plot points so feel free to skip this paragraph if you don't like minor spoilers. Much of the character's traits mean nothing. Kim's psychic powers end up having no bearing on the plot at all other than them finding the tapes which could have been done in a dozen other ways. Jeff's insanity again means nothing unless the viewer wants to interpret the ending of the film that he is still insane, the other characters never find out about it to cause dissension among them, it's just a tool to fill time for some pointless flashbacks. Halfway through the film we see the sheriff interviewing certain characters about the events basically letting us know who survives and doesn't before the film ends, yet once everything that happened in the woods and the factory is revealed the film just ends. Again couldn't we have seen them get arrested afterwards for all the difference it made? The jumps in time are more jarring then suspenseful throughout the film and since nothing happens after them at least the ending would have had more of an impact without them.Even the title cheats the viewer. There is no Book of Shadows in this film. Video tapes of shadows perhaps but not a book. The characters never find a book belonging to the witch. None of the characters own a book or read a book in the course of the film. And the two characters writing a book intend to title it "The Blair Witch: History or Hysteria?"Still other problems include the nonsensical way the filmmaker's decide Erica's take the evil spell back worked. Even the motivations of the witch make no sense considering the alternatives that are foreshadowed in the first 35 minutes. Then to top it all off the film provides a chronology of the witch's life in direct conflict with facts provided in the earlier film that based on other events in this film would also have to be true.Ultimately the film leaves the viewer letdown. It doesn't payoff, there are no scares, it is unnecessarily violent and most of the plot twists are pointless and/or disappointing. If it didn't have such a good set-up and character development in the early portion it wouldn't even get the half star I gave it.

It's been about 6 hours since I finished watching BW2 and I'm still not exactly sure what I think of it.I saw BWP after all the hype and was pretty glad I waited for my best friend to take me; not b/c it scared me (which it didn't until I got home to my apt. which is eerily close to a creepy wooded area from which odd noises emanate in the middle of the night while I am *trying* to sleep) but b/c I found myself actually caring about the characters and I was glad that they were just actors and not really dead.  That is, they at least seemed like real people; not just actors.  Sure, they were a bit over the top in some scenes; but who wouldn't be in that situation - if it were *real*?  Maybe it was just the fact that it looked "real" (more so than the sequel, to be sure) but it did creep me out a bit more than I expected it to; knowing it was "fake".On to BW2, which - as we know - isn't a sequel, but a followup to the first. I just didn't care about anybody in this movie.  I was surprised that they actually portrayed a believable (if not completely accurate) Wiccan, but even that character failed to arouse my empathy.  The goth girl was gorgeous, but just a bit too apathetic.  All of the goths I've ever met are far more passionate (and interesting) than Kim.  The two guys were just slightly less retarded than your average drunken frat boy; and the scariest one wasn't the "crazy" one.  The "pregnant girl" (yes, I remember her name was Tristen, but does it even matter that she had a name?) was actually the most disturbing and least believable one of the lot.  I would have pushed her, too.Also, the early scenes from the "mental institution" disturbed me more than I think they were meant to; and in the wrong way.  It wasn't the hose in the nose or the goo dripping from his mouth that bothered me, rather the blatant disregard for another human being's dignity and physical comfort.  Why exactly was the "doctor" smoking while performing some sort of unnecessary "procedure" on little Jeff?  At least in "Jacob's Ladder", the hospital from hell had a purpose, as well as an explanation.There's more to say, of course; but I only have 1,000 words and I'd just end up venting and rambling about why a film  with a decent premise and real potential was mutated into this.  I read somewhere that they rushed to release it for all the college kids and fans of the genre (and the first movie).  I'd buy that.  Too bad, BW2 could have been really spooky-ooky.As for a reccomendation: see it for yourself.  I can't tell you whether or not you'll like it; but at least you'll be able to make up your own mind. There's nothing worse than not thinking for yourself.PS.  Every story has a moral: Don't have a drunken orgy in haunted woods unless you have lots of high-tech film equipment.  Oh, and things going backwards are much more interesting than things going forwards.  But that's not really a moral, now is it?

The original Blair Witch movie was exceptional. In terms of style, structure, atmosphere and performance it worked effectively on every level. This sequel however, is a completely different beast. It is impossible to examine this film without reference to its predecessor and I've got to say that Book of Shadows is everything the original was not. Where the first film successfully utilised the power of persuasion, documentary realism and naturalistic performances for its overall effect, this movie is wholly reliant on big budget horror movie stylistics and slick special effects. To be fair to Berlinger, the imagery is generally good and occasionally disturbing. The film is visually striking and edited extremely well. Where it is badly let down however, is through a combination of poor acting and a truly woeful script. The genuine fear and tension that the original cast created is lost and replaced with cliched, over stated performances and some unbelievably dreadful dialogue ("She's a witch man...a big p***ed off witch"...pleeease). Its a shame too, because there are obviously some interesting themes and ideas being addressed. The basic premiss of the film which deals with the hype surrounding the Blair Witch phenomenon is a clever one, and the concept of group hysteria which lies at the heart of the story line has much potential. It could have been so much better if the overall execution was vastly improved. The film has the aesthetic qualities of a decent horror movie. With the aid of a script doctor and an acting coach, it could have been a real contender.

Book of Shadows was good. Plain and simple. It freaked me out at times (even though not as much as the first) and held its own. The acting was pretty darn good for a bunch of unknowns  (all showing tons of promise), and Joe Berlinger did a great job with the direction. I enjoyed the story immensely. How they built off all the hype of the first and used it to their advantage. That was creative, and no one gives it any credit for that. The ending was fantastic, as it left it open (just as in the first) and that, as much as it bugged me, definitely added something to the movie. The opening credits were pretty wicked too. Some of the nekkidness I think we could have done without but that didn't make the movie bad by any means. I'd give it a "B" overall. It's far superior to all the teen slasher flick c**p that is currently shoved down our throats. And critics need to realize that movies are for ENTERTAINMENT.Try to be ENTERTAINED!!

I didn't have any preconceived notions about how this movie was going to be, and I really enjoyed it.  The music was great, I just wish I could find the song done by Sunshine called Streamlined.  The way the film was exposed, with rich color, made it interesting to watch.  I just took it as a lighthearted jab at all the people who take movies too seriously. Therefore, I wasn't disappointed that it wasn't scary.  Each character portrayed the extreme of their stereotype... the goth chick, the wiccan, the crazy dude living off his internet earnings... it was hilarious in that respect.Just watch it the way you watched the movie called Scream, and you'll enjoy it.

I think Blair Witch 2 was great and better movie than Blair Witch Project. Cast is much more better especially goth Kim and wicca Erica. Movie can be great to you if you know secrets of esrever and you understand it. I think that some samples aren't understandable,but still great. My favourite scenes are when Erica is casting spells and Tristen's buster boysThe worst scenes are when Stephen is explaining Tristen some Blair Witch things

reviews.review_title: its an underrated film, good on its on merit.. i luved it!
reviews.content: I think it's a good movie. You don't really know which direction it was going and kind of has a nice twist to it. It still uses gimmicks but it kind of work for that sense of creepiness. It plays on your paranoia.. brilliant stuff. a good follow up. should also listen to the director's interesting commentary on how the term "documentary" or "shaky" camera technique has been abused.

I watched this movie for the first time in summer 2006, it was one I have always wanted to watch, but generally avoided because of bad reviews, but if there is one thing this movie has taught me, it is do not listen to what other people think of movies, everyone should be able to give there own opinion. How do you know you wont like a movie if you don't watch it, just because someone said it was rubbish, does not mean that it is! I loved this movie and the story that goes with it. The actors are very good and the fact that they take the first Blair witch project in the same light that we take it is very good. A definite must for all horror movie fans!

Here in Israel this movie skipped the theaters and went straight to video. I caught it on TV recently and... well, it's bad. but i have a little confession: I LIKE bad horror movies. they make me laugh, some even more than comedies. and may i add that i found the first BWP just plain BORING and couldn't see why it was supposed to be scary. and so to me it's a good thing the sequel is nothing like the first film, and needless to say i liked it MUCH better. pretty stupid plot, doesn't make sense in most parts, paranoia all around - now THAT'S comedy.

reviews.review_title: A brilliant, scary, clever, enjoyable film. Make your own mind up.
reviews.content: I must have seen a completely different film, to everyone else.  I am amazed at the comments that have been made about this film.I thought the acting to be terrific and realistic.  I found the film scary, eerie, funny.I refuse to compare it to the first as they are both completely different. But believe they are equally as good, for their own reasons.There is so much about the film, which is deep than most people seem to miss.  Everyone comes out of the cinema thinking they have understood it, but the only reason is that they expect to be told everything from start to end.  Sometime people, you have to open your mind and use your brain, then you may find there is so much more to the film than you first thought.If you don't believe me, see it again.  I've seen it 3 times now and each time is a new experience.Don't be persuaded by people to see or not see the film.  Make up your own mind.  If you go and see it because someone has said it is really good, you will expect too much.  If you don't go and see it because someone has told you it is bad, you may be missing out on a very enjoyable experience.What is your definition of a Scary Movie?

reviews.review_title: A good, entertaining trip into horror
reviews.content: There are some horror films that use gore, blood and violence in ways that are detrimental to a film (like the Friday the 13th sequels). To hear critics and audiences speak of Book of Shadows, you believe it is a horrifically gory film. This is not the case at all. Yes, there is blood and some gore, but what is shown is more shocking than horrific. It hearkens back to The Silence of the Lambs, in which any supposedly gory scene was shown only to shock, not appall. I certainly don't consider it as classic as Lambs, but Book of Shadows does, in essence, achieve the same goal: to shock you, to make you think, but not disturb you to vomit or have nightmares.The story revolves some several months after the Blair Witch Project opens. Some fans decide to go on a trip with a former nut-house patient named Jeff, who is suppose to be sane, who has started a tour group of Blair Witch spots. The people joining include a skeptic, Steven, his less skeptical wife,Tristen, a woman who claims to be a witch,Erica and a goth girl, Kim. On the tour, they meet a competing group. After a short argument, both teams separate from each other. As Jeff's group enjoy themselves on the first night, they wake up in the morning and don't remember anything of the previous night.They decide to investigate and find answers, but what they find is far from what they expected. The journey is shocking and fun to watch. You think you know what's coming, then are floored when something worse happens. This film really captures what a good psychological horror film is about: to shock us into thought. On all levels, this film delivers what it promised. It is a shocking, amazing, thought-provoking piece of cinema. I loved it.

I completely disagree with Gov'nor's comments.  Blair Witch 2 will not disappoint you.  I feel the writers/director did an incredible job of reinventing something that was thought to be unsurpassable.  I feel Book of Shadows, in it's own right, blows away the first Blair Witch Project. Don't get me wrong....the first flick was unique, fun, entertaining and worthy all on it's own.....but, Blair Witch 2 can compete with the heavy-hitter horror movies.  The biggest challenge that the makers of BW2 were faced with was creating something that didn't replicate nor take away from the first movie. I think they couldn't have done a better job.  So, judge for yourself....go see BW2.  I believe you will not be disappointed.  BUT - just for the record, I believe that the R Rating isn't restrictive enough here.  I feel NO ONE under the age of 17 should see this movie.  It's quite graphic and twisted. :)  Enjoy!

reviews.review_title: Scared the hell out of me!
reviews.content: I went into this movie having been a huge fan of the last one. I wanted it to fail. However, it scared the bejeepers out of me. A different feel than the first one, but 100% worth seeing. It was a sneak preview that I saw and I got a T-Shirt too! Weeee!

reviews.review_title: Really strange and gory, but good...
reviews.content: I, for one, was a huge fan of BW1. I find that people either hated it or they loved it, no in-between. I'm finding that with the previous comments on BW2. BW2 was nothing like the original, which couldn't have possibly been replicated anyway. It was more in the "real" movie style, but still maintaining its ability to scare the c*** out of me. It got really gory at times, and it was a little out there (I definitely had to think about what had just happened when it got over). Overall, i say it was a great flic, and if you can stomach blood and guts and want to be scared a whole bunch, go for it!

reviews.review_title: Entertaining but not unique horror movie.
reviews.content: I haven't sifted through the other comments so I'm limiting my comment to my own take on the film and a response to the primary post featured on the main page titled "Book of Shadows is technically the follow up to the 1999snoozefest, "The Blair Witch" -- First, a defense of the original; the initial comment states: "If you were frightened by the original BWP, it was because of the mystique, not because of what you saw in the film." On the contrary, I had been out of the loop on all the pre-movie hype and reality controversy and walked into the theatre expecting crap (as the few reviews I had read said it was) but wanting to see what the buzz was about as I was a screenwriting student at the time. What I got was exactly what was missing in most horror movies of the modern age, and that is the basic hypothosis (so often overlooked) that true horror, true terror, is achieved through IMPLICATION not through overt or cheap fright techniques. I might jump the first, or even every time some teenslasher comes out from behind the door, but the fright then subsides during the experience of the film, and by no means do I cary it out of the theater with me. But a film like "Jacob's Ladder" or "The Exorcist" that uses a lot of shadows and implications to sustain the fear levels, this creates a constant feeling of dread (part of the true definition of a horror story) that not only sustains throughout the film, but stays with me out of the theatre. The first Blair Witch achieved this because I was able to suspend my disbelief due to the realistic docu-video qualities of it. It was real and unreal. Was it deliverence locals or a real witch? Either way they disappeared and were most likely murdered (within the fiction of the film). This has absolutely nothing to do with the pre film hype or "mystique" (which I experienced very little of) as the original post claims, it has everything to do with what I saw in the film itself. And as for "technical expertise" the poster is obviously biased towards non-experimental non-arthouse film and is basing his ideal of technique on big budget hollywood films. I thought the technique was refreshing, new, exciting, and fit ideas I and others likeminded have had for films for a long time. I didn't snooze during the first, I was scared to death. -- Now, as for the sequal. It is a true sequal, it follows the first, it has the same subject, and the fact that they refer to the first as a film does not alter the fact that this fits the definition of a sequal. The Final Nightmare by Wes Craven was loosely based on fact and refered to all the other films as fiction, but it was still a sequal, and, next point, was still a "horror" film. -- What is the definition of a horror film? A film which maintains (or attempts to maintian) a constant feeling of dread and or fear and usually has an unhappy ending, and, most often deals with either the reality of or implication of the supernatural. Thus Final Nightamre and Blair Witch 2 (both similar in basic premise) are both truly horror movies. To say otherwise is rather absurd, epescially based on the meager support that the film refers to the original as fiction, or that it explores the ideas of what is real or not real (doesn't every horror movie you've ever seen explore that difference?) -- As for the film itself independant of the original and independant of my problems with the initial post; what is the main goal of any film? To entertain. Does this film entertain? I think it does. Therefore it has succeded in its primary goal. It maintains a good horror movie vibe, it messes with your head, it has wonderful atmosphere, good acting (above standard for the horror genre) and superb music. The screenplay is a bit messy (somewhat unfocused and in need of some redrafts) and the direction is a little sloppy, but it's above average in my book, I give this film a 6.5 out of 10 and I will definatley see it again. It is almost impossible to seperate discussion of the original when talking about the sequal, and in this case I don't think it should be. Yes, the film stands on its own, but at the same time it couldn't be in that upright and independant condition were it not for the support of it's mother. -- In a final word, I am all to aware that in this world people can base their opinions on what is "popular" or what is "not" even those who claim to be "outsiders" can allow their personal opinions to be guided by the masses just so they can feel superior by going against the norm. So when a film like Blair Witch, a low low budget indie horror movie that film buffs should be supporting with all their might, suddenly becomes a pop culture phenomenon the outsiders relish the chance to claim the film is pure crap and dismiss it without a fair trial. Sure there are many who honestly hated it, this is the way of the world, but I know from many conversations that what it boils down to is that people mostly hate Blair Witch because of it's popularity and its hype, not based on any really solid and crystalized criticism of the film itself. -- My two cents. . .

reviews.review_title: Hey, y'know, it's not half bad.....
reviews.content: Well, by reading most of the comments on this film, it would be hard to get any clear picture of if the sequel is any good or not.  I did like the first film, not because it was a stunningly filmed piece of art, but because it was a cool concept done pretty well.  Because of all the hype around the first film, any sequel is going to have a rough time of it, and many people will snub this movie because "it can't possibly be any better than the first one".  So if thats your attitude and you loved the first film, then best just stay at home and not disappoint yourself.  But for the rest of us free thinking open minded individuals, it may be worth taking a look see.  I have to admit that I was expecting this to be terrible, but I was shocked to find that it wasn't.  The acting is fine (no oscars here though), but the actual plot line and how it is tied to the first film is actually quite clever. It's all about expectation, this film is a not half bad teen shlocker in the "final scream at the faculty last summer" mould.  Pick up your popcorn, take out your brain and you may just enjoy this.

reviews.review_title: played more like TV than cinema
reviews.content: I liked the idea of using these characters, but their portrayal seemed phony. I liked the ideas of this movie, yet it lacked cinematic strength (with the exception of the group waking to book pages falling like snow or ashes). There was a decent underside view of a hanging. Overall, not many scenes resonated. The movie was vague in an unrewarding way. The use of video was interesting. LOST HIGHWAY did a better job conjuring up that sort of creepy meta-reality characters get stuck in when shown video evidence doing horrific acts.

I should have probably taken note when even the guy at my local video store said "Hey, why are you renting that? It sucks."Needless to say, I failed to heed his advice. Perhaps he was a mystical oracle who tried to warn me. Perhaps he was a cyborg sent from the future to stop me from making a tragic mistake. Perhaps he just knows bad movies when he sees them. Either way, maybe Book of Shadow's producers should have met him.Anyway, having loved the Blair Witch Project, I rented this. I felt like I was being tormented. For over an hour and fifteen minutes, I suffered. Through incomprehensible and reasonless plot twists, I watched. Through incessant and unnecessary blood/nudity I sat. And, through it all, I could think only one thing:Either I was on drugs or the producers were. And I'm pretty sure it's not me. There is some seriously freaky junk going on in this movie, and I don't mean in a good way. It's freaky because it really seems sometimes like they shot a bunch of scenes and randomly put them together in any order. In Fight Club, Tyler Durden liked to splice pictures of porno into kiddie films. (Anyone remember?) It kinda feels like Tyler Durden is running the tape projector during this movie. Except it's dead bodies and naked dancing, instead of porn.I won't even get into the awful acting. Wait, Tristan was cool. (The pregnant girl)As for the ending, I admit, I liked the ending. It was freaky in the good kinda way, even if it does basically make the past 75 minutes completely pointless. Do I recommend suffering through 80 minutes or so of garbage just to get to the ending? Not really. Bottom line: A very weird picture

The Blair Witch Project is, quite frankly, the worst movie I have seen.  It was worse than Camp Blood...and that is bad.  My life's movie consumption has been horror to a great deal, and at the theatre watching Book of Shadows ( I refer to call it Blair Witch 2...it so far surpassed BWP) for the first time...I was scared.  A movie scared me.Just a warning to everyone out there....if you like the first Blair Witch, you will hate this movie.  But, for anyone out there that HATES or even disliked the first movie...this is the movie for you!

I loved this movie. Mostly for it's originallity that it brought to the screen. I wish that it wasn't ascossiated with the BWP because that only brought it down. People did not enjoy this movie because they were expecting... something else, but they were hit with amazing originallity that is highly uncommon in recent horror movies. Which in my theory, confuses them, bringing their liking of the movie down. They probably spent half of the movie thinking  what is this? i don't know what will happen yet, that's different, and then the final question 'WHY'? well, in thinking this, it proves that they aren't paying attention to catch its edgy creativeness. Anyway, back to the movie, it had the most different ending. the events and flashes to other scenes had me guessing at a much different  and predictable ending. So watch this movie with a good open mind, accept it's few plot-holes and think of it as a movie, not a BW sequel.

poor reviews aside i really enjoyed this movie. i thought it was a perfect follow up to the first blair witch. it had alot to think about in it. and the camera work was fantastic. i personally thought that this movie was going to be terrible, but it stood up and proved me wrong. the only down side in my opinion is the acting. altough the main actor (the guy playing jeff) was great. the rest were very much "up and coming actors". i will definitely get this film on dvd!

I loved the Blair Witch Project and when I heard there was going to be a sequel, I was thrilled. But when I saw Book of Shadows, it hurt my feelings...it was that bad.I can't say I had high hopes after reading the storyline though; 5 fans of the movie go into the woods, and when they are in the woods spooky stuff starts to happen blah, blah, blah... This movie seemed like one big cliche with psychobabble. I think if a sequel was going to be made, they should have went with the "now even more footage was discovered buried in the woods" storyline and have the 3 main actors from the first one go back to film new scenes with the cameras. Of course they would be scenes from before the first guy went missing, then the house etc... or something along those lines.Hopefully Blair Witch 3 will be better.

"The Blair Witch Project" was creepy enough to creep into your dreams; BW2 will just put you to sleep. And if ever a movie deserved to be slept through, it's this sequel.CAUTION--SPOILER AHEAD!!Director Joe Berlinger said something about his movie being a comment on cultural hysteria. It's clear that he was bothered by the popularity of the first movie and wanted to burst the bubble for everyone. He robbed Blair Witch fans of the freedom to suspend their disbelief, which is a really dirty trick to pull on audiences (and other film-makers). Berlinger's plot revolved around a bunch of college kids whose enthusiasm for the Blair Witch turns them all into maniacal murderers; he was making a Blair Witch version of "Reefer Madness".

reviews.review_title: Move over Manos this is the Worst Film Ever Made
reviews.content: This is awful. It's a ungodly mess of a film in all aspects. It's got a confusing plot, dire acting, obnoxious cinematography, despicable characters and worst of all its an enjoyable experience it makes A Serbian Film look like Muppets In Space, not because its controversial but because it's one of the most terrible films put to celluloid. If you liked the first one, I would recommend NOT renting this or buying for that matter. If your a film student then this should be an example of what not to do. If you enjoy watching bad films for enjoyment (like me) then congratulations you have found the Holy Grail. The only redeeming feature of this film is that it didn't spawn a sequel.

Introducing to the movie we feel strange what's these characters, two students studying group hysteria, a Gothic interested in death a weak mind :maybe dangerous because of his recent passage in hospital, ironically and worse a witch who loved to have a contact with one of her friends the first opus witch. We fell the horror engaged like the first opus, we're back in the woods but not for a magic or human force as any horror movie. This film is leading us on a strange and terrifying way on doors perception, does perception is really objective, can we trust in our self mind, where is reality, where do we go, are we able to consider what is reality or fiction with or capricious,adventurous and dangerous mind. who are we

reviews.review_title: Just try and forget this one
reviews.content: If I had to choose one word to describe Book of Shadows: Blair Witch 2, it would be disturbing. As I left the theater with my cohorts Pedro and James each of us were visibly shaken and could not utter anything resembling a full sentence for at least half the ride home. I'm not going to spoil it for you but I will say this: Book of Shadows is not a movie that is easily forgotten. It infects your mind much in the same way that 8mm did. It reminds me of a line Joaquin Phoenix spoke in that film, "You dance with the Devil, the Devil don't change. The Devil changes you." ****

I was hoping for something more.  I didn't mind the views of the townfolk on the effects of the Blair Witch Project.  And I didn't mind the 2 second flashbacks throughout the movie. But the movie seem to be cut in the wrong areas.  Which was okay with the first on, it wasn't suppose to great big fantastic movie.  With a "10 million dollar budget", I'm sorry, I want more.  I want a professional completed movie not an independent film (not that there's anything wrong with them).As I mentioned up above, "Where's the book???", I think it the book the researcher had put together. I don't remember him, or anyone else, calling it that though.  I would have like to see more of what happened to them. Did they read from the book that night?  Did they summon her spirit?  Okay they're suppose to be camping out at the house.  I remember the house from the first one, and it wasn't just ruins.Simply put, I thought this movie missed what the first one was able to do to it's viewers...scare people.

reviews.review_title: Don't compare this film to the first!
reviews.content: The first BW was a classic! Undoubtedly! This film however, should be seen in it's own right and should not be compared to the first. Everything from the budget, the plot, the camera technique, visuals and the characters were all different and it made only a few allusions with the first film. Based on this judgement, i would say this film was better than your average horror film but by no means a classic. The plot, which never really seemed to explain what the 'book of shadows' was, had enough twists to keep it interesting to watch.

reviews.review_title: Easily one of the worst films of 2000
reviews.content: Wanna learn what's wrong with Hollywood in an hour and a half?  Then watch this film."The Blair Witch Project" worked because it was original.  It was a horror film with no gore, no "cue music", no cheap scares, and no special effects. It presented us with three realistic characters we could relate to, then put them in supernatural jeopardy - made believable by the bare bones approach.The film was an unexpected monster hit, and a sequel was inevitable. Unlike most films, a decent sequel could probably be made for "Blair Witch". "Blair Witch 2: Book of Shadows" is not that film.Everything that made the first film work has been replaced by what sucks about Hollywood movies.  Realistic characters have been replaced by cardboard cutouts, portrayed by community college level actors.  The thought-invoking plot of the first film has been replaced by copius amounts of gore.  The witch?  She's nowhere to be found.The direction is awful.  The dialog is painful.  The plot is a mess of "pseudo-reality" moments that are meant to be disturbing, but are merely obvious crutches to enable the screenwriters to show disturbing images without moving the plot forward at all.This film stinks.  Avoid it at all costs.

reviews.review_title: A group of stock characters in search of excitement.
reviews.content: This film has almost no connection with the original BWP, it is better made and scarier, but lacks the subtelty of the original, the constant sense of creepiness and tension.  There is a bit more personality development, some interesting scenes and a few genuine frights, nothing very original, and the viewer will spend an inordinate amount of time trying to figure out what is going on.  The film is  confusing, and relies to a great extent on questioning whether events have actually occurred, or have been imagined; one is never sure.  There is also a great deal of shaking of cameras, screaming, and barely glimpsed horrific images.  If you like that kind of thing, you might enjoy this movie.

I went into BW:2 expecting a run of the mill horror movie sequel having read numerous bad reviews at most movie sites. However BW:2 turned out to be a very clever and spooky thriller. The acting was not nearly as bad as most people have said. Don't go into this movie expecting a sequel to BW because this is a stand alone movie that pokes fun at the original.Overall I rate this movie 9/10

This movie was absolutely horrible.  Based on the release date (immediately preceding Halloween) and the relatively short amount of time that passed between the original Blair Witch and the sequel, I was expecting a very so-so follow up to an exciting independent film.  Holy Geezuz was I disappointed as the film consistently got worse and worse.  The plot is simple, the film lacks suspense, and the acting is laughable.  I have seen a lot of bad sequels in my day but this film takes the cake.  Wait for it to come out on cable, and then I would recommend it only if you have insomnia and the only other shows on are infomercials.

I work at a movie theater, and therefore I get in for free. I went to see Blair Witch 2 tonight, wanting to get in the Halloween mood, while also knowing that if the movie turned out awful I wouldn't have to worry about wasting my money. For all of you out there that are going to have to pay, think about it before you buy a ticket for Blair Witch 2. The original film was a gutsy, clever idea. The sequel is just like any other sequel; a pathetic attempt to cash in twice on a unique phenomenon. The movie actually starts out promisingly enough. Humorous, dark, disturbing, and very deep in places. Then, the story quickly unravels into psycho-babble madness, with fake blood, bad acting, and a ridiculously obvious plot. The first movie was frightening because of its ambiguity, the questions it left unanswered, the stark, un-airbrushed view of horror it provided. It appealed to people with a strong sense of imagination. Blair Witch 2 is mostly brain candy. It is a frightening film, at least it tries very hard to be one, with all it's images of raving madness, dripping blood, and children's voices wafting on the wind. But we have seen this over and over again, in countless other horror films, and quite a few of those have managed to do a better job than the filmmakers of Blair Witch 2. Early on in the movie, a character remarks that people are most afraid of the unknown. The makers of this movie should have taken this piece of wisdom into account, instead of following in the great Hollywood tradition of crappy sequels, shattering the mystery they worked so hard to create.

I think critics and the general public alike went into this movie thinking that it was going to be directly related to it's predecessor, "The Blair Witch Project."  This is why most people were disappointed by it.  This film carries little over from the first movie.  As a matter of fact, the point of Book of Shadows" was to condone the first movie, and it did a very good job of that. I think that the performances in this film were beautiful and the directing was jut as nice.  It was a direct film that didn't shy away from the point that it was trying to make, which was, "It is dangerous to blur the lines between fiction and reality."

This film is absolutely brilliant... a lot more to jump at than BWP, and pretty scary! It leaves you wondering "WHAT THE HELL WAS THAT!!" throughout the Whole film....... well worth the time. In fact so good that I am going to see it again tonight! It may have started slow but soon gets in to the action. A very genius idea to film it as they did!!

reviews.review_title: Not nearly as Bad as was reported.
reviews.content: After neglecting to see this film in theatres, due to poor reviews, I was impressed when I finally did rent it.  To be fair, it was no great marvel in film making, but it followed up "Blair Witch..." nicley.  Contrary to many on this page, I found the film pertinant, interesting, and well done.  The gore was not gratuitous, the acting was appropriate, and the story worked as a kind of spin off from the original.First off, the flashes of stabbings provided not only a horror aspect not present in "BW1", but also gave us a bit of misdirection, or forshadowing, depending on how close one may have been paying attention.  Personally I was trying to figure out which one of the 5 was getting mutilated.  If the directors wanted to make another B+W with college students running through the woods, they would have.  I felt that the different genre (more of a true horror film) provided another look at the story, and gave us a more intense look into the mind of the witch.For those of you who had a problem with the acting, this was no worse (and definately underplayed) than most B horror movies around.  Though it was not satiristic like "Scream" or "Evil Dead", it's actors were moderate in skill, but who can blame them.  The directors had to find no-name actors, who were willing to do this film.  How many Juliard trained thespians would agree to be in this, possably killing one's career.I felt that going from the different angle allowed this movie a different power than the first, though it didn't have the long term effect on my brain, it did make me jump when I watched it, where the first one didn't. It isn't as intelligent or creative, but if you went in expecting that, of course you'd be disappointed.

reviews.review_title: Almost stayed for the comedy... but realized it wasn't supposed to be funny
reviews.content: I've walked out of three movies in my lifetime (in 30 years of movie-going). It takes a lot for me to actually walk out of a movie, because there is usually something to appreciate in even a bad film.  But I've realized a common thread in the now three movies I've walked out on... I was actually laughing out loud during these movies... and they weren't comedies. They were however sadly funny because of the embarrassingly poor acting and writing.Yes it might have been interesting to see where it all led to in the end, but I couldn't, on principal, stay through to the end... because it wasn't worth my time.One line that struck me particularly funny, was how every few minutes one of the cast would utter "what was that" with a look on his or her face of sheer, utter, ...... blandness.FYI, one of the other movies I walked out on was this year's Invisible Man with Kevin Bacon and Elizabeth Shue.  I admire both of these artists for their work in other roles, but the acting was just too embarrassing here as well... and I couldn't sit through it.Bottom line is, your time has to be worth something.  I'd rather sit in the movie theater parking lot and "people watch" than sit through an hour and a half of dribble.

This movie has been trashed from all directions as a horror. And to be honest, as a horror it doesn't hold anything above terrible 80's movies for the intellectually abandoned. Scary Movie is more of a horror than this.But, in the aspects of a post post-modern effort in film making. This movie is quite a good addition to the industry. It continues on from the last movie...kind of and revisits many of the issues that were previously explored in BWP 1. However, the difference is, BW2 happens to prove a) Suspenseful b) Worth the money I put into see it and c)It says something about society and the mediatization of contemporary issues from everyday capitalism to the myths and legends which flavor society.It is intelligent and manages to create some background that will probably prove most important to any other movie that might be made.There are far too few open ended movies and in the allegorical world of the millenium and in the Motion Picture Arts especially, this movie manages to convey the essence of the direction that movies may be taking.As a horror movie, it is questionable, erroneous, and tacky. But, as a movie about society, exploration, and the nature of man - it is among the better and more original that have arrived on video in quite awhile.

reviews.review_title: Great plot, terribly executed. Watch 'The Last Broadcast' instead.
reviews.content: First 15 minutes is very well done, and the story itself is actually quite good, but in the end it's clear this story doesn't know what path it wants to go down. Revealing halfway through the film which characters are going to survive destroys all the tension.Wasn't the trailer a total con as well? It shows you lots of scary bits, but in the actual film these are only something that the characters see briefly and then realise they have imagined. For example, someone bursts into the room and sees the goth chick gorging on the dead bird. Horror! But it turns out to be a bit of Kentucky Fried Chicken when we look again. Oh dear!Go and watch 'The Last Broadcast' instead. It's far far superior

reviews.review_title: Better then the first, but by no means a great movie.
reviews.content: I found myself not liking the first movie, but seeing as I had nothing better to do on a Friday night, I figured I would go and see if this movie was better then its predecessor. To my surprise it was.  The whole feel of the movie was similar to the first one, but of course with higher budget and different writers/directors it was a lot different. But my biggest criticism of this movie, and the first one is that it just isn't scary.  The hype and peoples comments make the films out to be the most horrific thing since the Exorcist, but it just isn't true. A few spooky apparitions aside, it offers very little extra on the first movie. People go into forest to the same spots as the blair witch, some minor weird stuff happens, go back to guys place, a few more weird things happen with murders along the way with hallucinations in tow, and thats your basic movie. It offers very little tangible substance to the Blair Witch legend, but instead offers suspense in the form of the actors trying to piece together what is happening around them. It offers no jumps or shocks, very little horror, just slight suspense that you won't really think about at all after you have left the multiplex tucked up in bed afterwards. All in all, if you liked the first movie you will more then likely want to give this a watch, if only once.  If you didn't like the first film when Iwouldn't bother watching this one as it is much in the same vain. If you like horror, then go and watch the Exorcist, the Omen or Poltergeist, they are so much better and will leaving you thinking about it afterwards, which is what any good movie should do.

reviews.review_title: Liked the original? Hate the sequel
reviews.content: It seems to me that after asking around, those who liked the first movie, whether or not they found it scary or just totally different, hate Blair Witch 2. Obviously, those who hated the original tend to like the sequel. Why? I think it's because they are so totally different. If you go to see Blair Witch 2 hoping it to be like the original, you will be disappointed. I was. However, if you like big-budget horrors, 'jump-out-of-cupboard' predictability, unnecessary references to everything and anything sexual, a make-do plot with gaping holes, and a pointless twisted ending, then you'll love it. For those who actually have taste in movies, especially those in the horror genre, I guarantee disappointment. Forget the self-reference and sardonic wit of Scream. The tense, cleverly shot, 'keep-you-guessing-til-the-end' plot of The Blair Witch Project. This has nothing appealing; the actors give nothing to the film and could have been played by any sub-standard thespian, the plot is ridiculous and the 'scary' parts? They're just not scary. I was tricked into paying for my ticket on the belief that Blair Witch 2 would be scary, chilling, well-acted and somewhere along the fantastic, inspirational lines of the original. The truth is, the makers of this terrible movie should be paying us to sit through it.

I saw this movie last night and I couldnt agree MORE with grazzini101! In fact that review was dead on. This movie was a pointless waste of time. The acting was hideous. The characters were ridiculous. The story (?) was nonexistent. People were hooting with laughter at the absurdity of it all. SAVE YOUR MONEY! This will be on video before Christmas. The first 2 minutes were the only good part. yeck.

I agree with the reviewer below.  If you wanted to see something like the original, then why even GO to this movie?  It's for open minded people with brains, who can look at this mind trip they gave us and appreciate it.  It has a storyline, it has a very deep storyline, it has very good character development and near perfect acting (Jeff Donovan scores).At the end you don't know what's real or right anymore, and that's what it's purpose was.  Not to entertain you as much as make you USE your brain and contemplate some things.If you're going to be so ignorant and close-minded to not appreciate the goodness this movie holds then just disconnect yourself with it.  Do it that favor.

reviews.review_title: Let the movie sink in before you past judgement.
reviews.content: I went into this movie expecting to get the c**p scared out of me. Instead I walked out saying, "Wow what a mind trip." I was disappointed at first because I wanted to be scared. But I kept thinking about the film and it grew and grew on me. It is a great film and the director was successful on what he wanted to do. He wanted to question reality and video and ask what is real. Well I definitely left the theater with that feel. Great Work! Also wonderful to see a sequel taking a completely different direction with the same underlining theme to it!

The original Blair Witch movie was a major hit that drew lots and lots of people to Burkitsville in the hopes of seeing the place "where it all happened". That's reality, and that's where Blair Witch 2 picks up. It's fantasy based on reality based on fantasy masked as reality. So there's this native Burkitsville guy who's sort of persona non grata there because he wants to cash in the movie by making all sorts of thingies from it like the little crosses and selling them over the internet. But things started to get really ugly when he set up the "Blair Witch Hunt", which was this tour he organized for people who wanted to visit the famous location. At first everything was party, but then strange things started to happen. This one night the group blacks out for hours and wakes up only to discover everything they had brought had been torn to pieces, except for the tapes which the goth girl found with her mind or something. They had no idea who did it so they went to the guy's cool place to have a look at those tapes. Guess what they see? Really freaky stuff. When the movie started I got the feeling that it was gonna suck because of all the gory scenes which led me into thinking it was gonna be everything the original wasn't like dumb and unimaginative. The first half hour leaves you without much to work with because there's nothing really new. You get to see 'real' reports on tv about the original Blair Witch movie and what it caused afterwards, and you get to meet the group of college kids that was getting set up to visit Burkitsville. Until this point I had no clue as to where the movie was gonna head to. I mean, was it gonna be actually Blair Witch 2, as in everything again? But some time further into the story the movie gets its own personality. It never tries to copy the original or even use the same techniques that made it a hit. Yet, the sequel manages to keep the very core intact: the horror works more on a psychological level. You never got to see a witch or anything in the original and there was where its most brilliant achievement was. Now, things haven't changed. The Blair Witch is still only in the viewer's mind. The way they made all this work without copying the original is really, really freaky. And their excellent idea worked beautifully because the movie has a creepy atmosphere and the acting is fairly good. The ending also lived up to the original. It left a lot of questions without answers, giving the audience a chance to use their brain and give the story closure. Overall, a great sequel that anyone with a taste for the unusual and an IQ slightly above average should enjoy.

reviews.review_title: One of the best examples of a flashy, over done, inconsistent and unneeded cash-in.
reviews.content: PLEASE NOTE THAT THIS REVIEW CONTAINS SPOILERS > NOTE: This is also more of a rant then a review seeing as the film just cracks me up...BW2 follows the "adventures" of a group of people that go on a Blair Witch Hunting trip which involves camping out at Rustin Parr's house, the freaky one from the first film, and doing other Blair Witch related stuff. On the journey are four people: the writer, his wife, another women that's a Wicken (i.e. a good witch), a psychic Goth chick (cue the cheesy-beyond-words bit when she's walking with the wife of the writer and asks "When's the Baby due?" and the other women's like "How did you know?" so she says, after a moment of silence with a slow moving close up, "I just know") and finally there's the "There for comedic value" driver guy that spends the whole film permentally stoned.Added in with this are some weird and somewhat random "scary" shots of people dying in a forest every now and again, and the anally stupid plot line of them waking up in the morning with a "gap" of a few hours that none of them can remember from the night before (which is a stupid plot thread when you consider that they were drinking and smoking around the camp fire the night before so no-wonder they can't remember anything...). Then there's the clichéd to death part with the main character taking the people back to his house which just so happens to be an old warehouse from the 1840's that's located in the middle of the forest with loads of security camera's and a walkway that you just know is going to end up getting destroyed at some point.Other notable parts are the acting which begs the question of what the director told the actors to do, motivation wise, seeing as they have different expressions during the same supposedly scary scene (i.e. scared, bewildered, stoned, lost, confused, constipated). Then there's the crap sub-plots like the writers wife losing the baby (which she recovers from when the stoned guy gives her a free Blair Witch baseball cap), and the un-human like reactions of the characters (like the bit when the writer and Wicken are sitting at the table and suddenly end up ripping each other clothes off, then suddenly go back to the table staring at each other and just shrug it off. Like where's the "What the hell happened then? conversation that any normal person would ask).Add a pants-beyond-words ending which leaves you thinking more alone the lines of "Is that IT!?" as opposed to "What the Hell happened there?" and the general dialogue that barley reaches the levels of the Sun's readership with such engrossing conversations of:"Cool, I'll get the drinks""Thanks""Ok""Good"There are dozens of plot threads that are not even remotely cleared up, most notably the one with the main character having been in a psychiatric ward, and the whole film just reeks of a flashy, over done and inconsistent cash-in. Any hopes of a franchise are wasted with this film, which is probably just as well seeing considering the downhill spiral that horror franchises seem to have (Hellraiser anyone?).

I'm really picky about movies.  I particularly hate most US-made, high-budget, action/horror/suspense schlock.  "Book of Shadows" was actually a pleasant surprise.  I saw it on cable, and heard it was so awful that I never expected to sit through the whole thing.  But it turned out to be a very creative, clever and chilling tale.  Some of the plot mechanisms were indeed contrived (Now why was it that they all decided to stay in a creepy warehouse rather than drive someplace normal, away from the danger?), but I was able to overlook them quite easily because the eerie turns in events and interesting special effects came seemingly every second.  The film never dragged, and it was over in a respectable 1 1/2 hours.I must also add that this effort was much, much better than the quite-overrated "Blair Witch Project."

Does anyone know how to put all those hidden words together because for me its just a bunch af words and i dont get the holde meaning of it...hope anybody can help.I LOVED this movie ..its dark,creepy and with all those hidden clues its great to watch over and over again

reviews.review_title: Some people don't know a good movie if it stabs them in the gut!
reviews.content: I thoroughly enjoyed this movie and think it is a perfect follow-up to the "Project". Cheesy tours to the Blair Witch sites for curious tourists seems like exactly the kind of opportunity the locals would have pounced on.The dialog is good, the cast is believable and the premise is sound. Doing another documentary for Blair Witch 2 would NOT have been believable.This is an excellent horror film (with a GREAT soundtrack) that keeps you on your toes to the very end.As Tristan says while the party is in the woods, "Perception IS reality!" ...or is it?

In comparing Blair Witch movies, this one is the best. Why? It made more sense and can apply to real life. Some people get drunk, use drugs, etc and then blackout and don't remember what happens. This is almost the same thing as they don't remember and denies what they do wrong. So whose to say it did or not. I will watch it again soon for my "Halloween" treat.

reviews.review_title: not so good as Blair Witch Project
reviews.content: This movie is good, too. But not as good as the first one. Because it takes very long until something REALLY terrible happens.The end is like the original strange, but I like to think about a movie when it's over. If you've seen the Blair Witch Project and you have a little bit fantasy, you will understand it.

Okay, i only bought this because I liked the first one, and because it was cheap on Amazon. I didn't expect much, due to the awful reviews, but... it is an amazing film. I found it freakier than the first one, especially after looking at the secrets of Esrever, and I highly recommend this film to anyone wanting to watch a great horror movie.It has a great story, and I really liked the way it keeps flashing back and forth to other events. In some films this is stupid, but in this one it added to the tension and also to the story. The video manipulation, especially when they reverse the tape is good, and some of the images disturbed me more than anything in the original film.The actors are all excellent, and there isn't a boring part in this film.Amazing... 10/10

Let's just ask this question. What is the job of a horror movie? The obvious answer is to scare the viewer. BWP did just that. At the end I was scared stiff and had goose bumps all over my body. When I went to bed I was still scared. Weeks later I was still scared of what might be behind the next corner. BOS, however did none of these things. Sure, at the end, when we find out that we are seeing things as the three surviving campers saw them and not what the cameras were actually seeing, I had a few goose bumps, but they quickly went away and I had a very peaceful sleep that night.I will agree that BOS was more visually appealing than BWP, but it doesn't compare on the frightening scale.

reviews.review_title: Not as bad as everyone leads you to believe.
reviews.content: This movie is not getting a fair shake, as is the case with many sequels that must live up to their predecessor. Blair Witch was such a monumental success and such a unique film that this sequel was destined for doom before it was even conceived. Having seen it now I can say that a) I expected it to be aweful and b) I was pleasantly surprised. I can start by saying it would have been too easy to make a similar film in style so credit to the director in that this movie is TOTALLY different from the first film. It is well shot (visually), with some cool effects and a pumping soundtrack. I loved the 1st film but must admit that the phenomena was the most intriguing thing about the film and given that fact the second film does well to pick fun at that and progress a story based on the phenomena. Integrating the 1st film into the second film allows the second one to seem fresh yet at the same time continuing the phenomena.  Regarding the story, on the surface it is thin however I think this one requires some additional thought and possibly some additional viewing. This is not a film about a witch, this is a film about paranoia and the mass hysteria that can be created when people are put into outrageous circumstances, while believing in something that may not actually BE real. I do not want to give away too much of the plot but I felt that it was creative and unique. Is it a masterpiece? No, but it is not the mindless drivel that the film critics are leading us all to believe. I will say that the marketing of the film has been all wrong in that it looks like a "Scream" type teenie bopper movie and the title, well that just plain sucks. Book of Shadows has nothing to do with the film...big strike for the name!

Avoid at ALL costs.  Was amazed that suits gave the guys such a big budget. I hope the franchise runs out of steam after 3. Director? couldn't seem to make mind up if movie was a parody, satire or straight horror. Seems like a coherent film at times an incoherent mismash at others, maybe 3 will get it RIGHT?!?!?!?!?

reviews.review_title: No relation to the original "Blair Witch Project"
reviews.content: Book of Shadows: Blair Witch 2 has no relation whatsoever to the original Blair Witch Project. What actually has happened is an exploitation of the great success of the original film by putting "Blair Witch" on the title and misleading people to anticipate to watch something similar to the Blair Witch Project.The Original Blair Witch Project was a masterpiece. It was a real thriller that kept you at the edge of the seat by having a strong impact on your imagination.The sequence is a lot different. It's like comparing tomatoes with potatoes. It's failure derives from the fact that when you are going to watch it you are expecting to watch a high quality movie, as the original was. However, once the story unfolds you are wondering: "what am i watching?"To those of you who really enjoyed the original, as i did, i tell you one thing. Do not waste your time and money. You will be disappointed. You will see blood, murders, witches but you will never, throughout the film, have that feeling of fear and agony which you felt while watching the original.

i expected this movie to suck so bad i was angry at it.  how could they tarnish the clever, experimental original with this tripe, i thought. that said, i was very very surprised.  the movie gets into you slowly, just like the first.  the creeps are a slow build, and you don't realize it's getting to you until the end.  i also really liked the theme of what's real vs. what's not.  the movie seems to be about hysteria, and what people can do if they get worked up into enough of a frenzy.  the too-cool kids get so wrapped up in the idea of the witch that they blame her for their own actions and eventually go on a witch hunt of their own.  blair witches don't kill people, people kill people.  far more disturbing than the idea of a monster in the woods.  very nice.

reviews.review_title: "Disturbing and Unsettling" Damn was Harry Knowles right.
reviews.content: Blair Witch 2: Book Of Shadows was an alright movie.  If you liked the first movie, you may like this.  I LOVED the Blair Witch Project (almost religiously), but for some reason this movie just didn't seem to have the same feel as the TBWP.  It never snapped like the first one did at the end. This movie was disturbing (necks being slit always disturb me) and unsettling (what the hell happened???).  It worked, but not completely. The cast was believable in some parts, especially Jeff.  The movie just seemed to need something more.  I suggest watching the Sci Fi special to learn what Jeff did to get in the mental hospital, as it's never touched upon, and may confuse many viewers.  It does have a lot of the same themes of the first movie (human nature vs. evil witch), which I enjoyed.  I'll just finish with this: this movie was made for the people who stayed with the series. Also, YES THERE IS NO BOOK, but this movie IS THE BOOK.  A witch's book of shadows is the legacy of the coven, the artifact that is passed from generation to generation (i hope i know my stuff when I say this).  Watch the movie, you'll understand.3 out of 5 6 out of 10 C+

I went to see Book of Shadows the day it came out as I did for the first BWP. I respect the original as a groundbreaking did not find it scary.  I also liked the concept and thought it really did a good job of knocking the movie industry on its ass.Needless to say I was very skeptical on hearing of the sequel(s)...I guess the other movie is technically going to be a prequel. The whole mutli-dimensional junk they listed on blairwitch.com sounded really bad to me.  But when I started reading information on movie posters and about the time the preview hit theaters I actually began to have a strong interest.I went to see it and boy was I disappointed.  Much like The Cell this film is fairly visually pleasing but besides that it is very lacking. Poor story, poor introduction for those not aware of the previous movie somehow, and generally the film feels incomplete.  Its as if they just released a work in progress. The movie just ends up feeling like a documentary about schitzophrenia or drug binges. I totally did not end up connecting to the characters at all.And if you are looking for a scare you will be disappointed.  I admit I wasn't scared at the first movie, but not one person seemed afraid in my theather...and with good cause, as there is nothing really to be afraid of besides various bloody shots.  There is no suspense, everything is very transparently laid out.I have to admit I was quite disappointed, even more so upon learning the two orignal creators of the Blair Witch Project were Executive Producers. This barely connects to the original too only using it slightly as a back story, ending up just as a non-scary horror film unfortunately.The lack of a real story kills this film and the chances of success for the actors in it.  It seems like the movie makers just sat down and came up with some cool ideas and put them together and released it without trying to connect them.

Book of Shadows manages to be a movie for all people:  those who loved the Blair Witch Project, who hated it, and who never got around to seeing it.In fact, I think a newbie will enjoy watching Shadows before Project. Project has been reduced to a prop, a plot device to explain why five strangers end up in a haunted forest in the middle of the night.(mild spoilers, I guess...) For the Fangoria fan who hated Project, Shadows offers the classic 80's standbys of naked chicks and buckets of blood.  The script offers plenty of snickers at Project's expense.  Most of all, a few extra million in the budget gets you some of the images that actually run through these people's heads.  Trippy. For those who 'got' Project, Shadows examines similar themes:  the folly of ignoring fear, the false security of technology, the power of the things you can't see -- which is STILL scarier than what you can see.  Fear of the unknown is still the greatest fear of all, and Shadows remembers that. The fun is still there, watching these people who are SO convinced they won't get scared, learn why to be scared... Shadows is not the T2 of horror, however.  The camerawork cuts down on the Dramamine moments, but offers the strongest cliches in an otherwise refreshing tale.  The crazy house scenes are just there to pad the film. Dread and paranoia are the film's strengths, so there's still not enough jump-out-of-your-seat moments people expect in, say, Hellraiser films. Since we know that it's a movie, there's nothing to replace the big parlor trick that made Project a phenomenon in the first place. Maybe Shadows is too clever, too neatly fitting the Project, and its hype, into the second while basically recycling Project's story.  That's the new gimmick of Shadows, as if to suggest "Well, this is the real movie, the Project was just to get you in the mood."  It's a way to be all things to all people. So for those curious to see how they manage to wrangle an encore for The Blair Witch Project, Shadows is an impressive answer.  For those looking to see the scariest movie of the year (again), expect to be disappointed.

I love how meta this movie is, pre-dating the concept of "meta" by at least a decade or longer. This movie focuses on a group of fans of the original Blair Witch movie (a fake documentary, but real in this movie) who travel to the very real town of Burkittsville, Maryland to catch a glimpse of the Blair Witch. From there the movie dives into full-on psychological horror, leaving the characters and you the audience member questioning what's real and what's fake. Overall, the movie's cheesy, but fun.
I have never seen the first movie, boy was this a horrible introduction to the series.

Much like the title, Book of Shadows: Blair Witch 2, this movie does everything backwards. Instead of being a thrilling and horrifying found footage movie, like its predecessor, this sequel is more like student-made pseudo-intellectual fan fiction. It's wandered so far off the path of where the first film was, that it becomes almost unrecognizable as part of the original story. This horror flick tries to be so deep in all of its references and editing and cinematography, but it all comes off as pretentious and gratuitous. Book of Shadows was a waste of my time and a sequel I hope to soon forget.

The meta premise of the film is a great idea for a sequel, but that's where the fun ends. The rest of it is marred by absolutely horrid and clichéd made-for-tv cinematography and a complete lack of effective spooks.
Not as good as the original, but still entertaining nevertheless.
The film misses then misses again. It had very brief moments of potential but fails miserably.

A different feel from the original film that takes the fun out of the story and is all about money using a name of a movie that made more than it took to make is just another Hollywood stereotype that's true.
I have a soft spot for this film. Its not a good sequel and no way as good as the first. but I do enjoy watching from time to time. I don't know why its rubbish
This film is terrible, looks like they were going for a massive franchise which ignores the original and adds crappy sequels, but I'm glad they didn't. Definitely a cash grab. 0/100
This film does not make any sense. It's a soulless cash grab. The first one was way better than this disaster of a movie. I don't recommend this movie at all.

Book of Shadows: Blair Witch 2 is a case in study on how studio interference can ruin a promising idea. While the Blair Witch Project was controversial/divisive movie, people cannot deny its significance in movie pop culture and because it made twelve hundred times its budget back so naturally a sequel was inevitable. Director Joe Berlinger had the promising idea of making the sequel a satirical psychological thriller and the studio seemed intrigued by the idea and greenlit the sequel. Unfortunately, the studio did a complete 180 and wanted straight up supernatural horror film and as a result the script was change.
